template.name: AWS_Modern Data Architecture Accelerator
template.desc: Modern Data Architecture Accelerator (MDAA) accelerates the implementation of a secure and compliant data environment on AWS. This AWS Solution helps organizations of all sizes maintain high assurance of security compliance, freeing up time to focus on data-driven business outcomes. Use MDAA to rapidly solve complex data challenges through both traditional analytics and the latest technology, such as generative AI.

component.name: Amazon Macie
component.desc: Amazon Macie for data security and privacy.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-636
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-636: Not Failing Securely ('Failing Open') When the product encounters an error condition or failure, its design requires it to fall back to a state that is less secure than other options that are available, such as selecting the weakest encryption algorithm or using the most permissive access control restrictions. By entering a less secure state, the product inherits the weaknesses associated with that state, making it easier to compromise. At the least, it causes administrators to have a false sense of security. This weakness typically occurs as a result of wanting to "fail functional" to minimize administration and support costs, instead of "failing safe."

countermeasure.name: Enable and configure data discovery jobs
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security posture of your AWS environment, it is crucial to utilize Amazon Macie for identifying and classifying sensitive data. By enabling and properly configuring Amazon Macie data discovery jobs, you can automate the process of discovering sensitive data residing in your Amazon S3 buckets. This helps to mitigate risks associated with unauthorized access and data breaches.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console and open the Amazon Macie console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/macie/home.
  2. Ensure that Amazon Macie is enabled for your AWS account. If it is not enabled, follow the steps in the Getting Started with Amazon Macie guide.
  3. To create a data discovery job, in the Macie console, choose Jobs from the navigation pane and then select Create job.
  4. Select the S3 buckets that you want Amazon Macie to analyze. It is recommended to include all buckets storing sensitive or regulated data.
  5. Configure the scope and schedule of your discovery job. You can specify whether the job should run on a one-time or periodic basis. For continuous monitoring, configuring periodic scans is advisable.
  6. Define the criteria for the sensitive data classification. Amazon Macie uses managed data identifiers to detect sensitive data types such as personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and health data.
  7. Review and confirm the settings for your job. On the summary page, choose Create job to initiate the discovery process.
  8. Regularly monitor the findings generated by Amazon Macie in the console to understand the location and type of sensitive data within your environment.
  9. Take appropriate actions based on the findings. This may include securing data, modifying access control policies, or encrypting sensitive objects.

For comprehensive security and compliance management, refer to the official Amazon Macie Security Documentation.

Implementing Amazon Macie data discovery jobs ensures a proactive approach to data protection by leveraging automation and rich insights into data sensitivity, significantly reducing the effort needed to secure large-scale data stores.

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Review and update managed data identifiers
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure accurate tagging and data classification within Amazon Macie, it is essential to regularly review and update the managed data identifiers. This practice aligns with the security guidelines outlined by AWS to maintain robust data security and compliance. The following guidance outlines how to effectively implement this control:

  1. Navigate to the Managed Data Identifiers section in the Amazon Macie console.
  2. Review the current list of managed data identifiers to ensure they cover all necessary patterns and data types pertinent to your organizational requirements. Regularly assess these identifiers against evolving data types and compliance needs.
  3. Update the managed data identifiers periodically or as-needed basis to reflect changes in your data landscape or new regulatory requirements. This helps in maintaining the accuracy of data classification and protection mechanisms in place.
  4. Ensure that you stay informed about updates and new features released by AWS Macie by subscribing to the relevant AWS service announcements and reviewing the AWS Macie Security documentation.
  5. Document any changes made to the managed data identifiers, and ensure that these changes are reviewed and approved within your organizations change management process.

Incorporating these steps will help maintain the accuracy and reliability of data tagging in Amazon Macie, ensuring that sensitive data is effectively identified and protected according to the latest standards and requirements.

PR.DS-7: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment

countermeasure.name: Set up alert notifications
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure prompt notification of security incidents, set up alert notifications in Amazon Macie by following these steps:

  1. Enable Macie: First, make sure Amazon Macie is enabled in your AWS account. Refer to the Amazon Macie setup guide for instructions on how to enable and configure Macie.
  2. Configure Findings and Alerts: Navigate to the Macie console and set up a configuration for alert notifications. According to AWS security guidelines, it's critical to customize the sensitivity of the findings to reduce false positives. You can follow detailed instructions on configuring findings in the Findings documentation.
  3. Create Custom Alerts: For better granularity, create custom alerts in Amazon Macie. This involves defining policies and triggers for different types of data anomalies or security threats. Detailed steps can be found in the AWS blog post on how to create custom alerts with Amazon Macie.
  4. Integrate with AWS SNS: Configure Amazon Macie to send alerts to AWS Simple Notification Service (SNS). This ensures that your security team receives real-time notifications via email, SMS, or other messaging protocols. Official guidance on setting up SNS integration is available in the Amazon SNS Integration documentation.
  5. Review and Respond: Set up a schedule for regularly reviewing the alerts generated by Macie. This helps in ensuring ongoing monitoring and timely response to potential security incidents. The AWS best practices for reviewing security incidents can be found in the Reviewing Macie Findings documentation.

By properly setting up alert notifications in Amazon Macie and ensuring that your security team is promptly informed of any detected risks, you enhance your organization's ability to respond to security threats effectively and maintain a robust security posture.

countermeasure.name: Utilize Macie findings to adjust IAM policies
countermeasure.desc:
Countermeasure Description

Utilizing insights and findings from Amazon Macie can significantly bolster your security posture by helping you refine IAM policies and enhance access controls. This countermeasure focuses on leveraging Amazon Macie's detailed findings about sensitive data and potential security vulnerabilities to inform and adjust IAM policies accordingly.

Steps to Implement This Control:

  1. Review Macie Findings:
    • Log into the AWS Management Console and navigate to Amazon Macie.
    • Examine the types and locations of sensitive data identified by Macie, such as PII (Personally Identifiable Information) or financial records.
    • Review the security findings related to policies, procedures, and configurations that Macie highlights as potentially risky.
  2. Classify Data Sensitivity:
    • Use Macie's classification capabilities to tag and categorize your data based on sensitivity levels. This allows more granular IAM policy adjustments.
  3. Modify IAM Policies:
    • Based on the findings, adjust IAM policies to restrict access to sensitive data to only those roles or users who absolutely need it. Consider implementing the principle of least privilege.
    • Follow the IAM best practices to ensure robust access controls.
  4. Monitor and Log Access Activity:
    • Enable logging and monitoring to continuously track access to sensitive data as identified by Macie. Utilize AWS CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch for this purpose.
  5. Regularly Audit and Update Policies:
    • Conduct regular audits of IAM policies and access controls based on updated findings from Amazon Macie.
    • Ensure that any changes in your data storage or structure are promptly reflected in your IAM policies.

For more detailed security guidelines and best practices, refer to the AWS Macie Security Documentation.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unprotected sensitive data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data might be inadequately protected, leading to unauthorized access or data leaks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors such as hackers, insiders, or third-party service providers. Attack vectors may involve exploiting weak access controls, unencrypted data storage, or misconfigured security settings.
Impacts
Potential impacts include financial loss, regulatory fines, reputational damage, and loss of customer trust. Confidential information could be exposed, including personal data, intellectual property, or trade secrets.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses stolen credentials to access AWS S3 buckets containing sensitive customer data. Due to inadequate access controls and lack of encryption, the attacker successfully exfiltrates the data, leading to a data breach. In another scenario, a malicious insider with elevated privileges accesses and leaks confidential business documents stored in an AWS RDS instance without being detected.

threat.name: Data tagging inaccuracies
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inaccurate flagging and tagging of sensitive data can result in unintended data exposure.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Errors in data classification tools, misconfigurations by administrators, and lack of regular audits can lead to incorrect tagging.
Impacts
Sensitive data could be exposed to unauthorized users or improperly managed, leading to potential data leaks, compliance violations, and reputation damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An administrator incorrectly configures a data classification rule, leading to personal identification information being tagged as non-sensitive. This misclassification allows unauthorized access to sensitive data, exposing it to third parties.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate handling of security alerts
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper handling of security alerts may result in missed opportunities to mitigate potential threats.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include system administrators who fail to acknowledge or review security alerts in a timely manner, or automated processes that incorrectly filter out important alerts. Attack vectors may involve a sophisticated attacker leveraging unaddressed vulnerabilities due to missed alerts.
Impacts
The impacts can include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of customer trust, financial losses, and compliance violations. By missing critical alerts, the organization may not respond promptly to potential threats, leading to severe security incidents.
Example Attack Scenarios
One example scenario is where an organizations IT team overlooks alerts generated by AWS Macie indicating the detection of sensitive data such as personally identifiable information (PII) stored in an unsecured S3 bucket. Another scenario could involve an automated notification system filtering out repeated alerts from a particular IP address, subsequently ignoring a genuine attempted breach from a malicious actor using that address, leading to data exfiltration.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Improper access controls
threat.desc:
General threat description
Insufficient access controls can allow unauthorized users to access sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal employees with overly permissive access, external attackers exploiting inadequate security configurations, or compromised accounts might access sensitive information without proper authorization controls.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data can lead to data breaches, financial loss, legal ramifications, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal employee in the finance department exploits overly broad access permissions to view the salary details of other employees. Alternatively, an external attacker compromises an account with inadequate access controls, gaining unauthorized access to confidential client information.

countermeasure.name: Anonymize sensitive data in datasets
countermeasure.desc:
Anonymizing data is a crucial step in protecting sensitive information and minimizing the risk of exposing personal data within datasets analyzed by Amazon Athena. By implementing data anonymization, you ensure that personal data is obscured or de-identified, reducing the potential for unauthorized access and data breaches.

To effectively anonymize data in Amazon Athena, follow these guidelines:

  1. Understand Data Sensitivity and Compliance Requirements: Identify the types of sensitive data within your datasets and understand the compliance requirements that apply to your organization. This will help you determine the appropriate level of anonymization needed.
  2. Leverage AWS Lake Formation for Data Governance: Utilize AWS Lake Formation to manage and enforce fine-grained access controls on your datasets. Lake Formation allows you to create and enforce policies that help protect sensitive data. More details can be found in the Anonymize and manage data in your data lake with Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation blog post.
  3. Use Built-in Anonymization Functions: Amazon Athena provides built-in functions to help with data anonymization, such as masking, tokenization, and encryption. For instance, you can use SQL expressions to replace certain data fields with anonymized values. Refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation to learn more about the available functions and how to use them securely.
  4. Implement Field-Level Encryption: Use field-level encryption to encrypt sensitive fields within your datasets. This ensures that even if unauthorized access occurs, the sensitive data remains protected. AWS KMS (Key Management Service) can be used to manage cryptographic keys securely.
  5. Regularly Audit and Monitor Data Access: Conduct regular audits and monitor access to your data. AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config can help you track and log access to your Amazon Athena queries and underlying data stores, providing visibility into user actions and potential security issues.

By following these steps and leveraging the capabilities of Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation, you can effectively anonymize your data, thereby enhancing the security and privacy of the information analyzed within your data lake.

For further reference, consult the official Amazon Athena Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of Athena table data
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure data stored in Amazon S3 buckets used by AWS Athena is protected from unauthorized access, configuring encryption at rest is paramount. This involves enabling server-side encryption (SSE) for the relevant S3 buckets. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Navigate to the S3 Management Console in your AWS account.
  2. Select the bucket where Athena stores its data.
  3. Go to the "Properties" tab of the selected bucket.
  4. Locate the "Default encryption" section and click on "Edit."
  5. Choose your preferred encryption method:
    • SSE-S3: Server-Side Encryption with Amazon S3-Managed Keys.
    • SSE-KMS: Server-Side Encryption with AWS Key Management Service (KMS) Keys.
    • SSE-C: Server-Side Encryption with Customer-Provided Keys.
  6. Click "Save changes" to enable or update the encryption settings.

Enabling server-side encryption helps you comply with security standards and protects your sensitive data from unauthorized access. For more detailed instructions, refer to the official AWS documentation on encrypting data in Athena and the overarching security guidelines for Amazon S3 buckets available here.

countermeasure.name: Implement AWS Lake Formation to enforce strict access controls
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing and enforcing detailed access control policies using AWS Lake Formation can significantly enhance the security posture of your data lake environment. AWS Lake Formation provides fine-grained access controls over data stored in Amazon S3, enabling you to restrict access to datasets by granting permissions at the database, table, column, or row level. This ensures only authorized users can access specific datasets, thereby minimizing the risk of unauthorized data access.

To begin, ensure that AWS Lake Formation is set up and integrated with your existing AWS Athena environment. Follow these steps:

  1. Configure AWS Lake Formation: First, navigate to the AWS Lake Formation console. Here, register your Amazon S3 data lake storage resources by specifying the Amazon S3 locations where your data resides. Refer to the AWS Lake Formation Getting Started Guide for detailed instructions.
  2. Define Access Control Policies: Use Lake Formation permissions to grant database, table, and column-level access to specific IAM users or roles. For instance, a policy might restrict access to a table containing sensitive information such as PII (Personally Identifiable Information) to only specific roles. Detailed instructions on defining these policies can be found in the AWS Lake Formation Data Access Control documentation.
  3. Integrate with AWS Athena: Ensure that your AWS Athena queries are compliant with the access controls set in Lake Formation. When users run queries in Athena, Lake Formation credentials automatically enforce the defined permissions, thus controlling access to the datasets. Review the AWS Athena and Lake Formation Integration Guide for implementation details.
  4. Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly monitor and audit access to your datasets using AWS CloudTrail and AWS Lake Formation's audit capabilities. This helps in tracking user activities and ensuring compliance with your organization's security policies. For more details, refer to the Athena CloudTrail Logs documentation and the Lake Formation Auditing documentation.

By leveraging AWS Lake Formation to implement and enforce detailed access control policies, you effectively reduce the risk of unauthorized data access in your Amazon Athena queries, thereby strengthening your overall data security strategy.

countermeasure.name: Secure query result sets
countermeasure.desc:
Storing Query Results in Encrypted S3 Buckets and Restricting Access Using IAM and S3 Bucket Policies

A key measure to secure your AWS Athena query results involves storing them in encrypted Amazon S3 buckets and ensuring that access to these buckets is strictly controlled using IAM and S3 bucket policies. Follow the steps below to implement this control effectively:

Step 1: Create an Encrypted S3 Bucket

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Navigate to the Amazon S3 service.
  3. Create a new S3 bucket, or select an existing one where you want to store the query results.
  4. Ensure that server-side encryption (SSE) is enabled for the bucket. You can use either SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS.

Step 2: Set Up IAM Policies

IAM policies are essential to control which users and roles have permissions to access the S3 bucket and perform actions on it. Follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to the IAM service in the AWS Management Console.
  2. Define a policy that grants necessary permissions to access the specified S3 bucket. You can utilize managed polices or create a custom policy. An example policy could be:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "s3:*",
            "Resource": ["arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name", "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*"]
        }
    ]
}

Attach this policy to the respective IAM roles that need access.

Step 3: Configure S3 Bucket Policies

S3 bucket policies can be used to enforce security controls on a specific bucket. Steps to configure S3 bucket policies:

  1. Select the S3 bucket created in step 1.
  2. Go to the 'Permissions' tab.
  3. Add a bucket policy that restricts access based on IAM roles, specific IP ranges, or conditions, ensuring fine-grained control over who accesses your bucket. A sample policy might look like this:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Principal": {"AWS": "arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/RoleName"},
            "Action": "s3:GetObject",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*",
            "Condition": {
                "IpAddress": {"aws:SourceIp": "your-ip-range"}
            }
        }
    ]
}

By following these procedures, you ensure that your Athena query results are stored securely and that access to these results is tightly controlled. For more detailed information, please refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation.

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Use CalledVia context keys
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Athena service, it is crucial to limit requests to AWS Athena by configuring policies to include the aws:CalledVia global condition context key. This ensures requests are made only from authorized services.

Begin by identifying the services that are authorized to make requests to AWS Athena. These could be AWS Lambda functions, AWS Glue, or other AWS services in your environment.

Next, modify the IAM policies associated with your Athena-related roles to include the aws:CalledVia condition. This condition context key allows you to specify the services that are permitted to invoke Athena actions.

Heres a step-by-step guide to implement this:

  1. Identify the IAM roles and policies that need to be updated.
  2. Open the IAM Management Console.
  3. Navigate to the relevant policy you wish to update.
  4. Edit the policy to include the Condition block with the aws:CalledVia context key. 
    
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": "athena:*",
    "Resource": "*",
    "Condition": {
      "StringEquals": {
        "aws:CalledVia": [
          "lambda.amazonaws.com",
          "glue.amazonaws.com"
        ]
      }
    }
  }
}
  5. Apply and save the updated policy.

By including the aws:CalledVia condition context key, you significantly reduce the surface area for unauthorized access to Athena. This control ensures that only requests from specified AWS services, such as Lambda or Glue, are allowed to interact with Athena.

For further details and guidance, please refer to the official AWS Athena security documentation.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access through intermediary services
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized or intermediary services interacting with AWS Athena can lead to data leaks or malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, insiders, or unauthorized third-party services exploiting misconfigurations or security gaps.
Impacts
Exposure of sensitive data, financial loss, compliance violations, and potential damage to the organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to AWS Athena credentials through a compromised third-party service and executes queries to exfiltrate sensitive information. Alternatively, an insider uses intermediary services to route unauthorized requests, causing data exposure or unauthorized data modification.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Improper result set access
threat.desc:
General threat description
If result sets of Athena queries are not properly secured, they could be accessed by unauthorized users.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel gaining access to improperly secured Athena query result sets through misconfigured access permissions.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, potential compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages misconfigured AWS permissions to access confidential data stored in Athena query results, exposing sensitive information to unauthorized entities.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Unencrypted table data
threat.desc:
General threat description
If data within Athena tables is not encrypted, it may be accessed by unauthorized parties, leading to potential data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or attackers exploiting misconfigurations or vulnerabilities in the AWS environment.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, potential data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and damage to organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an AWS account and finds unencrypted Athena tables containing sensitive data, which they can exfiltrate. A malicious insider with access to Athena tables abuses their permissions to access and share sensitive information without detection.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper anonymization, sensitive data within datasets can be exposed to unauthorized individuals, leading to potential data breaches and privacy violations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and careless or untrained employees. Attack vectors range from direct access to the AWS Athena service without proper anonymization protocols to intercepting data in transit.
Impacts
Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive information, potential legal and compliance violations, loss of customer trust, and significant financial penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
Scenario 1: An employee queries a dataset in AWS Athena that contains unmasked Personally Identifiable Information (PII). The data is inadvertently shared or accessed by an unauthorized party, leading to a data breach.
Scenario 2: An external attacker leverages a misconfigured access control policy to retrieve sensitive data from AWS Athena, which was not properly anonymized, and uses the data for malicious purposes.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without strict access controls, unauthorized users might gain access to sensitive data, leading to potential data theft or misuse.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external hackers exploiting loose access permissions, and users accidentally sharing access credentials.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive data, financial repercussions, damage to reputation, and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious insider with knowledge of the system gains unauthorized access to financial records. An external hacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to access proprietary business information. A user accidentally shares their access credentials with a phishing attacker, compromising customer data.

weakness.name: CWE-256
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-256: Plaintext Storage of a Password Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise. Password management issues occur when a password is stored in plaintext in an application's properties, configuration file, or memory. Storing a plaintext password in a configuration file allows anyone who can read the file access to the password-protected resource. In some contexts, even storage of a plaintext password in memory is considered a security risk if the password is not cleared immediately after it is used.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Implement access controls on state files
countermeasure.desc:
Implement access controls to ensure that only authorized users and systems can access Terraform state files. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access and manipulation.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Configure strict IAM policies to control access to state file storage (e.g., S3 buckets).
  2. Enable versioning and logging on the storage to track changes and access to state files.
  3. Encrypt state files both in transit and at rest using appropriate encryption mechanisms.
  4. Regularly audit access logs and permissions to ensure compliance with security policies.

Implementing these measures significantly reduces the risk of unauthorized access to Terraform state files.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Access Control

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Implement code signing and integrity checks
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing code signing and integrity checks ensures that Terraform configurations have not been tampered with and maintain their integrity.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Use digital signatures to sign Terraform configuration files.
  2. Implement integrity checks in the CI/CD pipeline to verify the authenticity of configuration files before deployment.
  3. Enable version control and change tracking for all configuration files.
  4. Regularly review and audit changes to ensure compliance with security policies.

These measures help detect and prevent unauthorized modifications to Terraform configurations.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Code Signing

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Implement comprehensive logging and monitoring for all Terraform operations to ensure timely detection and response to security incidents.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Enable logging for all Terraform operations and configure logs to capture detailed information.
  2. Set up monitoring tools to analyze log data and detect anomalies or suspicious activities.
  3. Implement alerting mechanisms to notify administrators of potential security incidents.
  4. Regularly review and audit logs to ensure they are being generated and stored correctly.
  5. Conduct periodic drills to test the effectiveness of your logging and monitoring setup.

These measures help ensure that security incidents are promptly detected and addressed, minimizing potential damage.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Logging and Monitoring

countermeasure.name: Implement configuration management best practices
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing configuration management best practices ensures that Terraform resources are consistently and securely configured.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Develop and enforce standardized configuration templates for common resource types.
  2. Use infrastructure as code (IaC) linting tools to detect misconfigurations before deployment.
  3. Implement peer reviews for all configuration changes to ensure adherence to security best practices.
  4. Regularly audit configurations to identify and remediate any deviations from standards.
  5. Document and maintain a configuration management policy that outlines best practices and procedures.

These practices help ensure that all Terraform configurations are secure, consistent, and compliant with organizational policies.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Configuration Management

countermeasure.name: Implement encryption for Terraform communications
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing encryption for communications between Terraform and cloud providers ensures that data transmitted is protected from interception and unauthorized access.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Use SSL/TLS to encrypt data transmitted over the network.
  2. Configure Terraform to enforce encrypted connections and reject unencrypted traffic.
  3. Regularly update encryption protocols and certificates to comply with current security standards.
  4. Monitor network traffic to ensure that all communications are encrypted and detect any attempts at interception.
  5. Educate users on the importance of encryption and how to verify secure connections.

Encryption significantly reduces the risk of data interception and ensures the confidentiality and integrity of transmitted data.

reference.name: NIST Guide to SSL/TLS

countermeasure.name: Secure storage of secrets
countermeasure.desc:
Implement secure storage solutions for secrets used in Terraform configurations to prevent unauthorized access and exposure.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Use secret management tools (e.g., HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager) to store and access secrets securely.
  2. Ensure that secrets are encrypted both in transit and at rest.
  3. Implement access controls to restrict who can view and modify secrets.
  4. Regularly rotate secrets and update configurations to use the new values.
  5. Audit and monitor access to secrets to detect and respond to unauthorized access attempts.

These measures help ensure that sensitive information remains protected and reduce the risk of exposure.

reference.name: NIST Guide to Secret Management

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Terraform state files
threat.desc:
General threat description: Unauthorized access to Terraform state files can lead to the exposure of sensitive information and manipulation of the infrastructure state. State files often contain credentials, infrastructure details, and metadata that can be exploited.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Attackers can gain unauthorized access through compromised user credentials, misconfigured permissions, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the storage system (e.g., S3 buckets).

Impacts: Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, infrastructure manipulation, and potential downtime.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses stolen credentials to access the S3 bucket where state files are stored, retrieving sensitive data.
  • Misconfigured bucket permissions allow an unauthorized user to modify the state file, disrupting infrastructure operations.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure storage of Terraform secrets
threat.desc:
General threat description: Insecure storage of secrets in Terraform configurations can lead to the exposure of sensitive information such as API keys, passwords, and certificates.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Attackers can access exposed secrets through compromised source code repositories, shared development environments, or insufficiently protected configuration files.

Impacts: Exposure of secrets can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and potential service disruptions.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker gains access to a source code repository containing hard-coded API keys in Terraform configurations.
  • Secrets stored in plain text within configuration files are exposed through a shared development environment.

threat.name: Data interception during Terraform operations
threat.desc:
General threat description: Data interception occurs when an attacker eavesdrops on the communication between Terraform and cloud providers, potentially capturing sensitive information transmitted over the network.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include network-based attackers who use packet sniffing tools to intercept unencrypted data.

Impacts: Data interception can lead to data breaches, loss of confidentiality, and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a packet sniffer to capture unencrypted API calls between Terraform and the cloud provider.
  • Man-in-the-middle attacks where the attacker intercepts and potentially alters the communication between Terraform and the providers API.

threat.name: Misconfiguration of Terraform resources
threat.desc:
General threat description: Misconfiguration of Terraform resources can lead to unintended exposures, security vulnerabilities, and operational issues.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include developers making errors, lack of standardized configuration templates, and inadequate peer reviews.

Impacts: Misconfiguration can result in data breaches, service disruptions, and compliance violations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A developer accidentally misconfigures a security group, exposing sensitive resources to the internet.
  • Lack of standardized templates leads to inconsistent and insecure configurations across environments.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General threat description: Inadequate logging and monitoring of Terraform operations can result in the failure to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include attackers exploiting undetected vulnerabilities, unauthorized users making changes, or insider threats.

Impacts: Lack of logging and monitoring can lead to undetected breaches, delayed incident response, and extended periods of vulnerability.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker makes unauthorized changes to infrastructure without triggering any alerts due to inadequate monitoring.
  • Security incidents go unnoticed because logs are not properly configured or reviewed.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Terraform configuration tampering
threat.desc:
General threat description: Tampering with Terraform configurations can result in unauthorized changes to infrastructure definitions, leading to potential security risks and operational disruptions.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Attackers can tamper with configurations through compromised access to the code repository, unauthorized access to development environments, or exploiting CI/CD pipeline vulnerabilities.

Impacts: Tampering can lead to the deployment of vulnerable infrastructure, service disruptions, and potential breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker modifies Terraform configuration files in the code repository, introducing security vulnerabilities.
  • Unauthorized changes to configuration files are pushed through the CI/CD pipeline without proper review.

component.name: Cloud Formation
component.desc: AWS CloudFormation for infrastructure as code.

weakness.name: CWE-1188
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1188: Initialization of a Resource with an Insecure Default The product initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the administrator, but the default is not secure.

weakness.name: CWE-209
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-209: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-829
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-829: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere The product imports, requires, or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere.

countermeasure.name: Enable termination protection on production or critical CloudFormation stacks
countermeasure.desc:
Turn on stack termination protection for every CloudFormation stack that hosts production or otherwise business-critical resources. Termination protection prevents an accidental DeleteStack operationwhether issued from the console, CLI, API, or by an automated pipelinefrom tearing down live infrastructure.

How to implement

  1. During stack creation
    • Console: Create stack Configure stack options check Enable termination protection.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
    • aws cloudformation create-stack \
       --stack-name prod-network \
       --enable-termination-protection \
       --template-body file://network.yml
  2. For existing stacks
  3. aws cloudformation update-termination-protection \
     --stack-name prod-network \
     --enable-termination-protection
  4. Guardrails
    • Embed TerminationProtection: true or the corresponding CLI flag in every production pipeline so the protection cant be skipped by mistake.
    • Add an SCP or IAM policy that denies cloudformation:DeleteStack unless the request includes the condition aws:RequestTag{"Environment":"Sandbox"}.
    • Use AWS Config rule cloudformation-termination-protection-enabled (or a custom rule) to alert if a critical stack lacks the setting.
  5. Operational procedure
    • If you truly need to remove a protected stack, require a two-person review to first disable termination protection and then run the delete.
    • Log both actions with CloudTrail and notify the Security or SRE channel via EventBridge SNS.

Enabling termination protection provides a simple but highly effective safeguard against catastrophic, irreversible deletions in production accounts.

References

  • Protect a stack from being accidentally deleted (AWS CloudFormation)

countermeasure.name: Ensure templates containing sensitive information are stored securely
countermeasure.desc:
Any CloudFormation template that contains secrets, connection strings, or architecture details must reside only in encrypted storage with tightly scoped access:

  1. Choose an encrypted repository
    • CodeCommit (encrypted at rest with AWS-owned KMS keys), an S3 bucket with SSE-KMS, or a Git service hosted inside an encrypted EBS/EFS volume.
  2. Lock down access
    • Grant least-privilege IAM permissionsread/write only to DevOps roles and your CI/CD service role.
    • Require MFA for console access and Git pushes; enable branch protection to stop force-pushes or secret rewrites.
  3. Encrypt in transit
    • Enforce HTTPS/TLS for Git and S3; block HTTP with bucket policies ("aws:SecureTransport":"false").
  4. Remove or externalize secrets
    • Reference sensitive values through SSM Parameter Store or Secrets Manager parameters rather than hard-coding them.
    • If a template must embed data (for example, a Lambda ZIP hash), encrypt the file using AWS KMS-encrypted artifacts before storing.
  5. Continuous monitoring
    • Enable AWS Config rules (or Git hooks) that flag unencrypted buckets or repositories with public access.
    • Run secret-scanning tools (git-secrets, truffleHog) in your pipeline; fail builds if new credentials appear.
  6. Audit & rotate
    • Quarterly, review repository IAM policies and KMS key policies; rotate encryption keys per compliance policy.
    • Use CloudTrail and CodeCommit access logs to detect unusual reads or clones.

Securing storage for sensitive templates prevents credential leakage, intellectual-property exposure, and supply-chain tampering before infrastructure is even deployed.

References

  • Protect sensitive data in CloudFormation templates AWS Docs
  • Encrypt and control access to CodeCommit and S3 repositories

countermeasure.name: Implement code review processes for CloudFormation templates
countermeasure.desc:
Treat every CloudFormation template like application code: commit it to version control and block deployment until it has passed an automated scan and been approved by at least one qualified reviewer.

Implementation guidance

  1. Source-control first Store templates in a Git repository (AWS CodeCommit, GitHub, Bitbucket). Enable branch-protection rules that:
    • Force pull requests (PRs) for every change.
    • Require a minimum of one reviewer for dev stacks and two for production-bound stacks.
    • Block direct pushes to the main or release branches.
  2. Automated checks in the PR pipeline
    • Run cfn-lint to catch syntax errors and IAM typo-policies.
    • Run CloudFormation Guard or cfn-nag rules to enforce organisational policies (for example, no public S3 buckets, encryption required, termination protection enabled).
    • Fail the PR if any check returns a non-zero exit code.
  3. Human review focus areas
    • Validate logical changes (new resources, deletions, capability flags).
    • Confirm IAM policies are least-privilege and scoped to specific ARNs.
    • Ensure parameters do not hard-code secretsuse SSM or Secrets Manager instead.
    • Verify that stack tags include environment, owner, and cost-centre metadata.
  4. Merge & deploy
    • After approvals and green checks, merge to the protected branch that triggers the deployment pipeline (CodePipeline, GitHub Actions, etc.).
    • Require a second approval or change-control ticket when the pipeline targets a production account.
  5. Continuous improvement
    • Review rejected PRs quarterly to refine linter rules.
    • Rotate reviewers to avoid knowledge silos and keep security knowledge current.

A disciplined review workflow catches misconfigurations and privilege-escalation paths early, preventing insecure infrastructure from ever reaching an AWS account.

References

  • AWS CloudFormation security best practices treat templates as code
  • AWS CloudFormation Guard policy as code for template validation

countermeasure.name: Store CloudFormation templates in S3 buckets configured with server-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
When you keep packaged CloudFormation templates ( .yaml, .json, or ZIP archives referenced with TemplateURL and AWS::Include ) in Amazon S3, place them only in buckets that use server-side encryption (SSE):

  1. Choose the encryption mode
    • SSE-KMS with a customer-managed key (recommended) for full control over key rotation and granular access via key policy.
    • SSE-S3 if you do not need separate key management but still want 256-bit encryption at rest.
  2. Configure the bucket
    • In the console: Properties Default encryption Enable and select AWS KMS key or SSE-S3.
    • With the CLI:
      • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
         --bucket cf-templates-prod \
         --server-side-encryption-configuration \
         '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":{"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/cfn-templates"}}]}'
  3. Block plaintext uploads with a bucket policy that denies s3:PutObject when the request lacks encryption headers:
    1. {
       "Sid":"DenyUnencryptedObjectUploads",
       "Effect":"Deny",
       "Principal":"*",
       "Action":"s3:PutObject",
       "Resource":"arn:aws:s3:::cf-templates-prod/*",
       "Condition":{"StringNotEquals":{"s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption":"aws:kms"}}
      }
  4. Restrict access
    • Grant read permissions only to the CI/CD role that packages or validates templates and the CloudFormation service principal in the target account.
    • Enable Bucket Versioning and MFA delete to protect against overwrites and accidental removals.
  5. Validate continuously
    • Deploy the AWS Config managed rule s3-bucket-server-side-encryption-enabled (or a custom rule scoped to template buckets) so any unencrypted object or new bucket triggers an alert.
    • Include secret-scanning tools in the pipeline to ensure sensitive data is not stored in plaintext inside the templates themselves.

Securing template artifacts with SSE guarantees that infrastructure code is encrypted at rest, satisfies compliance frameworks requiring data-at-rest protection, and prevents inadvertent exposure if the bucket or snapshots are copied elsewhere.

References

  • Protecting data at rest using server-side encryption Amazon S3

countermeasure.name: Use CloudFormation drift detection regularly
countermeasure.desc:
Schedule an automated workflow that runs CloudFormation drift detection on every production or compliance-sensitive stack (for example, nightly or after each deployment). Detecting drift early reveals unapproved manual changessuch as altered security-group rules, missing resources, or changed IAM policiesso you can remediate before they become security incidents.

Implementation guidance

  1. Automate the scan
    • Use an EventBridge rule or CI/CD job that calls aws cloudformation detect-stack-drift --stack-name <stack> for each critical stack.
    • Capture the returned drift detection ID, then poll describe-stack-drift-detection-status until DetectionStatus is DETECTION_COMPLETE.
  2. Alert on drift
    • If StackDriftStatus equals DRIFTED, publish a message to an SNS topic tied to your on-call or ticketing system. Include a link to the consoles Drift details page for fastest triage.
  3. Establish remediation procedures
    • Legitimate change? Update the template and re-deploy so CloudFormation regains control.
    • Unapproved change? Roll back manually or use cloudformation update-stack with the original template.
  4. Harden against future drift
    • Enforce IAM least privilege so only CI/CD roles can mutate stack resources.
    • Enable stack termination protection and lock down the consoles/CLI in production accounts.
  5. Report & audit
    • Store drift results in an S3 bucket or Security Lake for compliance evidence.
    • Review quarterly to confirm scan cadence, add new stacks, and refine alert thresholds.

Regular drift detection keeps your live environment faithful to the version-controlled template, prevents configuration creep, and supports audit requirements for change control.

References

  • Detecting unmanaged configuration changes with CloudFormation drift detection
  • Automating drift detection with AWS CloudFormation and EventBridg

countermeasure.name: Use IAM condition keys to restrict which templates can be used
countermeasure.desc:
Limit stack and change-set operations so they can only use templates stored in your approved S3 locations (or specific signed URLs) by adding the cloudformation:TemplateURL condition key to every IAM policy, role, or Service Control Policy (SCP) that allows cloudformation:CreateStack*, cloudformation:UpdateStack*, or cloudformation:CreateChangeSet.

Implementation steps

  1. Pick the allowed repositories e.g., an SSE-KMSencrypted bucket cf-templates-prod-<acct-id> and, if needed, a staging bucket for non-prod.
  2. Author the policy
    1. {
       "Version": "2012-10-17",
       "Statement": [
         {
           "Effect": "Allow",
           "Action": [
             "cloudformation:CreateStack",
             "cloudformation:UpdateStack",
             "cloudformation:CreateChangeSet"
           ],
           "Resource": "*",
           "Condition": {
             "StringLike": {
               "cloudformation:TemplateURL": [
                 "https://cf-templates-prod-123456789012.s3.amazonaws.com/*"
               ]
             }
           }
         }
       ]
      }
  3. Use StringEquals for exact URLs or StringLike with wildcards for a bucket prefix.
  4. Attach where it matters
    • Production deployment role.
    • CI/CD service role.
    • An organization-wide SCP to stop rogue console/API usage in member accounts.
  5. Block inline templates if required add a Deny statement for RequestTag{"cfn-inline":"true"} or detect the absence of cloudformation:TemplateURL via Null conditions.
  6. Test attempt to deploy a stack that points to an unapproved bucket; the call should fail with AccessDenied (error code ThrottlingException / AccessDenied).
  7. Monitor & review use CloudTrail Lake or Athena to query for cloudformation:CreateStack events where requestParameters.templateURL does not start with your bucket path, and alert if any are found.

Enforcing this condition key stops attackersor well-meaning but careless engineersfrom importing templates that were never peer-reviewed, scanned, or stored in your controlled repository.

References

  • IAM condition keys for AWS CloudFormation

countermeasure.name: Use linting tools and SAST tools to scan templates for potential security misconfigurations
countermeasure.desc:
Add an automated stage to every CI/CD pipeline that runs infrastructure-as-code (IaC) linters and static application security-testing (SAST) tools against your CloudFormation templates. This stage blocks the merge or deployment if it detects syntax errors, insecure defaults, or policy violations.

Implementation guidance

  1. Select your scanners
    • cfn-lint for specification and regional-rule validation.
    • CloudFormation Guard (cfn-guard) or cfn-nag / Checkov / Snyk IaC for security and compliance rules (encryption required, no public resources, least-privilege IAM, etc.).
  2. Integrate into the pipeline
    • Add a dedicated Template Scan job in CodeBuild, GitHub Actions, or your chosen runner.
    • Fail the build on any ERROR from cfn-lint or any rule violation from the SAST toolset. Publish human-readable reports in the PR for reviewers.
  3. Maintain a rules repository
    • Store custom Guard or Nag rules in version control alongside the templates, and review them just like code.
    • Tag each rule with severity so non-blocking WARN findings dont halt lower-environment builds but still surface in reports.
  4. Continuously improve
    • Track recurring findings; harden your base modules so the same issue stops appearing.
    • Update tool versions and rule packs regularlyespecially after new AWS services or vulnerabilities are announced.
  5. Audit & alert
    • Export scan results to Security Hub or a central dashboard so security teams can spot trends.
    • Require an exception ticket, signed off by a security lead, for any deployment that must bypass a critical finding.

By enforcing automated linting and security scanning, you catch misconfigurationslike open security groups, unencrypted storage, or overly broad IAM policiesbefore they ever reach an AWS account, greatly reducing the risk of production vulnerabilities.

References

  • CloudFormation Guard policy-as-code for security & compliance

countermeasure.name: Use NoEcho property for CloudFormation to mask the value in logs and console
countermeasure.desc:
When a CloudFormation template needs a secretsuch as a database password, API key, or license tokendeclare it as a Parameter and set NoEcho: true. CloudFormation will replace the value with asterisks ( ***** ) in the console, CLI, SDK responses, and CloudTrail logs, preventing accidental exposure.

Implementation steps

  1. Define the parameter
    1. Parameters:
       DbPassword:
         Type: String
         NoEcho: true
         Description: "RDS master password (will be masked)"
  2. Reference the parameter wherever the secret is required (for example, in AWS::RDS::DBInstance MasterUserPassword).
  3. Pass the value securely at deploy time:
    • CLI: aws cloudformation create-stack --parameters ParameterKey=DbPassword,ParameterValue="$(aws secretsmanager get-secret-value )"
    • CI/CD: read from Secrets Manager or SSM Parameter Store and inject via a secure variable.
  4. Understand the limits NoEcho masks values in stack descriptions and events but does not hide data you copy into the Metadata or Outputs sections; never echo secrets there.
  5. Enforce in review pipelines add a lint rule (cfn-guard, cfn-nag) that fails the build if any parameter whose name contains Password, Token, or Secret lacks NoEcho: true.

Using NoEcho ensures that sensitive inputs stay confidential throughout the stack life-cycle while still letting templates remain fully declarative.

References

  • CloudFormation parameters syntax
  • General template snippets

countermeasure.name: Use stack policies with Deny statements for the Update:Delete or Delete actions
countermeasure.desc:
Attach a CloudFormation stack policy to every production or high-value stack that explicitly denies the actions Update:Delete, Update:Replace, and Delete for the resources you cannot afford to lose (for example, stateful databases, KMS keys, or VPCs). This prevents accidental or malicious template updates from tearing down or replacing critical infrastructure.

Implementation steps

  1. Author the policy JSON start with a blanket deny that blocks destructive updates, then whitelist resources that may be safely replaced:
    1. {
       "Statement": [
         {
           "Effect": "Deny",
           "Action": [ "Update:*", "Delete:*" ],
           "Principal": "*",
           "Resource": "*"
         },
         {
           "Effect": "Allow",
           "Action": "Update:*",
           "Principal": "*",
           "Resource": [
             "LogicalResourceId/StatelessALB",
             "LogicalResourceId/LambdaFunction*"
           ]
         }
       ]
      }
  2. Apply the policy
    • At creation:
      • aws cloudformation create-stack \
         --stack-name prod-app \
         --template-body file://template.yml \
         --stack-policy-body file://policy.json
    • On existing stacks:
      aws cloudformation set-stack-policy --stack-name prod-app --stack-policy-body file://policy.json
  3. Override only when necessary if a legitimate change needs to modify a protected resource, supply a temporary update-time policy with --stack-policy-during-update-body, execute the update, then restore the original deny policy.
  4. Automate and audit
    • Bake the policy file into your IaC repo and apply it automatically in your deployment pipeline.
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule (or Security Hub control) that flags stacks whose StackPolicy property is null or differs from the approved baseline.
    • Monitor CloudTrail for SetStackPolicy, UpdateStack, or DeleteStack events and alert on any operation that first removes the deny rules.

Using deny-first stack policies adds a hardened guardrail: even if someone has UpdateStack or DeleteStack permission, CloudFormation itself will refuse operations that could delete or replace protected resources unless a controlled override is in place.

References

  • Prevent updates to stack resources with stack policies
  • Configuring stack policies for least privilege

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion of critical infrastructure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unintentional removal of CloudFormation stacks or resourcesdue to manual errors, template misconfigurations, or faulty automationcan destroy critical infrastructure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Negligent admins running DeleteStack on the wrong environment
  • Templates or change sets lacking Retain policies
  • CI/CD pipelines applying malformed updates or drift-remediation scripts

Impacts

  • Immediate service outages
  • Irretrievable data loss
  • Extended recovery times and SLA breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An operator accidentally deletes the prod stack instead of dev in the console.
  2. A template update omits DeletionPolicy: Retain on an RDS instance, causing its deletion during deployment.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized stack operations by overly permissive IAM principals
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When IAM principals (users, roles, or service accounts) have overly broad CloudFormation permissionssuch as cloudformation:* on *they can perform stack operations (create, update, delete) beyond their legitimate scope, leading to unauthorized modifications or destruction of infrastructure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM credentials, and overlyprivileged automation roles.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Wildcard IAM policies granting cloudformation:* on all resources.
    • Misscoped servicelinked roles or crossaccount trusts.
    • Phishing or exploit of privileged accounts to gain leftover CloudFormation rights.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Resource Changes: Creation of malicious stacks or deletion of critical ones.
  • Data Loss & Outages: Destruction of databases, networking, or compute resources.
  • Cost Overruns: Spinning up expensive infrastructure.
  • Compliance Failures: Untracked changes breach audit requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Role Abuse: An attacker who phishes a DevOps engineers credentials uses their cloudformation:* role to delete production stacks.
  2. Automation Misconfiguration: A CI/CD service role with unrestricted stackupdate rights is hijacked to inject backdoored resources.
  3. CrossAccount Exploit: Overly permissive crossaccount trust lets an external AWS account delete your critical stacks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data embedded or passed insecurely into templates
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Embedding secrets (passwords, API keys, certificates) directly in CloudFormation templatesor passing them via unsecured parametersexposes sensitive data whenever those templates are accessed, versioned, or logged.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised CI/CD systems
  • Vectors:
    • Checking templates with hardcoded secrets into code repos or public S3 buckets
    • Passing plaintext parameters in CLI/console history or CloudTrail logs
    • Exporting stack parameters to logs or notifications without redaction

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Attackers obtain credentials to pivot into other systems
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of datahandling mandates (PCIDSS, HIPAA)
  • Attack Facilitation: Exposed infrastructure details enable targeted exploits

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A developer commits a template containing an RDS master password to GitHub; attackers clone it and connect to the database.
  2. An automated deployment logs parameter values (including API tokens) in CloudWatch; a malicious insider reads the logs to harvest credentials.
  3. A CloudFormation change notification emails full parameter sets to a distribution list, inadvertently revealing SSH keys to unauthorized recipients.

threat.name: Disclosure of template content stored insecurely
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
CloudFormation templates often embed parameters, mappings, or metadata. If these templates are stored without proper access controls or encryptionsuch as in public S3 buckets or unsecured code reposattackers can retrieve sensitive data or infrastructure details.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems
  • Vectors:
    • Public or misconfigured S3 buckets containing templates
    • Sourcecontrol repositories with weak permissions
    • CI/CD artifacts exposed via unsecured artifact stores

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Hardcoded passwords, keys, or ARNs are exposed
  • Reconnaissance: Attackers learn infrastructure topology and roles
  • Attack Facilitation: Sensitive parameters guide targeted exploits

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A public S3 bucket used for template storage is crawled by an attacker, who downloads a template containing database passwords.
  2. A GitHub repo with lax permissions leaks templates embedding IAM role ARNs and EC2 instance IDs, enabling precise phishing.
  3. A CI pipelines artifact store exposes unencrypted templates; a malicious insider retrieves them to map out VPC and subnet configurations for later intrusion.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Deployment of insecure or malicious infrastructure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Provisioning resources via compromised or poorly vetted CloudFormation templates can spin up insecure or malicious infrastructuresuch as open firewalls, backdoored compute, or overly permissive IAM rolesundermining your security posture from the outset.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD pipelines, supplychain attackers
  • Attack Vectors: Injecting malicious code into shared templates; using untrusted community templates; hijacking template repositories or artifact stores

Impacts

  • Backdoor Access: Attackercontrolled instances or management interfaces
  • Privilege Escalation: Overly broad IAM roles grant unintended rights
  • Data Exposure & Exfiltration: Open storage buckets or network ports leak sensitive data
  • Persistence: Malicious resources remain hidden in IaC until redeployment

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A CI pipeline pulls a tampered template that creates an EC2 instance with a backdoor user account, giving the attacker remote shell access.
  2. A team uses an Internet-sourced VPC template that unintentionally opens all subnets to the Internet, exposing databases and admin APIs.
  3. An attacker compromises the template artifact store and injects a Lambda function with wide iam:PassRole permissions, allowing escalation to full-account takeover.

threat.name: Configuration drift leading to insecure or unknown states
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Configuration drift occurs when live AWS resources diverge from their CloudFormation templates due to outofband changes. This unsynchronized state can introduce insecure settings, orphaned resources, or unknown dependencies that arent captured in your infrastructure as code.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, DevOps engineers making ad hoc fixes, and rogue automation scripts.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Manual console edits to security groups, IAM policies, or resource properties without updating the stack.
    • External tools or scripts provisioning resources outside CloudFormation.
    • Forgotten template updates after patching or scaling activities.

Impacts

  • Security Gaps: Unintended open ports, weak encryption settings, or outdated AMIs introduce vulnerabilities.
  • Compliance & Audit Failures: Drifted resources fall out of alignment with approved configurations, breaking governance.
  • Operational Uncertainty: Stack updates or deletions may fail or revert critical live changes, increasing downtime and risk.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Orphaned SSH Access: A support engineer opens SSH on a production EC2 security group for troubleshooting but never updates the templateleaving the instance exposed long term.
  2. Untracked Snapshot Creation: Automated backup scripts create EBS snapshots outside of CF; when the stack is deleted, these snapshots persist, revealing sensitive data.
  3. Vulnerable AMI Drift: A manual patch replaces CF-managed instances with a new AMI; the template still references the old, vulnerable AMI, causing future rollbacks to redeploy insecure hosts.

component.name: CloudTrail
component.desc: AWS CloudTrail for auditing and logging.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Activate multi-factor authentication (MFA) delete on the S3 bucket
countermeasure.desc:
To add an additional layer of security against accidental or malicious log deletion, it is recommended to activate Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) delete on the S3 bucket where your AWS CloudTrail logs are stored. This countermeasure ensures that any delete operations on the bucket require an extra verification step, reducing the risk of unauthorized access and log deletion.

Implementation Steps

  1. Enable MFA for the AWS account root user:
    • Sign in to the AWS Management Console as the root user.
    • Navigate to the IAM Dashboard and select "Activate MFA on your root account".
    • Follow the steps to activate and configure MFA.
  2. Enable MFA Delete for the S3 bucket:
    • Configure the bucket using AWS CLI:aws s3api put-bucket-versioning --bucket  --versioning-configuration Status=Enabled,MFADelete=Enabled --mfa "arn:aws:iam:::mfa/root-user MFA-code"        
    • Ensure the bucket versioning is enabled with Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) delete configuration.

References

  • AWS CloudTrail Best Practices
  • Amazon S3 MFA Delete
  • IAM MFA Overview

countermeasure.name: Add a condition key to the default Amazon SNS topic policy
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS CloudTrail setup, it is crucial to implement condition keys in your Amazon SNS policies. This countermeasure limits access to SNS topics based on specified conditions, thereby reducing the risk of unauthorized access. Below is a detailed guide for cloud engineers on how to implement this control:

Step-by-step Implementation:

  1. Identify Your Conditions: Determine the specific conditions under which access should be granted or denied. Common conditions include specific IP addresses, time of day, or source ARN.
  2. Edit SNS Policy: Navigate to the SNS topic in the AWS Management Console.
  3. Modify JSON Policy: Edit the topic policy in JSON format to include the desired condition keys. Condition keys such as Aws:SourceIp, Aws:RequestTag, or Aws:SourceArn can be used.{  "Version": "2012-10-17",  "Id": "ExamplePolicy",  "Statement": [    {      "Effect": "Allow",      "Principal": "*",      "Action": "SNS:Publish",      "Resource": "arn:aws:sns:region:account-id:topic-name",      "Condition": {        "IpAddress": {          "aws:SourceIp": "203.0.113.0/24"        }      }    }  ] }    
  4. Validate and Save: After modifying the policy, validate the JSON and save the changes. This ensures that only requests meeting the specified conditions can be executed.

References:

  • Using Identity-Based Policies to Secure Amazon SNS Topics
  • AWS IAM Policy Elements: Condition
  • AWS CloudTrail Security Best Practices
