countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail log file integrity
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and integrity of your CloudTrail logs, it is recommended to activate log file validation. Enabling this feature will help ensure that your log files have not been tampered with after delivery.

Steps to Implement Log File Validation

  1. Navigate to the AWS CloudTrail Console.
  2. Select the trail for which you want to enable log file validation.
  3. Go to the trail's settings and select Edit. In the Log File Validation section, check the box Enable log file validation.
  4. Save the changes to activate the feature.

Benefits of Log File Validation

  • Provides cryptographic integrity verification for your logs.
  • Helps to detect any unauthorized changes to the log files.
  • Offers enhanced security compliance by ensuring tamper-evident log storage.

Additional Information

For more detailed guidance, please refer to the AWS CloudTrail Best Practices for Security.

reference.name: 3.2 - Ensure CloudTrail log file validation is enabled
CWE-347: CWE-347

countermeasure.name: Ensure that trails are configured to cover all AWS regions
countermeasure.desc:
Configuring AWS CloudTrail to log activity across all AWS regions ensures comprehensive coverage and helps identify unauthorized activity, operational issues, and standards compliance.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Sign in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Open the CloudTrail console.
  3. Choose Trails from the navigation pane.
  4. Choose the trail to edit and then select Edit.
  5. To enable logging in all regions, set Apply trail to all regions to Yes.
  6. Review other trail settings as necessary and choose Save changes.

Enabling this setting ensures that CloudTrail records management events for both the current region and any future AWS regions to deliver comprehensive event logging across your entire AWS environment.

References:

  • AWS CloudTrail Concepts
  • Enable All Regions in CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Establish a CloudTrail trail to capture and store API activity across your AWS account
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing a CloudTrail trail is essential for capturing and storing API activity across your AWS account, which helps in achieving security and compliance requirements. Follow these steps to establish a CloudTrail trail:

  1. Create a CloudTrail Trail:
    • Navigate to the AWS CloudTrail console.
    • Choose "Create trail".
    • Enter a name for your trail and select the AWS region where you want to create it.
  2. Configure S3 Bucket for Log Storage:
    • Specify an S3 bucket to store CloudTrail log files. Ensure the bucket is in the same region as the trail.
    • Set appropriate permissions to allow CloudTrail to write to the bucket by attaching the required bucket policy. Refer to the AWS CloudTrail S3 Bucket Policy documentation for detailed steps.
  3. Enable CloudWatch Logs (Optional):
    • For real-time monitoring, configure the trail to send logs to CloudWatch. Create a CloudWatch Logs group and specify it in the trail settings.
    • Attach the necessary IAM role to allow CloudTrail to publish logs to CloudWatch. Detailed steps can be found in the CloudTrail to CloudWatch Integration Guide.
  4. Enable Multi-Region Trails:
    • If required, enable the trail to capture events from all AWS regions. This is recommended to ensure comprehensive monitoring across your entire AWS environment.
    • Refer to the AWS Multi-Region Trail setup documentation for further guidance.
  5. Verify and Activate the Trail:
    • Review your trail settings and ensure all configurations are correct.
    • Activate the trail and monitor to confirm that API activity is being captured and stored as expected.

For comprehensive security best practices, refer to the AWS CloudTrail Security Best Practices documentation.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access to Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security and integrity of your AWS CloudTrail logs, it is crucial to implement strict access controls for the Amazon S3 buckets where the logs are stored. Follow these steps to restrict permissions:

  1. Identify Necessary Access: Determine which users, roles, or services need access to the CloudTrail S3 bucket. This should be limited to essential personnel and systems only.
  2. Configure Bucket Policies: Set up S3 bucket policies to allow access only to the identified users. Deny all other unnecessary access. Refer to the AWS documentation for guidance on configuring S3 bucket policies.
  3. Use IAM Policies: Create and attach IAM policies that grant specific permissions to the identified users or roles. For detailed instructions on creating IAM policies, visit the IAM User Guide.
  4. Enable MFA: Require Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for any IAM users that have access to the S3 buckets storing CloudTrail logs. Check the IAM MFA Documentation for setup details.
  5. Regular Audits: Periodically review and audit the permissions of the S3 bucket. Ensure that access remains restricted to only those who need it. Monitor these activities using AWS CloudTrail itself as mentioned in the CloudTrail Monitoring Guide.

By carefully managing and restricting permissions to your S3 buckets, you help protect the integrity and confidentiality of your CloudTrail logs.

countermeasure.name: Limit access to the AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess policy
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain security and adhere to the principle of least privilege, it is crucial to restrict the AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess policy to only those users who require it. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Identify roles and users that require full access to CloudTrail by auditing your current IAM policy assignments and access patterns.
  2. Review the permissions granted by the AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess policy. This policy grants comprehensive privileges that may not be necessary for all users. Consider creating custom policies tailored to specific needs instead of using the full access policy broadly.
  3. Adjust IAM policies to limit the AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess policy to specific users or roles, ensuring that the distribution follows the principle of least privilege. Remove the policy from users or roles that do not need it.
  4. Monitoring and Re-evaluation: Continuously monitor and re-evaluate access to CloudTrail by periodically reviewing IAM policies and access logs to ensure compliance with the least privilege principle.

For more detailed instructions and best practices, refer to the official AWS CloudTrail security guidelines: AWS CloudTrail Security Best Practices.

reference.name: 1.12 - Ensure there is only one active access key for any single IAM user

countermeasure.name: Link CloudTrail with CloudWatch logs to enable real-time monitoring and alerting
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure robust real-time monitoring and alerting mechanisms for AWS CloudTrail, it is recommended to link CloudTrail with CloudWatch Logs. This integration helps in promptly identifying security incidents and unauthorized activity in your AWS environment. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Navigate to the CloudTrail console in the AWS Management Console.
  2. Select the trail you wish to monitor or create a new trail if you do not already have one.
  3. In the trail settings, find the section labeled CloudWatch Logs and click on the Configure button.
  4. Choose or create a new Log Group for storing CloudTrail events.
  5. Ensure that a suitable IAM role with the logs:PutLogEvents and logs:CreateLogStream permissions is assigned to CloudTrail so that it can send logs to CloudWatch.
  6. Save your changes and ensure the trails status reflects that it is actively sending logs to the configured CloudWatch Logs group.
  7. Set up CloudWatch Alarms by navigating to the CloudWatch console. Use filters and metrics to create alarms that trigger notifications based on specific log patterns or thresholds indicative of potential security incidents. For more details on setting up alarms, refer to the CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs Monitoring Documentation.

By completing these steps, you enable continuous monitoring and gain timely alerts on security-relevant activities tracked by CloudTrail, thereby enhancing your security posture and response capability in alignment with the official AWS security guidelines.

countermeasure.name: Log to a dedicated and centralized Amazon S3 bucket
countermeasure.desc:
Centralizing your AWS CloudTrail logs in a single S3 bucket enhances security and simplifies management. This approach allows for centralized auditing, monitoring, and the application of uniform security policies across all logs.

  1. Set Up the S3 Bucket: Create a dedicated S3 bucket to store all CloudTrail logs. Ensure that the bucket name is unique, descriptive, and follows your organization's naming convention.
    • Select a region that meets your regulatory compliance needs.
    • Enable versioning to protect data from accidental or malicious deletion. (Object Versioning)
  2. Configure Bucket Policies and Permissions: Use fine-grained access controls to ensure only authorized personnel and services can access the logs.
    • Apply the principle of least privilege for any IAM roles or users requiring access. (AWS IAM Policies)
    • Set up a bucket policy to allow CloudTrail to write logs to your S3 bucket. (CloudTrail Bucket Policies)
  3. Enable CloudTrail Logging: Configure CloudTrail to deliver log files to the centralized S3 bucket.
    • Navigate to the CloudTrail console and create a new trail or modify an existing one.
    • Select the S3 bucket created in step 1 as the destination for log files. (Create a Trail)
    • Enable log file validation to ensure integrity. (Log File Integrity Validation)
  4. Implement Monitoring and Alerts: Set up monitoring and notifications to track access and changes to the S3 bucket.
    • Enable AWS CloudWatch metrics to monitor S3 bucket access patterns and anomalies. (CloudWatch Metrics)
    • Configure AWS Config rules to ensure continuous compliance with your security policies. (AWS Config Rules)
    • Set up Amazon SNS to receive real-time alerts for critical activities. (Amazon SNS)

By following these steps, you ensure a robust and securely managed environment for your AWS CloudTrail logs, aligned with AWS's best practices. (AWS CloudTrail Security Best Practices)

countermeasure.name: SetAWS S3 lifecycle policies to manage log retention and automate the deletion of old log files
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing AWS S3 lifecycle policies allows you to manage your AWS CloudTrail log retention effectively. Lifecycle policies enable you to automatically transition logs to different storage classes and delete old log files to align with your organization's security and compliance requirements.

  1. Navigate to the S3 bucket where your CloudTrail logs are stored.
  2. Go to the Management tab and select Lifecycle rules.
  3. Create a new lifecycle rule by clicking on Add lifecycle rule.
  4. Provide a name for your rule and configure the specific filter criteria based on your log files' prefix.
  5. Under Lifecycle rule actions, choose Transition current versions of objects if you wish to move logs to a different storage class (e.g., from S3 Standard to S3 Glacier) after a set period.
  6. Configure the time after which the transition should occur, based on your retention policy.
  7. To automate deletion, select Expire current versions of objects and specify the number of days after which the logs should be deleted.
  8. Review your settings and save the rule to activate it.

For further details, refer to the AWS CloudTrail Best Practices Security Guide and the S3 Lifecycle Policies Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use server-side encryption with AWS KMS managed keys
countermeasure.desc:
Encrypting AWS CloudTrail logs using AWS KMS managed keys is crucial for protecting data at rest. To implement this control, follow these steps:

  1. Ensure that you have a Customer Master Key (CMK) in AWS Key Management Service (KMS). For more information on creating a CMK, refer to the AWS KMS Developer Guide.
  2. Modify your CloudTrail trail settings to enable log file encryption with the CMK. Navigate to the AWS CloudTrail console, select your trail, and click on Edit. Under the Data events section, choose the CMK you created for encrypting log files. For detailed steps, see the CloudTrail User Guide.
  3. Update your IAM policies to allow CloudTrail to use the specified KMS key. This ensures that only authorized entities can decrypt the logs. Detailed instructions are available in the CloudTrail log encryption documentation.

Implementing these steps secures your CloudTrail logs, ensuring that sensitive information is protected against unauthorized access and complies with AWS best practices.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Log storage overhead
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper lifecycle management, log data can accumulate excessively in storage, causing both cost and complexity issues.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Developers and system administrators who neglect to implement log lifecycle policies.
Impacts
Elevated storage costs, management difficulties, and the potential of breaching storage limits, leading to loss of important log data and degraded system performance.
Example Attack Scenarios
An organization does not establish log retention policies, resulting in years' worth of logs piling up in S3 storage. The increasing storage demand incurs high costs, and when storage limits are reached, critical logs may be lost, causing difficulties during troubleshooting and incident response.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive permissions on log storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Granting excessive permissions to S3 buckets storing logs can lead to unauthorized access.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal employees, external attackers, and third-party applications can exploit overly permissive S3 bucket policies to gain access.
Impacts
Data breaches, exposure of sensitive information, and potential tampering with log files.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages misconfigured S3 bucket permissions to access and exfiltrate sensitive log data. An insider abuses their access rights to view or alter logs, masking their malicious activity.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification

threat.name: Overly broad CloudTrail permissions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Assigning broad permissions like AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess to users without necessity can expose the organization to potential misuse of the audit trail.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or disgruntled employees who have been granted unnecessary permissions might exploit these privileges for malicious activities.
Impacts
Inappropriate access can lead to tampering with audit trails, deletion of logs, or unauthorized access to sensitive data, ultimately impacting the organization's security posture and compliance status.
Example Attack Scenarios
An employee with AWSCloudTrail_FullAccess permissions intentionally alters or deletes CloudTrail logs to cover up malicious actions or unauthorized access attempts, making it difficult for security teams to detect and respond to incidents efficiently.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized SNS topic access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without condition keys in SNS policies, unauthorized users may gain access to SNS topics.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unintended third-party access. Attack vectors can include exploiting overly permissive policies that lack necessary condition keys in AWS SNS policies.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to SNS topics can lead to data exfiltration, unauthorized message publishing, data integrity issues, and potential interruption of dependent services.
Example Attack Scenarios
An external attacker identifies an SNS topic with overly permissive policies and successfully gains access to publish or subscribe to the topic. A malicious insider exploits the lack of condition keys to escalate their permissions and compromise SNS topics, leading to unmonitored information leaks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Unencrypted log data
threat.desc:
General threat description
If logs are stored in an unencrypted format, they are susceptible to unauthorized access in case the storage bucket is compromised.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, including malicious insiders or external attackers, can gain access to compromised buckets and read the unencrypted logs.
Impacts
Sensitive information contained within the logs can be disclosed, potentially leading to a security breach. This can also result in non-compliance with data protection regulations and loss of trust from stakeholders.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an AWS S3 bucket where logs are stored without encryption. The attacker reads the logs, extracts sensitive information such as user activities, API calls, and system events, and uses this data to further compromise the system or sell the information to other malicious actors.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of real-time monitoring
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without integration with CloudWatch Logs, the detection and response to security events can be significantly delayed.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could exploit the time lag in detection, taking advantage of the delayed log availability. This could be done through various attack vectors, including unauthorized access, data exfiltration, or launching persistent attacks.
Impacts
The absence of timely log data can lead to delays in incident response, resulting in extended dwell time for malicious activities, potential data breaches, and greater damage to the organization's data and resources.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains unauthorized access to the AWS environment and uses tools to obfuscate their activities. Due to the lack of immediate logging in CloudWatch, the security team fails to detect the intrusion promptly, allowing the attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data over an extended period.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1546 - Event Triggered Execution

threat.name: Lack of comprehensive logging
threat.desc:
General threat description
Not creating a trail can result in missing critical logs for monitoring and forensic analysis.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include insiders or external attackers who exploit gaps in logging, or system administrators who fail to enable proper logging. Attack vectors could involve malicious activities going undetected due to the absence of logs.
Impacts
Without a trail, organizations may miss detecting security breaches, compliance issues, or operational problems, leading to increased risk exposure and potential legal/regulatory consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious insider disables logging or fails to enable it, allowing unauthorized data access and exfiltration to go unnoticed. An external attacker exploits a vulnerability and moves laterally within the cloud environment undetected due to the lack of comprehensive logging.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1562.008 - Disable or Modify Cloud Logs

threat.name: Incomplete log coverage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Applying trails to selected regions only can lead to gaps in log data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors who exploit unmonitored regions to conduct unauthorized activities without detection.
Impacts
Gaps in log data can hinder the ability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner. This can lead to a failure in identifying and mitigating potential threats in unmonitored regions.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit an AWS region that has not been configured for logging to perform illicit activities, such as spinning up unauthorized instances or exfiltrating data, without leaving behind audit trails that can be tracked by security teams.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Log integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without log file integrity enabled, log files may be altered without detection.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or external attackers could modify log files to cover their tracks or inject false information, potentially using compromised credentials or exploiting vulnerabilities.
Impacts
Security monitoring and forensic investigations may be compromised, leading to undetected security breaches, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, and potential legal repercussions.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS account and modifies CloudTrail logs to hide their activities, such as unauthorized data access or privilege escalations, thus evading detection and prolonging their presence in the system.

threat.name: Distributed log storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing logs in multiple buckets can complicate log management and increase the risk of data loss.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfiguration of storage policies, unauthorized access due to incorrect IAM permissions, accidental deletion of logs, and potential inability to consolidate logs for effective monitoring and auditing.
Impacts
Difficulty in managing and retrieving logs, increased risk of losing critical log data, challenges in meeting compliance requirements, and increased overhead costs.
Example Attack Scenarios
A company configures AWS CloudTrail to store logs in multiple S3 buckets but fails to implement consistent access policies across them. An attacker gains access to one of the less-protected buckets, deletes or alters logs, leading to incomplete forensic data during an investigation of a security incident. In another scenario, administrative errors lead to the accidental deletion of logs from a bucket, resulting in data loss that impacts compliance audits.

threat.name: Irreversible log deletion
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for delete operations on S3 buckets, logs could be deleted, potentially without any recovery options. This presents a risk to the integrity and availability of audit trails and other critical data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, including external attackers or malicious insiders, who gain access to AWS credentials, can use the lack of MFA on delete operations to erase critical logs.
Impacts
Deletion of logs can result in the loss of critical audit trails, making it difficult to trace unauthorized activities or investigate security incidents, thus undermining compliance and forensic investigations.
Example Attack Scenarios
Attackers obtain legitimate credentials through phishing or other means and use these credentials to access S3 buckets. Without MFA delete enabled, they delete log files crucial for detecting and investigating the breach.

component.name: CodeBuild
component.desc: AWS CodeBuild for continuous integration.

weakness.name: CWE-1190
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1190: DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

weakness.name: CWE-184
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-184: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place, but the list is incomplete, leading to resultant weaknesses. Developers often try to protect their products against malicious input by performing tests against inputs that are known to be bad, such as special characters that can invoke new commands. However, such lists often only account for the most well-known bad inputs. Attackers may be able to find other malicious inputs that were not expected by the developer, allowing them to bypass the intended protection mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

countermeasure.name: Deploy CodeBuild projects within a VPC for network isolation
countermeasure.desc: Deploy AWS CodeBuild projects within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) to ensure that build environments are isolated from external networks, thereby reducing exposure to external threats. Configure your VPC with appropriate security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to control inbound and outbound traffic to the build environments. This setup ensures that only authorized internal resources can communicate with the CodeBuild environment, enhancing the security of the build process. Additionally, leverage VPC endpoints for secure access to AWS services without traversing the public internet. Implementing this control helps safeguard your build environments against unauthorized access and network-based attacks.

reference.name: Use AWS CodeBuild with Amazon Virtual Private Cloud

SC-22 Architecture and Provisioning for Name/address Resolution Service

countermeasure.name: Encrypt build artifacts at rest in S3
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all build artifacts generated by AWS CodeBuild are stored in Amazon S3 with encryption enabled at rest. This prevents unauthorized access to sensitive data by protecting the artifacts using AWS-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3) or customer-managed keys (SSE-KMS). To implement this control, configure the S3 bucket that stores your build artifacts to enable server-side encryption (SSE) by default. Review and validate that all existing and new artifacts are encrypted at rest. This practice helps maintain the confidentiality and integrity of your build outputs, mitigating the risk of data breaches.

reference.name: Data encryption

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Enforce strict input validation in build scripts
countermeasure.desc: Implement strict validation of all inputs used within AWS CodeBuild scripts to prevent code injection attacks. Ensure that any parameters, environment variables, or external data consumed by build scripts are thoroughly validated for correctness, format, and security. Incorporate validation checks within the build scripts to sanitize inputs, rejecting any malformed or potentially malicious data before it is processed. Use allowlists, regular expressions, and secure coding practices to further reduce the risk of injection vulnerabilities. This control helps maintain the integrity and security of your build process by preventing unauthorized code execution.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Regularly update build environments with latest patches and software versions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS CodeBuild environments are consistently updated with the latest security patches and software versions. This includes regularly reviewing and applying updates to the underlying operating systems, libraries, and dependencies used within your build environments. Automate the update process where possible by utilizing AWS services such as AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager or incorporating patching steps into your CI/CD pipeline. Regularly verify that your build environments are up-to-date to minimize vulnerabilities and protect against potential security threats. Maintaining current software versions is critical for the security and stability of your build processes.

reference.name: Docker images provided by CodeBuild

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to S3 buckets for build artifacts
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that access to S3 buckets storing AWS CodeBuild artifacts is tightly controlled by implementing strict permissions. Configure bucket policies and IAM roles to allow access only to authorized users and services that require it. Utilize the principle of least privilege by granting the minimum necessary permissions for accessing, modifying, or managing the build artifacts. Additionally, consider enabling logging and monitoring of access to these S3 buckets using AWS CloudTrail and Amazon S3 access logs to detect any unauthorized access attempts. Proper access control ensures the confidentiality and integrity of your build artifacts.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties

countermeasure.name: Sanitize build logs to remove sensitive data
countermeasure.desc: Implement log sanitization processes within AWS CodeBuild to ensure that any sensitive data, such as credentials, API keys, or personally identifiable information (PII), is removed or obfuscated before logs are stored or shared. This can be achieved by incorporating log filtering mechanisms in your build scripts or using custom logging configurations that exclude sensitive information. Regularly audit and review build logs to identify and address any inadvertent exposure of sensitive data. By sanitizing logs, you protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and reduce the risk of data leakage.

reference.name: Help protect sensitive log data with masking

Maintain a curated list of build images that have been vetted for security vulnerabilities and are configured according to your organization's security standards. Regularly update these images to include the latest security patches and remove outdated or vulnerable ones. Enforce the use of these approved images by restricting the selection of build environments in your CodeBuild project configurations. This control helps minimize the risk of executing malicious scripts and enhances the overall security of your build process.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sensitive data in logs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data in logs occurs when confidential information, such as credentials or personal data, is inadvertently recorded in AWS CodeBuild logs. This can lead to unauthorized access if the logs are improperly secured or accessed by unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, unauthorized users, or external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Accessing logs that contain sensitive data.
    • Exploiting insufficient log sanitization processes to retrieve confidential information.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information leading to potential data leaks or identity theft.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust and credibility if sensitive data is exposed.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of data protection regulations, possibly resulting in legal penalties and fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to CodeBuild logs and extracts exposed API keys or credentials, which they then use to compromise other systems.
  2. Internal Data Leak: A developer inadvertently logs sensitive customer information, which is later accessed by an unauthorized internal user, leading to a data breach.
  3. Compliance Breach: Logs containing personal data are accessed without proper controls, violating data protection laws and resulting in regulatory action.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Insufficient network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient network isolation in AWS CodeBuild occurs when the build environment is not properly segregated from other network resources. This lack of isolation exposes the build environment to potential external threats, allowing unauthorized access, data leakage, or interference with build processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised internal systems, or malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of network misconfigurations to gain access to the build environment.
    • Lateral movement from other compromised resources within the same network.

Impacts

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized access to the build environment, leading to potential data theft or code tampering.
  • Operational Disruption: Interference with build processes, potentially resulting in failed builds or deployment of compromised code.
  • Compliance Risks: Non-compliance with security standards requiring network segmentation, possibly leading to regulatory fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: An attacker exploits an unprotected network segment to gain access to CodeBuild and injects malicious code into the build pipeline.
  2. Lateral Movement: A compromised server within the same network is used to access and tamper with the build environment due to lack of network segmentation.
  3. Data Exfiltration: An attacker intercepts sensitive data transmitted between the build environment and other resources due to inadequate network isolation.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Compromised build environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A compromised build environment occurs when an attacker gains unauthorized access to the infrastructure or resources used by AWS CodeBuild. This can result in the manipulation of the build process, introduction of malicious code, or exposure of sensitive data. A compromised build environment undermines the security of the entire CI/CD pipeline and can lead to severe downstream impacts on deployed applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised third-party tools.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in the build environment or associated infrastructure.
    • Unauthorized access due to weak security controls or misconfigurations in the build environment.

Impacts

  • Integrity Loss: Unauthorized modifications to the build process or outputs, leading to the deployment of compromised or malicious software.
  • Data Exposure: Leakage of sensitive information, including source code, credentials, and configuration files.
  • Operational Disruption: Interruption or sabotage of the build process, causing delays or deployment of flawed applications.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Infrastructure Exploit: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the underlying infrastructure hosting the build environment, gaining control over the build process and inserting malicious code into the final product.
  2. Misconfiguration Abuse: Due to a misconfiguration, an unauthorized user gains access to the build environment, modifies build scripts, and causes the deployment of compromised software.
  3. Third-Party Tool Compromise: A third-party tool integrated into the build environment is compromised, allowing an attacker to manipulate the build process or steal sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain

threat.name: Unauthorized access to build artifacts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to build artifacts occurs when individuals or entities gain access to the files, binaries, or other outputs generated by AWS CodeBuild without proper authorization. This can lead to the exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized code changes, or distribution of compromised software.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, unauthorized internal users, or compromised build systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured S3 bucket permissions where build artifacts are stored.
    • Gaining access through over-permissioned IAM roles associated with the build environment.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive or proprietary code and data contained in build artifacts.
  • Operational Risk: Deployment of compromised or altered software, leading to potential security vulnerabilities.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust if compromised artifacts are distributed.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured S3 Bucket: An attacker exploits a publicly accessible S3 bucket containing build artifacts, downloads the artifacts, and discovers sensitive information or injects malicious code.
  2. Internal Misuse: An insider with excessive permissions accesses build artifacts and modifies them, leading to the deployment of unauthorized code in a production environment.
  3. Artifact Tampering: An attacker gains access to artifacts stored in an insecure location, alters the files, and these compromised files are later deployed, resulting in a security breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1500 - Compile After Delivery

threat.name: Code injection via build scripts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Code injection via build scripts occurs when an attacker or unauthorized user introduces malicious code into the build scripts used by AWS CodeBuild. This malicious code can then be executed during the build process, potentially compromising the integrity of the build, leaking sensitive data, or introducing vulnerabilities into the final software product.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised CI/CD systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inserting malicious code directly into build scripts or configurations.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in third-party dependencies or plugins used in the build process.

Impacts

  • Compromised Software Integrity: Malicious code could be embedded in the final software product, leading to security vulnerabilities or backdoors.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive information might be extracted and sent to unauthorized parties during the build process.
  • Operational Disruption: The build process could be sabotaged, resulting in failed builds or deployment of insecure code.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Script Manipulation: An attacker gains access to the build script repository and injects malicious code that exfiltrates sensitive data during the build process, which is then sent to an external server.
  2. Third-Party Dependency Exploit: A malicious actor exploits a vulnerability in a third-party library or plugin integrated into the build script, leading to the execution of unauthorized code during the build.
  3. Insider Attack: A disgruntled employee inserts malicious code into the build scripts, which, once deployed, opens a backdoor in the application for future exploitation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

countermeasure.name: Configure repository policies
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively control access to AWS CodeCommit repositories and ensure that only authorized users can interact with specific repositories, you should set up and configure repository policies. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:
  1. Identify the necessary permissions:
    Determine which actions (e.g., reading, writing, and deleting code) specific users or groups should be allowed to perform. Reference the available permissions in the AWS documentation: Permissions Reference.
  2. Create an Identity and Access Management (IAM) policy:
    Develop a fine-grained IAM policy that specifies the permissions identified. Here is a basic example: 
                {
              "Version": "2012-10-17",
              "Statement": [
                {
                  "Effect": "Allow",
                  "Action": [
                    "codecommit:GitPull",
                    "codecommit:GitPush"
                  ],
                  "Resource": "arn:aws:codecommit:us-east-1:123456789012:MyDemoRepo"
                }
              ]
            }
  3. Attach the IAM policy to the necessary users or groups:
    Using the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or an AWS SDK, attach the policy to the IAM users, roles, or groups that require access to the repository. Reference how to attach policies in the AWS IAM documentation: Attaching IAM Policies.
  4. Test the policy setup:
    Validate the policy by having users perform the expected actions to ensure the permissions are correctly applied. Verify that unauthorized actions are blocked, and authorized actions are permitted.
  5. Audit and monitor repository access:
    Continuously monitor and audit repository access using AWS CloudTrail and AWS CloudWatch. Set up alerts for any unauthorized or suspicious access attempts. Detailed monitoring tips can be found here: Monitoring CodeCommit.
By enforcing repository policies and continuously monitoring access, you safeguard your AWS CodeCommit repositories, ensuring they are accessed and modified only by authorized personnel.

countermeasure.name: Enable branch protection
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS CodeCommit repositories, activate branch protection rules to restrict who can push changes and enforce approval workflows. This ensures that only authorized personnel can make changes to your critical branches and that all changes go through a predefined approval process.

Here's how to implement this control:

  1. Create an IAM Policy: Define an IAM policy that specifies the conditions under which branches can be modified. This includes specifying which users or roles are allowed to push changes to a particular branch. 
    Reference: Create an IAM Policy
  2. Attach the IAM Policy: Attach the IAM policy to the users, groups, or roles that require branch protection. This will restrict unauthorized users from making changes to the protected branches. 
    Reference: Attach the IAM Policy
  3. Configure Approval Rules: Set up approval rules to enforce that all changes go through a review process. You can configure these rules to require multiple approvers or specific individuals to approve the changes. 
    Reference: Configure Approval Rules

Implementing branch protection rules provides an additional layer of security by ensuring that changes to your source code are properly reviewed and authorized, thus minimizing the risk of unauthorized or malicious modifications.

For more detailed guidelines, refer to the Amazon documentation article:  Configure an IAM policy to limit pushes and merges to a branch.

countermeasure.name: Implement backup and restoration procedures
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure data recovery in the event of data loss in AWS CodeCommit, create and routinely test backup and restoration procedures as per AWS security guidelines. This can be achieved by integrating multiple AWS services such as CodeCommit, CodeBuild, Amazon S3, and CloudWatch Events.

1. Automate Event-Driven Backups: Utilize AWS CloudWatch Events to trigger operational backups of your CodeCommit repositories. You can set up CloudWatch Events rules to detect changes or periodically schedule backups.

2. Configure AWS CodeBuild: Create a CodeBuild project that runs a buildspec file to automate the process of cloning the CodeCommit repository and then storing those copies in Amazon S3. AWS CodeBuild will execute these actions based on the defined events in CloudWatch.

3. Secure Storage in Amazon S3: Ensure that backups are securely stored in Amazon S3 by applying appropriate IAM policies and enable encryption on the S3 bucket. This ensures that only authorized AWS principals have access to the backup data, aligning with IAM best practices in AWS security. For detailed IAM policies and S3 security best practices, refer to the AWS IAM Best Practices and Amazon S3 Security Best Practices.

4. Routine Backup Testing: To ensure the effectiveness of your backup procedures, routinely test the restoration process from the S3 bucket. Verify that the backups are intact and retrievable. This practice aligns with testing and verification guidelines outlined in the AWS CodeCommit Security Documentation.

5. Document and Automate: Maintain detailed documentation of the backup and restoration procedures. Automating this process via AWS services not only increases efficiency but also reduces the risk of human errors. Refer to the AWS Prescriptive Guidance for a comprehensive step-by-step guide on automating backups from CodeCommit to S3.

6. Continuous Improvement: Regularly review and update the backup and restoration processes to adapt to new AWS features and security enhancements. Engage in continuous improvement practices to enhance your overall security posture.

For detailed security information and best practices, refer to the following AWS Prescriptive Guidance:  Automate event-driven backups from CodeCommit to Amazon S3 using CodeBuild and CloudWatch Events

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized repository access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized individuals accessing repositories can lead to data theft, loss, or manipulation of code.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, compromised credentials, or improper access controls.
Impacts
Theft of sensitive data, integrity issues in source code, and potential downtime due to codebase manipulation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to repository credentials through phishing, then modifies source code to introduce vulnerabilities or exfiltrate proprietary information, causing significant operational and reputational damage to the organization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567.001 - Exfiltration to Code Repository

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Code tampering
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized changes to the code repository can compromise the integrity and security of the software by adding vulnerabilities, defects, or harmful code intentionally.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Insiders with write access or external attackers who have gained unauthorized access to the repository.
Impacts
Compromised data integrity, unauthorized data access, system disruption, and potential financial and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A disgruntled employee with access to the repository introduces backdoors or bugs into the codebase. 2. An external hacker exploits weak access controls to inject ransomware or other malicious code into the project.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Data loss during migration
threat.desc:
General threat description
Migrating repositories without proper procedures can lead to significant issues related to data integrity, including data loss or corruption.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The primary threat agents include administrators or engineers performing the repository migration without adhering to structured guidelines. Attack vectors may include manual errors, improper tooling, and insufficient validation of the migration process.
Impacts
Potential impacts include the irreversible loss of important code, configuration files, documentation, and historical commit data. This can lead to delays in development, inability to recover earlier work, and a loss in productivity and morale.
Example Attack Scenarios
A development team migrates a repository from an existing version control system to AWS CodeCommit without a comprehensive backup or validation policy. Errors occur during migration, and several critical files are corrupted without an easy means to restore them. This disrupts the development process and introduces substantial rework and investigation efforts.

countermeasure.name: Consider integrating manual approval actions in your pipeline
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing manual approval actions within your AWS CodePipeline ensures that code and configuration modifications undergo review and authorization by designated personnel before proceeding to deployment. By integrating these manual approval steps, you can maintain high security and compliance standards, mitigating risks associated with unauthorized or potentially harmful changes.

To configure manual approval actions in AWS CodePipeline, follow these steps:

  1. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the CodePipeline section and select the pipeline where you want to add a manual approval action.
  2. Edit the pipeline and insert a new stage or modify an existing stage to include a manual approval action.
  3. When defining this action, specify the necessary approvers. These should be IAM users or groups with the appropriate permissions to approve the deployment.
  4. Configure notifications for the approval action, ensuring approvers are promptly informed when their review is required. This can be integrated with AWS SNS or other communication tools.
  5. Document the approval process including the criteria for approval and ensure all stakeholders are aligned with the procedure.

For detailed steps and security considerations, refer to the Manual Approval Actions in AWS CodePipeline.

countermeasure.name: Implement versioning and change tracking for pipeline configurations
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and auditability of your AWS CodePipeline configurations, it is critical to implement versioning and change tracking mechanisms. This countermeasure ensures that all changes made to pipeline configurations are tracked, logged, and auditable, making it easier to detect unauthorized changes.

Heres how you can implement this control:

  • Enable Versioning: Utilize AWS CodePipelines built-in features to maintain version history of your pipeline configurations. Every change to the pipeline should create a new version, allowing you to track the evolution of the pipeline settings over time.
  • Utilize AWS CloudTrail: Configure AWS CloudTrail to log API calls related to CodePipeline. CloudTrail provides a comprehensive event history, enabling you to monitor and track changes made to your pipeline configurations. For detailed setup, refer to the AWS CodePipeline Security Documentation.
  • Implement Code Reviews: Use AWS CodeCommit or another version control system to store your pipeline configuration files. Implement code review processes to ensure that all configuration changes are reviewed and approved before deployment.
  • Audit and Monitor Changes: Regularly audit the changes logged by CloudTrail and version control systems to verify that all changes are authorized. Set up Amazon CloudWatch alarms to notify you of any unexpected changes to critical pipeline settings. For more details, reference the AWS CodePipeline Versioning and Change Control documentation.

By following these guidelines, you ensure that all modifications to your pipeline configurations are tracked and auditable, strengthening the overall security posture of your AWS CodePipeline setup.

countermeasure.name: Use encryption and authentication for the source repositories that connect to your pipelines
countermeasure.desc:
These are the CodePipeline best practices for security:

  • If you create a pipeline or action configuration that needs to include secrets, such as tokens or passwords, do not enter secrets directly in the action configuration, or default values of variables defined at pipeline level or AWS CloudFormation configuration, because the information will display in logs. Use Secrets Manager to set up and store secrets, and then use the referenced secret in the pipeline and action configuration, as described in Use AWS Secrets Manager to track database passwords or third-party API keys.
  • If you create a pipeline that uses an S3 source bucket, configure server-side encryption for artifacts stored in Amazon S3 for CodePipeline by managing AWS KMS keys, as described in Configure server-side encryption for artifacts stored in Amazon S3 for CodePipeline.
  • If you are using the Jenkins action provider, when you use a Jenkins build provider for your pipelines build or test action, install Jenkins on an EC2 instance and configure a separate EC2 instance profile. Make sure that the instance profile grants Jenkins only the AWS permissions required to perform tasks for your project, such as retrieving files from Amazon S3. To learn how to create the role for your Jenkins instance profile, see the steps in Create an IAM role to use for Jenkins integration.

threat.name: Data leakage through pipeline artifacts
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly secured pipeline artifacts can result in unauthorized access to sensitive data, leading to data breaches and leakage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders who gain access to improperly secured artifacts stored in the pipeline.
Impacts
Exposure of sensitive data, financial loss, damage to reputation, and potential legal consequences due to data privacy violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an unprotected S3 bucket where pipeline artifacts are stored and exfiltrates sensitive information, leading to a major data breach.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Pipeline configuration manipulation
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized changes to the pipeline configuration might lead to unintended deployments or security vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external attackers gaining access to the AWS CodePipeline configuration, potentially through compromised credentials or insufficient access controls, and making unauthorized modifications.
Impacts
The integrity and reliability of software deployments could be compromised, resulting in the release of unapproved or insecure code, data breaches, or operational disruptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS CodePipeline configuration through a leaked API key and modifies the pipeline steps to deploy malicious code to production. Alternatively, a disgruntled employee with elevated permissions changes the configuration to redirect deployments to a personal server, leading to data exfiltration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

threat.name: Code injection vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Malicious actors might inject unauthorized code into the pipeline, leading to compromised application code or data exfiltration.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include external attackers or malicious insiders. Attack vectors include exploiting vulnerabilities in the pipeline's security configurations, leveraging compromised credentials, or exploiting unsecured APIs.
Impacts
Impacts can include the deployment of compromised applications, leading to sensitive data leaks, financial loss, damage to the organization's reputation, and potential legal ramifications.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the pipeline through compromised credentials and injects malicious code that exfiltrates customer data. Alternatively, a malicious insider injects harmful code during the build process, which gets deployed to production, compromising the application's integrity.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Configure secure external storage for AWS Config data
countermeasure.desc:
When leveraging external storage locations for AWS Config data, it is crucial to ensure these locations are properly secured in compliance with AWS security best practices. This countermeasure involves multiple steps:

  1. Enable Encryption at Rest: Ensure that the external storage location supports and uses strong encryption for data at rest. AWS Config data should be encrypted using AWS Key Management Service (KMS) or another secure encryption service offered by the external provider.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Secure Data at Rest
  2. Use Secure Transport: Data in transit to the external storage must be encrypted using secure transport protocols such as HTTPS/TLS. This helps prevent interception and man-in-the-middle attacks.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Secure Data in Transit
  3. Access Control: Apply strict access control policies to the external storage location. Utilize IAM roles and policies to restrict access to only those services or users who require it. Additionally, implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) for accessing sensitive data.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Access Control
  4. Regular Auditing: Regularly audit access logs and configurations of the external storage to ensure compliance with security policies. Use AWS Config rules to continuously monitor the configurations and enforce compliance.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Auditing
  5. Data Integrity Controls: Implement mechanisms to verify the integrity of the AWS Config data stored externally. Use checksums or hash functions to detect unauthorized modifications.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Data Integrity

countermeasure.name: Confirm and verify delivery channels
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that delivery channels are correctly set up in AWS Config and that the service is recording resources as expected, follow these steps:

  • Set Up Delivery Channels:

First, make sure you have at least one delivery channel configured in AWS Config. A delivery channel specifies details about where AWS Config delivers configuration snapshots and configuration history files. You can create or update a delivery channel using the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDK.

For more information, refer to Managing AWS Config Delivery Channels.

  • Verify Configuration Recorder:

Ensure that the configuration recorder is enabled and properly configured. This is essential for capturing the configuration changes of your AWS resources. Navigate to the AWS Config console and check that the configuration recorder is active and recording the resources you've specified.

Details can be found here: Managing the Configuration Recorder.

  • Validate Resource Recording:

To confirm that AWS Config is recording the resources as expected, review the recorded configurations and compliance status of your resources. Regularly check AWS Config console or use AWS CLI commands to make sure all intended resources are being tracked and that there are no gaps in recording.

For comprehensive guidance, see Evaluating AWS Resource Configurations with AWS Config.

  • Enable Notifications:

Set up Amazon SNS notifications to receive alerts about configuration changes. This ensures that you are promptly informed about any changes to your AWS resources configurations. Configure SNS topics and subscriptions as needed.

Refer to Monitoring AWS Config with Amazon SNS for additional details.

  • Review and Audit Regularly:

Regularly audit your AWS Config settings and delivery channels to ensure continuous compliance with your security policies and to adhere to best practices. Conduct periodic checks to ensure that everything is set up and operating as required.

Best practices for auditing AWS Config can be found in the official documentation AWS Config Security Best Practices.

By following these steps, you can ensure that AWS Config delivery channels are correctly set up and the service is recording resources effectively, aligning with AWS security best practices.

countermeasure.name: Enable continuous monitoring of configuration changes
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure continuous compliance with best practices, it is crucial to leverage AWS Config rules for monitoring and evaluating configuration changes. Follow these steps to implement this control effectively:

  1. Enable AWS Config in your AWS account by navigating to the AWS Management Console, selecting AWS Config, and following the setup wizard to specify the resources you want to track and the Amazon S3 bucket for storing configuration snapshots.
  2. Create AWS Config rules to define desired configurations and compliance standards. You can choose from the pre-built rules provided by AWS or create custom ones to meet specific requirements. For detailed instructions, refer to the AWS Config documentation on evaluating resource configurations.
  3. Configure the rules to continuously monitor resources by setting the appropriate triggers, such as configuration changes or periodic evaluations. Ensure that the rules are set to remediate non-compliant resources automatically if necessary, by attaching AWS Systems Manager Automation documents.
  4. Review and analyze the compliance reports generated by AWS Config. These reports provide insights into the status of your resources and help identify areas that need attention. Utilize the AWS Config console for a comprehensive overview of compliance status.
  5. Leverage the integration with AWS CloudTrail to track API calls and detect changes in resource configurations. This integration enhances your ability to investigate and respond to unauthorized changes. Refer to the AWS Config and AWS CloudTrail integration guide for more details.

By following these steps and utilizing AWS Config rules, you can achieve continuous monitoring and compliance with best practices, significantly enhancing your cloud security posture. For more information, refer to the AWS Config security documentation.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt AWS Config data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that data collected by AWS Config is protected against unauthorized access, it is essential to apply AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for encryption. AWS Config supports encrypting data at rest using AWS KMS keys. Follow the steps below to configure AWS KMS for your AWS Config:

Set up a Customer Master Key (CMK) in AWS KMS:

Navigate to the AWS KMS console and create a CMK by following the steps delineated in the AWS KMS Developer Guide. Ensure that the CMK policies are configured to grant the necessary permissions for your AWS Config.

Apply the CMK to AWS Config:

AWS Config uses the KMS key to encrypt configuration data at rest. To ensure AWS Config uses your CMK, update the AWS Config settings to specify the KMS key ARN that you have created. For detailed instructions on applying the CMK to AWS Config, refer to the guidance provided in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

Verify Permissions:

Confirm that AWS Config has the necessary permissions to use the KMS CMK. The AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles or users associated with AWS Config should have the necessary kms:Encrypt and kms:Decrypt permissions for the CMK in its policy. Refer to the section on IAM roles for AWS Config for comprehensive information on configuring IAM permissions.

Enable AWS Config:

Once you have set up the CMK and granted the appropriate permissions, enable AWS Config and specify the KMS key ARN in the AWS Config settings. Detailed guidance is available in the Setting Up AWS Config documentation.

By following these steps, you can securely encrypt the configuration data collected by AWS Config, thereby mitigating the risk of unauthorized data access. For additional security recommendations and best practices, consult the AWS Config Developer Guide's Security and Compliance section.

countermeasure.name: Require logging of all AWS Config rule changes
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Config setup, it is essential to leverage the AWS Config rule history to monitor changes to rules and detect any unauthorized modifications. This countermeasure strengthens your cloud environment by ensuring that any changes in the AWS Config rules are tracked and reviewed. The following steps guide a cloud engineer on how to implement this control:

  • Enable AWS Config:

First, ensure that AWS Config is enabled in your AWS environment. Refer to the official documentation for setting up AWS Config: Setting Up AWS Config.

  • Configure Rule History:

AWS Config automatically keeps a history of rule evaluations. To access and review the rule history, navigate to the AWS Config console and go to the Rules section. From there, select a specific rule to view its configuration changes and history.

  • Monitor Changes:

Regularly review the AWS Config rules history to identify any unauthorized modifications. This can be done through the AWS Config console, where you can view detailed change logs for each rule.

  • Automate Alerts:

Set up Amazon CloudWatch alarms or AWS Config notifications to alert administrators of specific changes in AWS Config rules. This ensures timely detection and response to unauthorized activities. Detailed guidance on configuring notifications can be found here: Monitoring AWS Config with Amazon CloudWatch.

  • Audit and Compliance:

Additionally, integrate AWS Config rule history reviews into your regular security audits and compliance checks. This helps in maintaining a secure and compliant cloud environment. Refer to the auditing guidelines provided by AWS: Ensuring Compliance with AWS Config.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to AWS Config snapshots
countermeasure.desc:
To apply AWS IAM policies to control who can view, modify, or delete AWS Config snapshots, follow these steps to ensure that only authorized users have the necessary permissions:

  1. Navigate to the IAM service in the AWS Management Console.

  2. Create an IAM policy that defines the permissions for viewing, modifying, and deleting AWS Config snapshots. Use the following JSON policy document as a template:

    {
            "Version": "2012-10-17",
            "Statement": [
                {
                    "Effect": "Allow",
                    "Action": [
                        "config:DeliverConfigSnapshot",
                        "config:DescribeConfigurationRecorders",
                        "config:DescribeConfigurationRecorderStatus",
                        "config:GetComplianceDetailsByConfigRule",
                        "config:GetComplianceSummaryByConfigRule",
                        "config:DescribeConfigRuleEvaluationStatus",
                        "config:DescribeConfigRules",
                        "config:DescribeConfigurationAggregatorSourcesStatus",
                        "config:DescribeConfigurationAggregators",
                        "config:DescribeAggregationAuthorizations",
                        "config:SelectResourceConfig"
                    ],
                    "Resource": "*"
                }
            ]
        }

  3. Attach this policy to an IAM user, group, or role that requires the specified permissions.

  4. Test the permissions by logging in with an account that has the newly attached policy and attempting to view, modify, or delete AWS Config snapshots. Ensure that unauthorized actions are appropriately blocked.

For detailed guidance on restricting AWS Config access, refer to the AWS Config Developer Guide: Restricting Access to AWS Config.

Additionally, for overall security best practices and information, see the "Security in AWS Config" section in the AWS Config Developer Guide: Security in AWS Config.

countermeasure.name: Use external ID for role assumption
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your cross-service roles and prevent confused deputy attacks when using AWS Config, it's critical to specify an external ID. This ensures that only the correct, intended AWS service can assume the role.

Heres a step-by-step guide on implementing this control:

  1. Create or Edit the IAM Role:
    • Go to the IAM console.
    • Select 'Roles' from the navigation pane.
    • If creating a new role, click 'Create role' and select the AWS service that will assume this role. If editing an existing role, choose the role from the list.
  2. Specify Trust Relationships:
    • In the role trust policy, add or modify the policy to include the sts:ExternalId condition. This must match the external ID provided by the trusted AWS service.
    • Example trust policy snippet: 
      {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Principal": {"Service": ".amazonaws.com"},
    "Action": "sts:AssumeRole",
    "Condition": {"StringEquals": {"sts:ExternalId": "external-id-value"}}
}
  3. Provide the External ID:
    • Share the external ID with the trusted AWS service or external party that requires access. Ensure this is done securely.

Following these steps helps mitigate the risk of confused deputy attacks by ensuring that only the intended AWS service can assume the IAM role with the specified external ID. For more detailed information and security guidelines, refer to the official AWS documentation on Cross-Service Confused Deputy Prevention and the AWS Config Security Page.
