usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Cross-service confused deputy attacks
threat.desc:
General threat description
In a cross-service confused deputy attack, an attacker can trick a more privileged service into performing actions on their behalf, potentially leading to unauthorized access or changes.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors exploit the trust relationships between different AWS services by manipulating the requests in a way that makes a privileged service act on their behalf. This often involves the misuse of IAM roles and policies.
Impacts
Successful attacks can result in unauthorized access to sensitive data, unauthorized modifications of resources, execution of unintended code, and potentially significant financial costs as a result of misuse of cloud resources.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a compromised low-privilege service to send a request to a more privileged service, leveraging an overly permissive IAM policy. The privileged service then performs sensitive actions such as accessing confidential data stored in S3 buckets, initiating EC2 instances, or modifying security group rules on behalf of the attacker.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1528 - Steal Application Access Token

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insufficient data protection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate protection of data collected by AWS Config can result in unauthorized access to sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious insiders, external attackers, or entities exploiting misconfigured AWS Config settings. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized access due to poor encryption practices, lack of proper IAM policies, or network vulnerabilities leading to data breaches.
Impacts
Impacts of inadequate data protection can include exposure of sensitive information, potential regulatory fines, loss of customer trust, and considerable financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits improperly configured IAM policies to gain access to AWS Config data, leading to the exposure of sensitive information such as compliance reports and resource configurations. In another scenario, a malicious insider downloads unencrypted AWS Config data stored in an S3 bucket and sells it on the dark web, compromising organizational security.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to AWS Config snapshots
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to AWS Config snapshots can expose historical configuration data, potentially leading to security risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers or malicious insiders who gain unauthorized access to AWS Config snapshots through misconfigured access policies or stolen credentials. Attack vectors could involve exploiting weak or improperly managed IAM roles or permissions.
Impacts
The exposure of historical configuration data can lead to significant security risks, including the ability to understand configurations over time, potentially revealing vulnerabilities, non-compliance with internal policies, or regulatory requirements. Additionally, this data could be used to craft more sophisticated and targeted attacks on the AWS environment.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an application with permissions to access AWS Config snapshots, subsequently gaining unauthorized access to the historical configuration data. 2. A compromised user account with insufficiently restricted permissions accesses and exfiltrates AWS Config snapshots, using the data to understand the organization's security posture and plan further attacks. 3. An insider with appropriate access permissions intentionally downloads and shares AWS Config snapshots, leading to a data leak and exposing sensitive configuration history.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1619 - Cloud Storage Object Discovery

threat.name: Insecure external data storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing AWS Config data in insecure external locations can lead to data breaches and unauthorized access.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigurations or weaknesses in external storage locations to gain unauthorized access to AWS Config data.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to AWS Config data can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive configuration information, and potential compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attack may occur if AWS Config data is stored in an unsecured S3 bucket with improper access controls, allowing an attacker to access and exfiltrate the data. Another scenario could involve misconfigured permissions on a third-party storage service that inadvertently exposes the data to unauthorized users.

threat.name: Improperly configured delivery channels
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured delivery channels can result in AWS Config not recording resource configurations or changes, leading to gaps in compliance and security monitoring.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfigured settings by users, insufficient access controls, or automated scripts with incorrect configurations.
Impacts
Gaps in compliance reporting, undetected configuration changes, reduced ability to track resource state over time, increased risk of security breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An administrator accidentally configures the delivery channel to point to a non-existent S3 bucket, leading to loss of recorded configuration data. 2. Automated scripts that provision cloud infrastructure misconfigure the delivery channel, resulting in an inability to monitor new resource configurations. 3. Insufficient access controls allow an unauthorized user to modify the delivery channel settings, disrupting the tracking of compliance and security-related data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized config rule changes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized changes to AWS Config rules can lead to misconfigurations and potential security vulnerabilities in your AWS environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal actors such as employees or external attackers who have gained unauthorized access to the AWS management console or API.
Impacts
Misconfigurations in the AWS environment, leading to potential data breaches, compliance violations, and exposure to further attacks.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS management console and modifies AWS Config rules to allow insecure resource configurations. This could weaken the security posture of the infrastructure, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data or services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of configuration changes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failure to adequately monitor configuration changes can lead to unnoticed misconfigurations that pose security risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include internal users with configuration access and external attackers who exploit vulnerabilities. Attack vectors involve unauthorized changes to configurations that go undetected.
Impacts
Impacts include potential unauthorized data access, data breaches, compliance violations, and compromised system integrity.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal user maliciously alters security group rules to allow unrestricted access. Due to lack of monitoring, the change goes unnoticed, resulting in unauthorized data extraction by an external attacker who exploits the open access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

countermeasure.name: Evaluate the library/service security posture
countermeasure.desc:
Create a workflow for the team to evaluate the security and integrity of data handled by third-party libraries or services integrated into your analytics and visualization projects by following these actionable steps:

  • Assess the service's security and privacy track record. Research any past security breaches or vulnerabilities that have been publicly disclosed. Use resources like CVE (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) and NVD (National Vulnerability Database) to check for any known issues.
  • Verify that the service implements robust encryption techniques to protect data both in transit and at rest. Ensure configurations allow for secure integration practices. Consult the OWASP Cheat Sheet Series for best practices on secure communication and storage.
  • Confirm that the service minimizes data retention, especially for sensitive data and metadata. Ensure that any data storage complies with applicable privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA). Review the services data retention policies and mechanisms for secure data deletion.
  • Continuously monitor the security practices of the service provider. Subscribe to their security bulletins or use automated tools like Google Alerts to stay informed about any updates or issues related to their services.

By systematically evaluating the security measures and practices of third-party services, developers can better protect sensitive data and comply with regulatory requirements.

reference.name: How do you evaluate third-party libraries for security?

countermeasure.name: Secure data connectors and API integration
countermeasure.desc:
To protect the integrity and confidentiality of data exchanged between your system and any utilized libraries or tools, adhere to the following steps:

  • Regularly update all libraries to mitigate vulnerabilities exposed in older versions. Utilize tools like Dependabot or Snyk to automate dependency updates and vulnerability alerts.
  • Restrict API access to authorized systems, services, and users only. Implement authentication mechanisms such as API keys, tokens, or OAuth. Ensure that these credentials are stored securely, such as in environment variables or dedicated secrets management tools.
  • Encrypt data in transit using TLS protocols to safeguard data from interception and tampering. Ensure that TLS implementation is up-to-date by following guidelines from the OpenSSL Project or similar.
  • Continuously monitor API interactions and data transfers for unusual or unauthorized activities. Set up logging for all access and transactions to facilitate auditing and forensic analysis. Tools like Splunk or ELK Stack can be instrumental for monitoring and logging.
  • Implement input validation techniques to prevent common web vulnerabilities such as cross-site scripting (XSS) and SQL injection. Tools like OWASP ESAPI can be utilized for secure input handling.

By following these steps, developers without prior security experience can significantly enhance the security of data connectors and API integrations in their applications.

reference.name: How to Prevent Data Breach Risks in Integration and Third-Party Apps
Navigating Third-Party Library Security: Best Practices for Safe Dependency Management

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to sensitive data exposed through misconfigurations or vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When integrating third-party data analytics and visualization tools or libraries, organizations may encounter misalignments in security postures. Such discrepancies can expose sensitive data through misconfigurations or vulnerabilities inherent in these tools. This exposure is particularly concerning if the third-party service fails to adhere to stringent data protection standards such as GDPR or HIPAA, which are crucial for maintaining confidentiality and compliance.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors
Threat agents include external attackers exploiting known vulnerabilities, insiders exploiting system weaknesses, or even third-party vendors whose inadequate security measures provide a gateway to sensitive data. Common attack vectors involve exploiting misconfigurations in the analytics setup, using compromised credentials to gain unauthorized access, or exploiting vulnerabilities within the analytics and visualization software itself.

Impacts
The consequences of unauthorized access to sensitive data through these vulnerabilities can be severe. Beyond the immediate breach of confidentiality, there can be a violation of compliance regulations, resulting in hefty fines and damaged reputations. Furthermore, the integrity of data analysis and business decision-making processes can be compromised, leading to strategic missteps based on inaccurate or manipulated data insights.

Example Attack Scenarios
Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a misconfiguration in a data visualization tool that exposes sensitive customer data. Using this access point, the attacker extracts data, leading to a significant breach of customer privacy and compliance violations.
Scenario 2: A developer integrates a visualization library without properly assessing its security features, leading to the integration of a library with known vulnerabilities. An attacker exploits these vulnerabilities to inject malicious code, gaining access to the entire data flow within the organization.

reference.name: A05:2021 Security Misconfiguration
Security Misconfigurations Caused 35% of All Time Cyber Incidents

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious or erroneous data into your analytics and visualization pipeline
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
In this scenario, attackers target the data analytics and visualization tools or libraries integrated into applications. By injecting malicious or erroneous data into the analytics and visualization pipeline, attackers can manipulate the output and functionality of these tools. This manipulation not only misleads end-users with deceptive data visualizations but can also serve as a conduit for executing more severe attacks, including the execution of malicious scripts directly through the visualization components.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors
The primary threat agents in this scenario are cyber attackers who possess skills in crafting deceptive data or scripts capable of compromising data integrity or security. These attackers may include external malicious actors, insider threats, or even third parties with temporary access to the system. Common attack vectors involve injecting falsified data or scripts into data streams that feed into the visualization tools, exploiting weak input validation mechanisms to deliver malicious payloads.

Impacts
The impacts of such attacks are multifaceted. Initially, there is the direct deception of users through manipulated visual data, which can lead to erroneous business decisions. More dangerously, if the attack escalates to script execution, it could result in cross-site scripting (XSS), where attackers might steal sensitive information, compromise user sessions, or gain unauthorized access to broader systems and data repositories.

Example Attack Scenarios
Scenario 1: An attacker injects falsified sales data into a visualization tool used by a retail company. This leads the company to make poor inventory decisions based on the manipulated high demand visualized for certain products.
Scenario 2: Through a compromised user account, an attacker injects a script into the data source for a popular visualization library used in an enterprise's reporting dashboard. The script executes as an XSS attack, stealing session tokens of the enterprise's finance team and gaining unauthorized access to sensitive financial reports.

reference.name: Data Tampering: A Comprehensive Guide

component.name: Database Migration Service

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

countermeasure.name: Configure AWS DMS to use secure endpoints for encrypted data transfer
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data during AWS DMS migrations, configure secure endpoints to ensure encrypted communication between replication instances and databases:

Enable SSL/TLS for Endpoints:

  • When setting up source and target endpoints in AWS DMS, enable SSL/TLS encryption. This ensures that data transferred between databases and replication instances is encrypted in transit.

Use Verified Certificates:

  • Ensure SSL/TLS certificates used for encryption are signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA) and are up-to-date. This prevents man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks and ensures the authenticity of the endpoints.

Enforce Encryption Policies:

  • Apply AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to enforce encryption requirements for all DMS tasks. This restricts the creation of non-secure endpoints.

Monitor Endpoint Security:

  • Regularly audit endpoint configurations using AWS Config or AWS Security Hub to ensure compliance with encryption best practices and detect any deviations from secure settings.

reference.name: Security in AWS Database Migration Service

countermeasure.name: Enable detailed logging and monitoring for DMS tasks
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS DMS operations, enable detailed logging and monitoring:

Enable CloudWatch Logs:

  • Configure CloudWatch Logs for DMS tasks to capture execution metrics and errors.
  • Set CloudWatch Alarms for abnormal task behavior, such as failures or unusual data changes.

Use CloudTrail for Auditing:

  • Ensure CloudTrail is enabled to log all API calls related to AWS DMS for auditing and analysis.
  • Store CloudTrail logs in a secure S3 bucket for review and compliance.

Set Up Real-Time Alerts:

  • Use CloudWatch Events to trigger alerts or automated responses to suspicious activities.
  • Integrate with AWS Security Hub or GuardDuty to enhance detection of potential threats.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS DMS built-in data validation for migration accuracy
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure data consistency and prevent corruption during AWS DMS migrations, enable the service's built-in data validation feature:

Enable Data Validation:

  • In the AWS DMS console, activate the data validation option when configuring a migration task. This feature checks that the data in the source and target databases matches after migration, ensuring consistency.

Configure Validation Rules:

  • Set up validation rules to verify row counts, checksums, and data types for tables being migrated. Adjust the rules based on the criticality and sensitivity of the data to catch discrepancies early.

Monitor Validation Results:

  • Regularly monitor validation reports and logs to identify and resolve any mismatches or data integrity issues promptly.
  • Set up CloudWatch Alarms to receive notifications if validation failures occur, allowing quick corrective actions.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure communication endpoints
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Insecure communication endpoints in AWS DMS refer to vulnerabilities where data transmitted between source and target databases, or between AWS DMS instances, is not adequately encrypted. This can lead to interception, unauthorized access, or alteration of data, especially during migrations involving sensitive information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, state actors.
  • Vectors: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing on unencrypted networks, exploiting weak or misconfigured encryption settings, DNS spoofing.

Impacts:

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized data access.
  • Integrity: Data tampering or corruption.
  • Availability: Disruption of migration processes.
  • Compliance: Breaches of GDPR, HIPAA, CCPA, leading to fines and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Unencrypted Data Transfer: During migration, data is transmitted without SSL, allowing attackers to intercept and extract sensitive information.
  • Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts communication between AWS DMS and databases, accessing and potentially modifying data.
  • Weak Encryption Exploit: An attacker forces a downgrade to a vulnerable encryption standard, decrypting sensitive traffic during migration.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Lack of task monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Lack of Task Monitoring" in AWS DMS refers to the inadequate or absent monitoring of migration tasks, which can lead to undetected errors, unauthorized modifications, or malicious activities during data migration. Without proper oversight, tasks may fail, become corrupted, or be manipulated without triggering alerts or corrective actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, cybercriminals, negligent administrators.
  • Vectors: Unmonitored or poorly configured DMS tasks, unauthorized changes to migration settings, exploitation of gaps in task management, or use of compromised credentials.

Impacts:

  • Data Loss/Corruption: Unnoticed task failures or unauthorized changes can result in incomplete or corrupted data migrations.
  • Operational Disruption: Prolonged or unnoticed migration issues can delay critical operations.
  • Security Risks: Unmonitored tasks may allow unnoticed data theft or manipulation by malicious actors.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Unnoticed Task Failure: A data migration task fails midway due to a network issue, but without proper monitoring, the failure goes unnoticed, resulting in incomplete data transfer.
  • Unauthorized Modifications: A malicious insider alters the migration task settings to divert sensitive data to an unauthorized location, and due to lack of monitoring, the change remains undetected.
  • Data Corruption Overlooked: During a large-scale migration, data gets corrupted due to configuration errors, but without real-time monitoring or alerts, the issue is only discovered after the migration is complete, requiring a costly rollback and redo.

threat.name: Data integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Data Integrity Compromise" in AWS DMS refers to the risk of data being altered, corrupted, or manipulated during migration processes. This can occur due to software bugs, configuration errors, or malicious attacks, leading to the loss of data accuracy and reliability, which is crucial for decision-making and operational processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, accidental errors by administrators.
  • Vectors: Exploiting vulnerabilities in AWS DMS configurations, injecting malicious data during migration, tampering with data in transit, or manipulating data storage settings.

Impacts:

  • Data Accuracy: Inaccurate or incomplete data can lead to faulty analytics and decision-making.
  • Operational Disruption: Corrupted data can disrupt applications and processes dependent on accurate data.
  • Financial Loss: Incorrect data can lead to financial errors, regulatory fines, and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Malicious Data Injection: An attacker gains access to the DMS instance and injects false records into the database during migration, causing significant discrepancies in financial reporting.
  • Configuration Error: An administrator accidentally configures the migration task to exclude critical data fields, resulting in a partial and inaccurate data set being transferred.
  • Data Tampering in Transit: During migration, data packets are intercepted and modified by a man-in-the-middle attack, corrupting the database at the target endpoint without immediate detection.

A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Assign specific IAM roles to AWS Glue jobs at the time of creation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and manage permissions efficiently within your AWS Glue environment, assign specific IAM roles to AWS Glue jobs at the time of creation. This practice ensures that each job runs with only the necessary permissions required for its operation, adhering to the principle of least privilege. This minimizes the risk of unauthorized actions and potential security breaches.

Implementation Guidance:

Create an IAM Role for AWS Glue Jobs:

  • Navigate to the IAM console in the AWS Management Console.
  • Choose "Roles" and then "Create role".
  • Select "Glue" as the service that will use the role.
  • Attach the necessary policies that define the permissions for the Glue job. Ensure the policies grant only the permissions required for the job's specific tasks.

Define Permissions Policies:

  • Use managed policies provided by AWS or create custom policies to fine-tune the permissions.

Assign the IAM Role to a Glue Job:

  • When creating a new Glue job in the AWS Glue console, specify the IAM role under the "IAM role" field.
  • For existing jobs, you can update the role by navigating to the job's configuration and editing the "IAM role" field.

Use the AWS CLI or AWS SDKs:

  • You can also assign roles programmatically when creating or updating jobs using the AWS CLI or SDKs.
  • Example using AWS CLI:

aws glue create-job --name MyGlueJob --role arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/GlueJobRole --command 'Name=glueetl,ScriptLocation=s3://my-script-location'

Regularly Review and Rotate IAM Roles:

  • Periodically review the permissions associated with IAM roles to ensure they are still appropriate.
  • Rotate roles and credentials as part of a security best practice to mitigate the risk of compromised credentials.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Glue Documentation on IAM Roles and the IAM Best Practices.

Security best practices in IAM

countermeasure.name: Implement encryption for the AWS Glue Data Catalog to protect metadata at rest
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Glue Data Catalog encryption provides enhanced security for your sensitive data. AWS Glue integrates with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) to encrypt metadata that's stored in the Data Catalog. You can enable or disable encryption settings for resources in the Data Catalog using the AWS Glue console or the AWS CLI.

When you enable encryption for your Data Catalog, all new objects that you create will be encrypted. When you disable encryption, the new objects you create will not be encrypted, but existing encrypted objects will remain encrypted.

You can encrypt your entire Data Catalog using AWS managed encryption keys or customer managed encryption keys. For more information on key types and states, see AWS Key Management Service concepts in the AWS Key Management Service Developer Guide.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Insufficient access control measures for AWS Glue jobs can lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of data processing activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Insufficient access control measures for AWS Glue jobs can lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of data processing activities. When permissions are not properly restricted, malicious actors or uninformed users could exploit these permissions to perform unauthorized actions within Glue jobs. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external actors with some level of access to the AWS environment may exploit weak or misconfigured IAM roles and policies associated with Glue jobs. This exploitation could be executed through compromised user accounts, overly permissive roles, or inadvertent user error. 
Impacts
The primary impacts include unauthorized data access, data corruption, service disruption, and potential data loss. Confidential or sensitive data could be compromised, leading to reputational damage and regulatory compliance penalties. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An internal user with insufficiently restricted permissions modifies a Glue job to exfiltrate sensitive data to an external location. 
2. A compromised account with access to Glue jobs alters data processing logic, resulting in corrupted or incorrect data outputs. 
3. Overly permissive permissions granted to a third-party contractor allow them to access and manipulate Glue jobs, leading to unintended data exposure.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to metadata in AWS Glue can allow malicious actors to obtain sensitive information
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to metadata in AWS Glue can allow malicious actors to obtain sensitive information about your data catalog, ETL jobs, and other resources. This meta-information can be used to orchestrate further attacks or exfiltrate sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers who have gained access through compromised credentials, or internal users with unnecessary permissions. Attack vectors can include exploiting misconfigurations in IAM policies, improper permission settings, or vulnerabilities in the AWS Glue service itself.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to metadata include the potential exposure of sensitive data structures, revealing business-critical information, loss of intellectual property, and the possibility of launching subsequent attacks using the gleaned metadata. It can also lead to a loss of customer trust and regulatory non-compliance.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker obtains credentials from a low-privileged user but finds that IAM policies are misconfigured, allowing access to AWS Glue metadata. The attacker then retrieves details about ETL jobs and uses this information to identify data storage locations to exfiltrate data. 
2. An internal employee with broader-than-necessary permissions accesses metadata about critical ETL jobs and alters the job configurations to reroute sensitive data to an external location under their control. 
3. Exploiting a vulnerability in AWS Glue, an attacker circumvents authentication mechanisms to access metadata directly, gaining insights into the organizations data structures and using this information to identify soft targets for further attacks.

countermeasure.name: Enable modern data access protocols for improved security and performance
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to implement modern data access protocolssuch as SSL/TLS-enabled WebHDFSto enhance both security and performance in your Datalake environment:

Configure Modern Data Access Protocols:

  • Enable protocols like SSL/TLS-enabled WebHDFS to ensure that all data transfers between clients and the Datalake are encrypted and secure.
  • Verify that your Datalake services are configured to use the latest encryption standards (e.g., TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3) and that non-secure protocols are disabled.

Test and Validate:

  • Use network and performance testing tools to confirm that data access is both secure and optimized for performance.
  • Conduct regular penetration tests and vulnerability assessments to ensure that the modern data access protocols are functioning as intended.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor access logs and encryption configurations to detect any deviations from the established protocols.
  • Periodically review and update the protocol configurations to comply with evolving security standards and performance benchmarks.

References

  • TLS Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Enforce the latest TLS for secure data transfers
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to secure data transfers to and from your Datalake by utilizing the latest TLS protocol version:

Configure TLS Settings:

  • Update your Datalake network and service configurations to enforce the use of the most recent TLS version (e.g., TLS 1.3) for all data transfers.
  • Disable legacy and less secure versions of TLS to ensure that communications are encrypted using robust, modern protocols.

Test and Validate:

  • Employ network analysis tools to verify that data transfers are encrypted with the correct TLS version.
  • Conduct regular penetration tests and vulnerability scans to confirm that the security settings are correctly applied and effective.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor logs and network traffic to detect any deviations from the enforced TLS configuration.
  • Periodically review your TLS settings against updated CIS benchmarks and industry standards, making necessary adjustments to maintain secure data transfers.

References

  • TLS Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Ensure Hadoop, Spark, and other frameworks are updated to the latest stable versions
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to maintain the security and performance of your Datalake by ensuring that Hadoop, Spark, and other associated frameworks are kept up-to-date:

Plan and Execute Updates:

  • Establish a maintenance schedule to routinely check for and deploy the latest stable releases of Hadoop, Spark, and other frameworks.
  • Prioritize security patches and version updates that address vulnerabilities as indicated by vendor advisories and CIS benchmarks.
  • Test updates in a staging environment before applying them to production to ensure compatibility and stability.

Test and Validate:

  • Perform comprehensive testing after updates to verify that all components function as expected and that security enhancements are active.
  • Utilize automated vulnerability scanning tools to confirm that known security flaws have been addressed post-update.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor system logs and update notifications to detect any lag in applying patches or potential issues with newly deployed versions.
  • Periodically audit the update process and review compliance with CIS Datalake Security Benchmarks to maintain ongoing system security.

References

  • Hadoop Security Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Force all HTTP traffic to HTTPS to ensure data encryption in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to enforce secure data transmission in your Datalake by redirecting all HTTP traffic to HTTPS:

Review Documentation:
Consult the CIS Datalake Security Benchmarks for detailed guidance on secure protocol configurations and best practices for enforcing HTTPS in your network.

Configure HTTPS Redirection:

  • Update server and network configurations to automatically redirect all HTTP requests to HTTPS.
  • Verify that SSL/TLS certificates are installed correctly and that only secure protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3) are enabled.
  • Configure any load balancers or reverse proxies to enforce HTTPS across all endpoints.

Test and Validate:

  • Use network monitoring tools to confirm that all HTTP traffic is redirected and encrypted via HTTPS.
  • Conduct periodic penetration tests and vulnerability scans to ensure that unsecured HTTP access points are eliminated.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor network logs and traffic to detect any instances of non-HTTPS connections.
  • Periodically review HTTPS configurations and certificate statuses, updating protocols as necessary to comply with evolving security standards.

References

  • TLS Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Integrate the Datalake with a robust IAM solution
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to integrate your Datalake with a robust Identity and Access Management (IAM) solutionsuch as Microsoft Entra ID or AWS IAMto enforce secure user authentication and strengthen overall access control:

Configure IAM Integration:

  • Integrate a robust IAM solution with your Datalake to centralize user authentication and enforce granular access controls.
  • Map user roles and permissions according to the principle of least privilege, and enable features such as Single Sign-On (SSO) and multi-factor authentication (MFA) to enhance security.
  • Ensure that IAM policies are properly configured to control access to sensitive data and administrative functions within the Datalake environment.

Test and Validate:

  • Conduct thorough testing to verify that the IAM integration enforces secure authentication and that only authorized users can access Datalake resources.
  • Use automated tools and manual audits to confirm that the IAM policies are effective and correctly restrict access.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor authentication logs and IAM audit trails to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts.
  • Periodically review IAM configurations and update policies in alignment with evolving security standards and organizational requirements.

References

countermeasure.name: Prohibit non-secure protocols and enforce encryption in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to secure all ingestion channels in your Datalake by prohibiting the use of non-secure protocols (e.g., FTP) and enforcing encryption in transit:

Disable Non-Secure Protocols:

  • Identify and disable any non-secure data transfer protocols, such as FTP, from all Datalake ingestion endpoints.
  • Update network configurations to ensure that only secure protocols (such as SFTP, FTPS, HTTPS) are enabled for data transfers.

Enforce Encryption in Transit:

  • Configure all ingestion channels to use encryption protocols, ensuring that data in transit is protected from interception.
  • Verify that encryption settings are applied consistently across all network devices, load balancers, and data gateways involved in the ingestion process.

Test and Validate:

  • Use network monitoring and security tools to confirm that non-secure protocols are disabled and that all data transfers are encrypted.
  • Conduct periodic penetration tests and vulnerability scans to ensure that secure protocols are enforced effectively, and adjust configurations as needed.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor ingestion channel logs and network traffic to detect any use of non-secure protocols.
  • Periodically review and update the secure protocol configurations in line with evolving security standards and industry best practices.

References

  • TLS Best Practices

Configure IAM Integration:

Test and Validate:

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate authentication controls
threat.desc:
General threat description

Weak or misconfigured authentication in IBM Cloud Continuous Deliverysuch as using simple passwords, lacking multi-factor authentication (MFA), or misconfiguring identity integrationscan allow unauthorized users to gain access to build pipelines and sensitive configuration settings, putting the entire continuous delivery process at risk.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers: Using brute-force or credential stuffing to breach weak login defenses.
  • Malicious insiders: Exploiting over-privileged accounts or misconfigured access.
  • Compromised tokens: Reusing or hijacking stolen authentication tokens.
  • Misconfigured SSO/OAuth integrations: Failing to enforce robust identity verification.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to and manipulation of build and deployment pipelines.
  • Injection of malicious code or alteration of build artifacts.
  • Lateral movement into connected systems and broader network compromise.
  • Compliance and regulatory risks due to inadequate protection of sensitive processes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Brute-force attack: An attacker uses automated tools to guess weak passwords, gaining access to critical pipeline configurations.
  2. Phishing compromise: A user is deceived into revealing credentials, and without MFA, the attacker leverages the stolen credentials to alter deployment processes.
  3. Token replay: Stolen tokens are reused due to weak session controls, allowing an attacker continuous unauthorized access.
  4. SSO misconfiguration: Faulty integration with an identity provider results in overly broad access, enabling an attacker with a compromised token to infiltrate the continuous delivery environment.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inefficient data access protocols
threat.desc:
General threat description

Inefficient data access protocols refer to the use of outdated or suboptimal methods for transferring and querying data within the continuous delivery environment. These protocols can lead to degraded performance, increased resource usage, and potential security weaknesses, as they may lack proper optimizations or robust security controls.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers: Exploiting vulnerabilities in unoptimized protocols to intercept or manipulate data.
  • Malicious insiders: Taking advantage of inefficient protocols to access or exfiltrate sensitive information.
  • Automated tools: Scanning for and leveraging known weaknesses in outdated data access methods.
  • Misconfigured connectors/integrations: Allowing inefficient protocols to be used, thereby weakening overall security.

Impacts

  • Slowed build and deployment processes due to increased data latency and resource consumption.
  • Increased vulnerability to data interception, injection, or tampering attacks.
  • Degradation of system performance, potentially causing service disruptions.
  • Higher operational costs and increased risk of compliance issues due to insecure data practices.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Data Interception: An attacker exploits an unencrypted, inefficient protocol used for data transfers between CI/CD components to intercept sensitive build artifacts.
  2. Injection Attack: A misconfigured connector that uses an outdated data access protocol allows an attacker to inject malicious data, compromising the integrity of build processes.
  3. Performance Degradation Exploit: Automated tools trigger excessive data requests over an inefficient protocol, causing a slowdown that disrupts the continuous delivery pipeline.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description

Unencrypted data transmission occurs when sensitive informationsuch as API keys, build artifacts, and credentialsis sent between components of IBM Cloud Continuous Delivery without proper encryption. This exposes data to interception and tampering during transit.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Network-based attackers: Capturing unencrypted traffic through packet sniffing.
  • Man-in-the-middle (MitM) attackers: Intercepting and modifying data exchanged between systems.
  • Misconfigured endpoints: Systems that default to non-secure protocols, exposing sensitive content.
  • Compromised network devices: Downgrading connections to unencrypted communication channels.

Impacts

  • Exposure of confidential data and sensitive credentials.
  • Potential data manipulation, compromising the integrity of build artifacts.
  • Increased risk of unauthorized access and lateral movement.
  • Regulatory and compliance breaches due to inadequate data protection in transit.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Intercepted API Calls: An attacker on a public network captures unencrypted API calls between the CI/CD system and external services, harvesting sensitive tokens.
  2. MitM Exploit: A compromised network device forces a downgrade in encryption protocols, allowing a MitM attacker to alter data being transmitted between IBM Cloud Continuous Delivery components.
  3. Connector Misconfiguration: An integration connector uses an unencrypted channel by default, leading to the exposure of build configuration data and proprietary information.

threat.name: Insecure management of secrets
threat.desc:
General threat description

Insecure management of secrets occurs when sensitive credentialssuch as API keys, tokens, or passwordsare stored or transmitted without adequate protection. In IBM Cloud Continuous Delivery, this weakness may arise from plaintext storage, hardcoded secrets in deployment scripts, or misconfigured vault integrations, leaving the system vulnerable to unauthorized access and compromise.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers: Scanning for misconfigurations and exploiting weak storage methods.
  • Malicious insiders: Accessing and misusing secrets due to lax access controls.
  • Compromised automation tools: Extracting secrets from logs or configuration files.
  • Misconfigured integrations: Failing to properly isolate or encrypt secrets during transmission.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to build and deployment pipelines.
  • Manipulation or exfiltration of sensitive data from integrated systems.
  • Lateral movement within the environment via compromised credentials.
  • Potential data breaches and non-compliance with security regulations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Plaintext Storage Exposure: An attacker gains access to configuration files where API keys are stored in plaintext, enabling them to connect to production services.
  2. Hardcoded Secrets in Pipelines: Deployment scripts contain hardcoded credentials which are leaked via version control, leading to unauthorized pipeline executions.
  3. Log File Leakage: An automation tool logs sensitive tokens, and an attacker monitoring the logs retrieves the secrets to access restricted systems.
  4. Misconfigured Vault Integration: A secret management system is not properly integrated, causing secrets to be transmitted or stored unencrypted, which an attacker then intercepts.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Insecure identity integration
threat.desc:
General threat description

Insecure identity integration occurs when IBM Cloud Continuous Delivery's connections to external identity providers (e.g., SSO, OAuth, LDAP) are misconfigured or weak. This may result in improper validation of user identities, allowing unauthorized access to build pipelines and sensitive deployment configurations.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers: Exploiting misconfigurations in SSO or token validations.
  • Malicious insiders: Leveraging overly permissive identity mappings.
  • Compromised accounts: Using stolen tokens due to inadequate identity integration controls.
  • Configuration errors: Incorrectly set integration parameters allowing unauthorized privileges.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to critical delivery pipelines and sensitive data.
  • Alteration or injection of malicious code into build processes.
  • Lateral movement across systems connected via integrated identity providers.
  • Increased risk of data breaches and compliance violations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. SSO Misconfiguration: An attacker exploits a misconfigured SSO integration that fails to enforce strict token validation, granting unauthorized access to deployment settings.
  2. Token Hijacking: Stolen or replayed authentication tokens bypass inadequate identity checks, allowing an attacker to modify build pipelines.
  3. Over-Permissioned Claims: Incorrect identity federation settings result in overly broad user claims, enabling unauthorized privileges and access to restricted CI/CD environments.
  4. Insider Exploitation: A malicious insider leverages lax identity integration to elevate their access rights and disrupt or manipulate automated delivery processes.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General threat description

Outdated runtime environments occur when the systems and containers used in the continuous delivery process are not regularly updated or patched. This leaves known vulnerabilities in the underlying operating system, libraries, and frameworks that attackers can exploit to compromise the delivery pipeline.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers: Exploiting publicly known vulnerabilities using automated tools.
  • Malicious insiders: Leveraging outdated components to inject malicious code into runtime environments.
  • Automated scanners: Identifying unpatched runtime images to target for further exploitation.
  • Misconfigured deployment scripts: Causing legacy components to be deployed in production.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to build and runtime environments.
  • Execution of arbitrary code through known vulnerabilities, leading to compromised builds.
  • Disruption of the continuous delivery process and service outages.
  • Increased risk of data breaches and compliance violations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Container Exploitation: An attacker discovers that a container image used in the runtime environment is unpatched, exploits a known vulnerability to gain remote access, and injects malicious code into the build pipeline.
  2. Privilege Escalation: Outdated OS libraries in the runtime environment allow a malicious insider to escalate privileges, undermining security controls and accessing sensitive deployment configurations.
  3. Automated Vulnerability Scanning: An external attacker uses automated tools to identify legacy runtime components in the CI/CD environment, then targets these components to disrupt service and exfiltrate data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Insecure data ingestion practices
threat.desc:
General threat description

Insecure data ingestion practices occur when input datasuch as code commits, configuration files, or external data feedsare ingested into the continuous delivery pipeline without proper validation, sanitization, or encryption. This can allow attackers to inject malicious payloads or corrupted data, compromising the integrity and security of the build and deployment processes.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers: Submitting crafted data or payloads designed to inject malicious content.
  • Malicious insiders: Introducing compromised or manipulated data to disrupt workflows.
  • Automated tools: Exploiting weak validation in connectors or APIs to send harmful inputs.
  • Misconfigured data connectors: Allowing unverified or unsanitized data from external sources into the pipeline.

Impacts

  • Injection of malicious code or configuration errors into the delivery pipeline.
  • Compromise of build artifacts, leading to unauthorized code execution.
  • Undetected propagation of corrupted or malicious data through automated processes.
  • Increased risk of compliance and integrity issues across deployment environments.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Payload Injection: An attacker submits a malicious code snippet via an external data feed into the CI pipeline, which then gets incorporated into the build artifacts.
  2. Connector Exploitation: A misconfigured data connector allows unvalidated payloads from a third-party system, resulting in the execution of unintended commands in the delivery process.
  3. Malicious Data Entry: A disgruntled insider introduces corrupted configuration files through an insecure ingestion channel, causing production deployments to fail or behave unpredictably.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1505 - Server Software Component

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you defineregular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable Amazon S3 server access logging
countermeasure.desc:
Server access logging provides detailed records of the requests that are made to a bucket. Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits, help you learn about your customer base, and understand your Amazon S3 bill. For instructions on enabling server access logging, see Logging requests with server access logging.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-logging-enabled AWS Config managed rule.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesnt record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesnt support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If youve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you wont be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.
