weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Assign specific IAM roles to AWS Glue jobs at the time of creation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and manage permissions efficiently within your AWS Glue environment, assign specific IAM roles to AWS Glue jobs at the time of creation. This practice ensures that each job runs with only the necessary permissions required for its operation, adhering to the principle of least privilege. This minimizes the risk of unauthorized actions and potential security breaches.

Implementation Guidance:

Create an IAM Role for AWS Glue Jobs:

  • Navigate to the IAM console in the AWS Management Console.
  • Choose "Roles" and then "Create role".
  • Select "Glue" as the service that will use the role.
  • Attach the necessary policies that define the permissions for the Glue job. Ensure the policies grant only the permissions required for the job's specific tasks.

Define Permissions Policies:

  • Use managed policies provided by AWS or create custom policies to fine-tune the permissions.

Assign the IAM Role to a Glue Job:

  • When creating a new Glue job in the AWS Glue console, specify the IAM role under the "IAM role" field.
  • For existing jobs, you can update the role by navigating to the job's configuration and editing the "IAM role" field.

Use the AWS CLI or AWS SDKs:

  • You can also assign roles programmatically when creating or updating jobs using the AWS CLI or SDKs.
  • Example using AWS CLI:

aws glue create-job --name MyGlueJob --role arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/GlueJobRole --command 'Name=glueetl,ScriptLocation=s3://my-script-location'

Regularly Review and Rotate IAM Roles:

  • Periodically review the permissions associated with IAM roles to ensure they are still appropriate.
  • Rotate roles and credentials as part of a security best practice to mitigate the risk of compromised credentials.

For more detailed guidance, refer to the AWS Glue Documentation on IAM Roles and the IAM Best Practices.

countermeasure.name: Implement encryption for the AWS Glue Data Catalog to protect metadata at rest
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Glue Data Catalog encryption provides enhanced security for your sensitive data. AWS Glue integrates with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) to encrypt metadata that's stored in the Data Catalog. You can enable or disable encryption settings for resources in the Data Catalog using the AWS Glue console or the AWS CLI.

When you enable encryption for your Data Catalog, all new objects that you create will be encrypted. When you disable encryption, the new objects you create will not be encrypted, but existing encrypted objects will remain encrypted.

You can encrypt your entire Data Catalog using AWS managed encryption keys or customer managed encryption keys. For more information on key types and states, see AWS Key Management Service concepts in the AWS Key Management Service Developer Guide.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Insufficient access control measures for AWS Glue jobs can lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of data processing activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Insufficient access control measures for AWS Glue jobs can lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of data processing activities. When permissions are not properly restricted, malicious actors or uninformed users could exploit these permissions to perform unauthorized actions within Glue jobs. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external actors with some level of access to the AWS environment may exploit weak or misconfigured IAM roles and policies associated with Glue jobs. This exploitation could be executed through compromised user accounts, overly permissive roles, or inadvertent user error. 
Impacts
The primary impacts include unauthorized data access, data corruption, service disruption, and potential data loss. Confidential or sensitive data could be compromised, leading to reputational damage and regulatory compliance penalties. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An internal user with insufficiently restricted permissions modifies a Glue job to exfiltrate sensitive data to an external location. 
2. A compromised account with access to Glue jobs alters data processing logic, resulting in corrupted or incorrect data outputs. 
3. Overly permissive permissions granted to a third-party contractor allow them to access and manipulate Glue jobs, leading to unintended data exposure.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to metadata in AWS Glue can allow malicious actors to obtain sensitive information
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to metadata in AWS Glue can allow malicious actors to obtain sensitive information about your data catalog, ETL jobs, and other resources. This meta-information can be used to orchestrate further attacks or exfiltrate sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers who have gained access through compromised credentials, or internal users with unnecessary permissions. Attack vectors can include exploiting misconfigurations in IAM policies, improper permission settings, or vulnerabilities in the AWS Glue service itself.
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized access to metadata include the potential exposure of sensitive data structures, revealing business-critical information, loss of intellectual property, and the possibility of launching subsequent attacks using the gleaned metadata. It can also lead to a loss of customer trust and regulatory non-compliance.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker obtains credentials from a low-privileged user but finds that IAM policies are misconfigured, allowing access to AWS Glue metadata. The attacker then retrieves details about ETL jobs and uses this information to identify data storage locations to exfiltrate data. 
2. An internal employee with broader-than-necessary permissions accesses metadata about critical ETL jobs and alters the job configurations to reroute sensitive data to an external location under their control. 
3. Exploiting a vulnerability in AWS Glue, an attacker circumvents authentication mechanisms to access metadata directly, gaining insights into the organizations data structures and using this information to identify soft targets for further attacks.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-307
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-307: Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts The product does not implement sufficient measures to prevent multiple failed authentication attempts within a short time frame, making it more susceptible to brute force attacks.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-668
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Apply least-privilege permissions
countermeasure.desc: When you set permissions with IAM policies, grant only the permissions required to perform a task. You do this by defining the actions that can be taken on specific resources under specific conditions, also known as least-privilege permissions. You might start with broad permissions while you explore the permissions that are required for your workload or use case. As your use case matures, you can work to reduce the permissions that you grant to work toward least privilege. For more information about using IAM to apply permissions, see Policies and permissions in IAM.

countermeasure.name: Don't create access keys for the root user
countermeasure.desc:
Access keys let you run commands in the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI) or use API operations from one of the AWS SDKs. We strongly recommend that you do not create access key pairs for your root user because the root user has full access to all AWS services and resources in the account, including billing information.

Since only a few tasks require the root user and you typically perform those tasks infrequently, we recommend signing in to the AWS Management Console to perform root user tasks. Before creating access keys, review the alternatives to long-term access keys.

countermeasure.name: Establish permissions guardrails across multiple accounts
countermeasure.desc: As you scale your workloads, separate them by using multiple accounts that are managed with AWS Organizations. We recommend that you use Organizations service control policies (SCPs) to establish permissions guardrails to control access for all IAM users and roles across your accounts. SCPs are a type of organization policy that you can use to manage permissions in your organization at the AWS organization, OU, or account level. The permissions guardrails that you establish apply to all users and roles within the covered accounts. However, SCPs alone are insufficient to grant permissions to the accounts in your organization. To do this, your administrator must attach identity-based or resource-based policies to IAM users, IAM roles, or the resources in your accounts. For more information, see AWS Organizations, accounts, and IAM guardrails.

countermeasure.name: Get started with AWS managed policies and move toward least-privilege permissions
countermeasure.desc: To get started granting permissions to your users and workloads, use the AWS managed policies that grant permissions for many common use cases. They are available in your AWS account. Keep in mind that AWS managed policies might not grant least-privilege permissions for your specific use cases because they are available for use by all AWS customers. As a result, we recommend that you reduce permissions further by defining customer managed policies that are specific to your use cases. For more information, see AWS managed policies. For more information about AWS managed policies that are designed for specific job functions, see AWS managed policies for job functions.

countermeasure.name: Monitor access and usage
countermeasure.desc:
It's recommended to use your current tracking mechanisms to monitor, alert, and report the sign in and use of root user credentials, including alerts that announce root user sign-in and usage. The following services can help to ensure that root user credential usage is tracked and perform security checks that can help prevent unauthorized use.

If you want to be notified about root user sign-in activity in your account, you can leverage Amazon CloudWatch to create an Events rule that detects when root user credentials are used and triggers a notification to your security administrator. For details, see Monitor and notify on AWS account root user activity.

If you want to set up notifications to alert you of approved root user actions, you can leverage Amazon EventBridge along with Amazon SNS to write an EventBridge rule to track root user usage for the specific action and notify you using an Amazon SNS topic. For an example, see Send a notification when an Amazon S3 object is created.

If you already using GuardDuty as your threat detection service, you can extend its capability to notify you when root user credentials are being used in your account.

Alerts should include, but not be limited to, the email address for the root user. Have procedures in place for how to respond to alerts so that personnel who receive a root user access alert understand how to validate that root user access is expected, and how to escalate if they believe that a security incident is in progress. For an example of how to configure alerts, see Monitor and notify on AWS account root user activity.

countermeasure.name: Regularly review and remove unused users, roles, permissions, policies, and credentials
countermeasure.desc: You might have IAM users, roles, permissions, policies, or credentials that you no longer need in your AWS account. IAM provides last accessed information to help you identify the users, roles, permissions, policies, and credentials that you no longer need so that you can remove them. This helps you reduce the number of users, roles, permissions, policies, and credentials that you have to monitor. You can also use this information to refine your IAM policies to better adhere to least-privilege permissions. For more information, see Refining permissions in AWS using last accessed information.

countermeasure.name: Require human users to use federation with an identity provider to access AWS using temporary credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Human users, also known as human identities, are the people, administrators, developers, operators, and consumers of your applications. They must have an identity to access your AWS environments and applications. Human users that are members of your organization are also known as workforce identities. Human users can also be external users with whom you collaborate, and who interact with your AWS resources. They can do this via a web browser, client application, mobile app, or interactive command-line tools.

Require your human users to use temporary credentials when accessing AWS. You can use an identity provider for your human users to provide federated access to AWS accounts by assuming roles, which provide temporary credentials. For centralized access management, we recommend that you use AWS IAM Identity Center (IAM Identity Center) to manage access to your accounts and permissions within those accounts. You can manage your user identities with IAM Identity Center, or manage access permissions for user identities in IAM Identity Center from an external identity provider. For more information, see What is AWS IAM Identity Center in the AWS IAM Identity Center User Guide.

For more information about roles, see Roles terms and concepts.

countermeasure.name: Require multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend using IAM roles for human users and workloads that access your AWS resources so that they use temporary credentials. However, for scenarios in which you need an IAM user or root user in your account, require MFA for additional security. With MFA, users have a device that generates a response to an authentication challenge. Each user's credentials and device-generated response are required to complete the sign-in process. For more information, see Using multi-factor authentication (MFA) in AWS.

If you use IAM Identity Center for centralized access management for human users, you can use the IAM Identity Center MFA capabilities when your identity source is configured with the IAM Identity Center identity store, AWS Managed Microsoft AD, or AD Connector. For more information about MFA in IAM Identity Center see Multi-factor authentication in the AWS IAM Identity Center User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Require workloads to use temporary credentials with IAM roles to access AWS
countermeasure.desc:
A workload is a collection of resources and code that delivers business value, such as an application or backend process. Your workload can have applications, operational tools, and components that require an identity to make requests to AWS services, such as requests to read data. These identities include machines running in your AWS environments, such as Amazon EC2 instances or AWS Lambda functions.

You can also manage machine identities for external parties who need access. To give access to machine identities, you can use IAM roles. IAM roles have specific permissions and provide a way to access AWS by relying on temporary security credentials with a role session. Additionally, you might have machines outside of AWS that need access to your AWS environments. For machines that run outside of AWS you can use AWS Identity and Access Management Roles Anywhere. For more information about roles, see IAM roles. For details about how to use roles to delegate access across AWS accounts, see IAM tutorial: Delegate access across AWS accounts using IAM roles.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to account recovery mechanisms
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure you develop a process to manage root user credential recovery mechanisms in case you need access to it during emergency such as takeover of your administrative account.

  • Ensure you have access to your root user email inbox so that you can reset a lost or forgotten root user password.
  • If MFA for your AWS account root user is lost, damaged, or not working, you can sign in using another MFA registered to the same root user credentials. If you lost access to all your MFAs, you need both the phone number and the email used to register your account, to be up to date and accessible to recover your MFA. For details, see Recovering a root user MFA device.
  • If you choose not to store your root user password and MFA, then the phone number registered in your account can be used as an alternate way to recover root user credentials. Ensure you have access to the contact phone number, keep the phone number updated, and limit who has access to manage the phone number.

No one person should have access to both the email inbox and phone number since both are verification channels to recover your root user password. It is important to have two groups of individuals managing these channels. One group having access to your primary email address and another group having access to the primary phone number to recover access to your account as root user.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Secure your Organizations account root user credentials
countermeasure.desc:
As you move to a multi-account strategy with Organizations, each of your AWS accounts has its own root user credentials that you need to secure. The account you use to create your organization is the management account and the rest of the accounts in your organization are member accounts.

Secure root user credentials for member accounts

If you use Organizations to manage multiple accounts, there are two strategies that you can take to secure root user access in your Organizations.

Secure root user credentials of your Organizations accounts with MFA.

Do not reset the root user password for your accounts, and only recover access to it when needed using the password reset process. When you create a member account in your organization, Organizations automatically creates an IAM role in the member account that allows the management account temporary access to the member account.

For details, see Accessing member accounts in your organization in the Organizations User Guide.

Set preventative security controls in Organizations using a service control policy (SCP)

If you use Organizations to manage multiple accounts, you can apply an SCP to restrict access to member account root user. Denying all root user actions in your member accounts, except for certain root-only actions, helps prevent unauthorized access. For details, see Use an SCP to restrict what the root user in your member accounts can do.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Secure your root user credentials to prevent unauthorized use
countermeasure.desc:
Secure your root user credentials and use them for only the tasks that require them. To help prevent unauthorized use, dont share your root user password, MFA, access keys, CloudFront key pairs, or signing certificates with anyone, except those that have a strict business need to access the root user.

Don't store the root user password with tools that depend on AWS services in an account that is accessed using that same password. If you lose or forget your root user password, you will not be able to access these tools. We recommend that you prioritize resiliency and consider requiring two or more people to authorize access to the storage location. Access to the password or its storage location should be logged and monitored.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Secure your root user sign-in with multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Because a root user can perform privileged actions, it's crucial to add MFA for the root user as a second authentication factor in addition to the email address and password as sign-in credentials. We strongly recommend enabling multiple MFA for your root user credentials to provide additional flexibility and resiliency in your security strategy. You can register up to eight MFA devices of any combination of the currently supported MFA types with your AWS account root user.

  • FIDO Certified hardware security keys are provided by third-party providers. For more information, see Enable a FIDO security key for the AWS account root user.
  • A hardware device that generates a six-digit numeric code based on the time-based one-time password (TOTP) algorithm. For more information, see Enable a hardware TOTP token for the AWS account root user.
  • A virtual authenticator application that runs on a phone or other device and emulates a physical device. For more information, see Enable a virtual MFA device for your AWS account root user.

countermeasure.name: Update access keys when needed for use cases that require long-term credentials
countermeasure.desc:
Where possible, we recommend relying on temporary credentials instead of creating long-term credentials such as access keys. However, for scenarios in which you need IAM users with programmatic access and long-term credentials, we recommend that you update the access keys when needed, such as when an employee leaves your company. We recommend that you use IAM access last used information to update and remove access keys safely. For more information, see Updating access keys.

There are specific use cases that require long-term credentials with IAM users in AWS. Some of the use cases include the following:

  • Workloads that cannot use IAM roles You might run a workload from a location that needs to access AWS. In some situations, you can't use IAM roles to provide temporary credentials, such as for WordPress plugins. In these situations, use IAM user long-term access keys for that workload to authenticate to AWS.
  • Third-party AWS clients If you are using tools that dont support access with IAM Identity Center, such as third-party AWS clients or vendors that are not hosted on AWS, use IAM user long-term access keys.
  • AWS CodeCommit access If you are using CodeCommit to store your code, you can use an IAM user with either SSH keys or service-specific credentials for CodeCommit to authenticate to your repositories. We recommend that you do this in addition to using a user in IAM Identity Center for normal authentication. Users in IAM Identity Center are the people in your workforce who need access to your AWS accounts or to your cloud applications. To give users access to your CodeCommit repositories without configuring IAM users, you can configure the git-remote-codecommit utility. For more information about IAM and CodeCommit, see Using IAM with CodeCommit: Git credentials, SSH keys, and AWS access keys. For more information about configuring the git-remote-codecommit utility, see Connecting to AWS CodeCommit repositories with rotating credentials in the AWS CodeCommit User Guide.
  • Amazon Keyspaces (for Apache Cassandra) access In a situation where you are unable to use users in IAM Identity Center, such as for testing purposes for Cassandra compatibility, you can use an IAM user with service-specific credentials to authenticate with Amazon Keyspaces. Users in IAM Identity Center are the people in your workforce who need access to your AWS accounts or to your cloud applications. You can also connect to Amazon Keyspaces using temporary credentials. For more information, see Using temporary credentials to connect to Amazon Keyspaces using an IAM role and the SigV4 plugin in the Amazon Keyspaces (for Apache Cassandra) Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use a strong root user password to help protect access
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend that you use a password that is strong and unique. Tools such as password managers with strong password generation algorithms can help you achieve these goals. AWS requires that your password meet the following conditions:

  • It must have a minimum of 8 characters and a maximum of 128 characters.
  • It must include a minimum of three of the following mix of character types: uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and ! @ # $ % ^ & * () <> [] {} | _+-= symbols.
  • It must not be identical to your AWS account name or email address.

For more information, see Change the password for the AWS account root user.

countermeasure.name: Use conditions in IAM policies to further restrict access
countermeasure.desc: You can specify conditions under which a policy statement is in effect. That way, you can grant access to actions and resources, but only if the access request meets specific conditions. For example, you can write a policy condition to specify that all requests must be sent using SSL. You can also use conditions to grant access to service actions, but only if they are used through a specific AWS service, such as AWS CloudFormation. For more information, see IAM JSON policy elements: Condition.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM Access Analyzer to generate least-privilege policies based on access activity
countermeasure.desc: To grant only the permissions required to perform a task, you can generate policies based on your access activity that is logged in AWS CloudTrail. IAM Access Analyzer analyzes the services and actions that your IAM roles use, and then generates a fine-grained policy that you can use. After you test each generated policy, you can deploy the policy to your production environment. This ensures that you grant only the required permissions to your workloads. For more information about policy generation, see IAM Access Analyzer policy generation.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM Access Analyzer to validate your IAM policies to ensure secure and functional permissions
countermeasure.desc: Validate the policies you create to ensure that they adhere to the IAM policy language (JSON) and IAM best practices. You can validate your policies by using IAM Access Analyzer policy validation. IAM Access Analyzer provides more than 100 policy checks and actionable recommendations to help you author secure and functional policies. As you author new policies or edit existing policies in the console, IAM Access Analyzer provides recommendations to help you refine and validate your policies before you save them. Additionally, we recommend that you review and validate all of your existing policies. For more information, see IAM Access Analyzer policy validation. For more information about policy checks provided by IAM Access Analyzer, see IAM Access Analyzer policy check reference.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive permissions granted to users and roles can lead to unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Excessive permissions granted to users and roles can lead to unauthorized access and actions within the AWS environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal users with broad permissions, compromised user credentials, or roles with high levels of access. Attackers may exploit these to move laterally within the environment or escalate privileges.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, data modification, infrastructure changes, financial loss, and potential regulatory non-compliance.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal user with excessive privileges accidentally changes critical infrastructure settings, resulting in an outage. A compromised set of credentials is used to access sensitive data in S3 buckets which were granted broad read permissions, leading to a data breach.

threat.name: Unauthorized individuals exploiting recovery mechanisms can regain access to accounts
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized individuals exploiting recovery mechanisms can regain access to accounts even after credentials have been secured.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers who have previously compromised an account may exploit recovery processes such as password reset questions, email recovery, or multi-factor authentication reset bypasses to regain access.
Impacts
Repeated unauthorized access to accounts, leading to potential exfiltration of sensitive data, unauthorized changes to AWS resources, and long-term persistence within the environment.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker who previously had access to an account uses knowledge gained during the prior compromise to answer security questions accurately or bypass multi-factor authentication, allowing them to reset the password and regain access.

threat.name: Compromised account root user credentials can lead to unauthorized changes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Compromised root user credentials can lead to unauthorized changes to the overall account structure and permissions. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders or external attackers who gain access to an organization's root user credentials through phishing, social engineering, or exploiting vulnerabilities. 
Impacts
Unauthorized changes to account structures and permissions, potentially causing data breaches, financial losses, and reputational damage. 
Example Attack Scenarios
Attackers use phishing emails to trick an employee into divulging root user credentials. Once obtained, the attackers make unauthorized changes to IAM policies, create new administrative users, and revoke access for legitimate users, leading to widespread disruption and data compromise.

threat.name: Compromised root user credentials can lead to complete account takeover
threat.desc:
General threat description
Compromised root user credentials can lead to a complete account takeover and unauthorized access to all resources. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
This can occur if an attacker gains knowledge of the root user's password through phishing, brute force attacks, or social engineering. Additionally, poor security practices like not enabling multi-factor authentication (MFA) heighten the risk. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access to every service and resource in the AWS environment, leading to data breaches, financial loss, and operational downtime. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker sends a phishing email to the root user, tricking them into entering their credentials on a fake login page. Once the attacker gains those credentials, they log in to the AWS console and have unrestricted access to all resources, potentially deleting critical data and launching new instances at the victim's expense.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Use of long-term credentials increases the risk of unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Use of long-term credentials increases the risk of unauthorized access due to their persistence and potential exposure. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors who may gain access to AWS IAM credentials through phishing, insecure storage, or exfiltration attack vectors. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access may lead to data breaches, unauthorized data manipulation, and potential financial losses for the organization. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully phishes an employee, obtaining long-term AWS IAM credentials. These credentials are then used to access sensitive data or perform unauthorized actions, going unnoticed for extended periods due to the persistent nature of the credentials.

threat.name: Lack of monitoring and unrestricted access can lead to undetected malicious activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of monitoring and unrestricted access can lead to undetected malicious activities and unauthorized access to resources. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external attackers can exploit the lack of monitoring to engage in unauthorized or malicious activities without being detected. Additionally, users or services with unrestricted access may inadvertently or maliciously access sensitive data or perform unauthorized actions. 
Impacts
Unauthorized access to resources can result in data breaches, data loss, service disruptions, and significant financial and reputational damage. Undetected malicious activities can escalate over time, leading to more severe security incidents. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains access to an IAM user's credentials due to unrestricted access policies and leverages this to exfiltrate sensitive data without being detected due to inadequate monitoring.
2. An insider with excessive permissions intentionally deletes critical resources, causing service disruptions and data loss, which go unnoticed until significant damage has been done.

component.name: Ingestion

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-502
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-502: Deserialization of Untrusted Data The product deserializes untrusted data without sufficiently verifying that the resulting data will be valid.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

countermeasure.name: Apply authorization checks and access control
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing robust authorization checks and access control mechanisms is essential to ensure that only authorized users are able to perform sensitive actions such as data export and import. This countermeasure is designed to prevent unauthorized access and data leakage, which are critical for maintaining the security of your application. Heres how you can effectively apply these controls:

1: Define Access Control Policies

  • Action: Establish clear access control policies that define who can access the data export/import functionalities.
  • Details: Determine which roles or user groups should have the permissions to perform exports and imports. Consider the principles of least privilege and need-to-know to minimize access as much as possible.

2: Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)

  • Action: Use RBAC to enforce access control policies based on user roles.
  • Details:
    • Map out all user roles within your application.
    • Assign permissions to these roles regarding who can initiate data exports or imports.
    • Implement checks in your application to ensure that only users with the correct roles can access these functions.

3: Secure API Endpoints

  • Action: Ensure that all API endpoints handling data export and import are secured with appropriate authentication and authorization checks.
  • Details:
    • Use OAuth tokens, API keys, or similar methods to authenticate API requests.
    • Verify that the authenticated user has the required role or permission before processing their request.
    • Log all access attempts, both successful and unsuccessful, to help detect and respond to potential security incidents.

4: Apply Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC)

  • Action: Incorporate ABAC to add another layer of security, based on attributes in addition to roles.
  • Details:
    • Define attributes that might include user location, time of access, and the type of data being requested.
    • Use these attributes to make dynamic access control decisions, providing finer-grained security than RBAC alone.

5: Validate and Sanitize Inputs

  • Action: Ensure that all input used in data export and import processes is validated and sanitized to prevent injection attacks.
  • Details:
    • Check all input data for correctness and sanitize any inputs used in file paths, SQL queries, or commands.
    • Use prepared statements or parameterized queries when interacting with databases to avoid SQL injection.

6: Regularly Review and Update Access Controls

  • Action: Regularly review your access control configurations and policies to ensure they still align with current business needs and security best practices.
  • Details:
    • Conduct periodic audits of user roles and permissions.
    • Update access controls in response to changes in personnel, roles, or security requirements.
    • Use automated tools to help manage and audit permissions across your application.

7: Educate Users on Security Best Practices

  • Action: Train users on the importance of security, particularly how they handle data export and import functions.
  • Details:
    • Provide regular training sessions on the potential risks and the critical nature of following security protocols.
    • Encourage users to report any suspicious activities or potential breaches.

By implementing these steps, you create a robust framework for authorization checks and access control that can significantly enhance the security of your data export/import processes. This framework not only protects sensitive data but also helps in maintaining compliance with regulatory requirements such as GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS, which mandate strict access controls and user data protection.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that serialization is not used when communicating with untrusted clients
countermeasure.desc:
Serialization can expose systems to various security risks, especially when data is serialized and deserialized across untrusted boundaries. This countermeasure focuses on avoiding serialization when dealing with untrusted clients to prevent attacks such as remote code execution or injection vulnerabilities. Heres how to implement this practice effectively:

Understand the Risks of Serialization:

  • Familiarize yourself with the dangers associated with serialization, particularly how deserializing data from untrusted sources can lead to attacks such as remote code execution.
  • Reference: OWASP provides detailed insights into serialization vulnerabilities and is a valuable resource for understanding these risks.

Use Simple Data Formats for Data Exchange:

  • Instead of using complex serialization formats that include executable code, opt for simple, non-executable data formats like JSON or XML for data interchange.
  • Implement parsers that strictly validate incoming data against a schema to ensure it adheres to expected structures and types.

Validate and Sanitize All Incoming Data:

  • Regardless of the format, rigorously validate and sanitize all incoming data to ensure it contains only the expected types of information.
  • Use tools and libraries that inherently provide secure parsing options that reduce the risk of injection attacks.

Avoid Exposing Serialization Interfaces:

  • If your application must serialize data, ensure that serialization interfaces are not exposed to untrusted clients. Keep serialization internal to the system where possible.
  • Design APIs such that they accept and return only simple, structured data formats that are less prone to manipulation.

Implement Robust Authentication and Authorization:

  • Ensure that any endpoint or function that might involve data serialization requires strong authentication and authorization to prevent unauthorized access.
  • Example: Use OAuth for user authentication and ensure that each API call is verified to come from an authorized user before processing.

Monitor and Log All Data Transactions:

  • Keep detailed logs of all data transactions, including serialization and deserialization events, to monitor for unusual activity that could suggest an attack.
  • Use security monitoring tools to alert on anomalies that may indicate exploitation attempts.

Regular Security Audits and Penetration Testing:

  • Regularly conduct security audits and penetration tests to identify and mitigate any vulnerabilities associated with data serialization and deserialization.
  • Engage with cybersecurity professionals who can simulate attacks on your system to test the robustness of your serialization and deserialization processes.

Educate Developers and Administrators:

  • Train your development team on the security risks associated with serialization and the best practices for safely handling data exchange with untrusted clients.
  • Regular workshops and security training sessions can help keep security at the forefront of your team's practices.

By implementing these steps, you ensure that your data export/import functions are secure and resistant to the common pitfalls of serialization when interacting with untrusted clients. This proactive approach not only enhances the security of your application but also safeguards sensitive data from being exploited via serialization vulnerabilities.

countermeasure.name: Implement and monitor business logic limits for actions and transactions
countermeasure.desc:
To protect your application from abuse and ensure it operates within its intended use, it's critical to implement and monitor business logic limits. These limits help prevent fraudulent activities and excessive use, which could degrade system performance and impact the user experience. Heres a step-by-step guide on how to effectively apply these controls:

1: Define Business Logic Limits

  • Action: Identify critical actions and transactions within your application that require limits based on typical usage patterns and business needs.
  • Details:
    • Determine limits for activities such as the number of transactions per user per day, maximum login attempts, or the quantity of items that can be processed in a single transaction.
    • Consult with business stakeholders to understand the operational requirements and constraints.

2: Implement Limits in Application Logic

  • Action: Integrate these defined limits directly into your applications business logic.
  • Details:
    • Code these limits into the application, ensuring that checks are performed before the execution of the related actions.
    • For example, limit the number of items a user can purchase in a single order or restrict the number of password reset attempts within a certain time frame.

3: Use Rate Limiting and Throttling Techniques

  • Action: Apply rate limiting and throttling to prevent abuse of your applications interfaces and services.
  • Details:
    • Implement rate limiting on API endpoints to control the number of requests a user can make within a specified time period.
    • Use server-side tools or cloud service features to enforce these limits and prevent the endpoints from being overwhelmed by excessive requests.

4: Validate and Sanitize Inputs

  • Action: Ensure all user inputs are validated and sanitized to prevent common vulnerabilities that could be exploited to bypass business logic limits.
  • Details:
    • Use strong validation rules to check that all inputs meet the expected format and range.
    • Sanitize inputs to remove unwanted characters or scripts that could be used in an injection attack.

5: Monitor and Audit Transactions

  • Action: Set up monitoring and auditing mechanisms to track compliance with business logic limits and to detect potential abuse or anomalies.
  • Details:
    • Log all transactions and key actions, along with their frequency, to detect patterns that may indicate abuse or attempts to circumvent business logic limits.
    • Use monitoring tools to set alerts for when certain thresholds are reached or exceeded.

6: Regularly Review and Adjust Limits

  • Action: Periodically review the effectiveness of your business logic limits and adjust them based on new business insights or changes in user behavior.
  • Details:
    • Analyze the logged data and monitoring alerts to assess whether the limits are too strict, too lenient, or if new limits need to be established.
    • Adjust the limits in consultation with business and security teams to ensure they continue to protect the application without negatively impacting user experience.

7: Educate Users About Limits

  • Action: Communicate the existence and rationale of these limits to your users to manage their expectations and reduce frustration.
  • Details:
    • Include information about the limits in user guides, FAQs, or during the sign-up and error messages.
    • Provide clear and constructive feedback when a limit is reached to help users understand how to proceed.

By implementing and monitoring these business logic limits, you can safeguard your application against operational abuse and maintain its integrity and performance. This approach not only enhances security but also supports a sustainable user experience by ensuring the application behaves as intended under various load conditions.

countermeasure.name: Implement application and network rate limiting
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing rate limiting is an essential security measure to protect your application from abuse and overuse, such as denial-of-service attacks or brute force attacks. Rate limiting controls the number of requests a user can make to an application or network resource within a given time frame. Here's how to put this protective measure in place effectively:

Identify Critical Resources:

  • Determine which parts of your application or network are critical and most vulnerable to overuse or abuse. This typically includes login pages, data export/import endpoints, and API access points.
  • Example: The data export function might be limited to 5 requests per hour per user to prevent overload.

Choose a Rate Limiting Strategy:

  • Decide on the type of rate limiting mechanism that best fits your applications needs. Common strategies include fixed window counters, sliding window logs, and token bucket algorithms.
  • Reference: Research the pros and cons of each method to choose the most appropriate one. For instance, a token bucket algorithm allows for bursts of traffic which might be useful for legitimate high-traffic scenarios.

Implement Rate Limiting at Different Layers:

  • Apply rate limiting at both the application and network layers to provide multiple lines of defense.
  • Network-level rate limiting can be configured on your firewall or router to prevent excessive traffic from reaching your servers.
  • Application-level rate limiting can be implemented in your application code or via middleware that checks the number of requests from a user or IP address against your set limits.

Configure Specific Limits:

  • Set practical request limits based on the typical user behavior and your systems capacity. Consider different limits for different types of users or actions. For instance, read operations could have a higher rate limit compared to write operations.
  • Example: Use middleware in a web framework (like Express for Node.js) to limit requests to data export APIs:

const rateLimit = require('express-rate-limit');

const apiLimiter = rateLimit({
   windowMs: 15 * 60 * 1000, // 15 minutes
   max: 100,
   message: "Too many accounts created from this IP, please try again after 15 minutes"
});

app.use('/api/', apiLimiter);

Provide Feedback to Users:

  • Inform users when they are approaching the limit of allowed requests and after they have hit the limit. Clear communication helps prevent frustration and supports legitimate users in managing their usage.
  • Example: Return HTTP status code 429 ("Too Many Requests") with a message explaining how long they should wait before making additional requests.

Monitor and Adjust Limits:

  • Continuously monitor the effectiveness of your rate limits and adjust them as necessary based on user feedback and system performance.
  • Use analytics to understand traffic patterns and adjust your rate limiting settings to optimize both security and user experience.

Educate Your Team:

  • Ensure that all team members understand the purpose and mechanisms of rate limiting. Proper training helps in maintaining and adjusting rate limiting rules as the application and its user base evolve.

Regular Testing and Reviews:

  • Regularly test the rate limiting measures under different load conditions to ensure they function as expected during peak traffic and attack scenarios.
  • Review and update the configurations as your network and application environments evolve.

By implementing these steps, you will effectively control the flow of requests to your applications sensitive functions, thus protecting it from various types of abuse and ensuring its availability and reliability. Rate limiting not only helps in mitigating denial-of-service attacks but also in managing the load on your infrastructure, making it a critical component of a well-rounded security and performance strategy.

countermeasure.name: Validate all data received
countermeasure.desc:
Validating all data received by your application is a critical security control that protects against a variety of vulnerabilities, including injection attacks, data corruption, and unauthorized access. Heres how to effectively implement this security practice:

1: Define Validation Rules

  • Action: Establish comprehensive validation rules for all input data types that your application receives.
  • Details:
    • Determine what constitutes valid input for each field (e.g., alphanumeric, numeric, date formats).
    • Set constraints on acceptable input length, format, and range.
    • Identify mandatory and optional fields.

2: Implement Input Validation

  • Action: Integrate input validation into your application at the point of data receipt.
  • Details:
    • Use server-side validation as the primary method to ensure security, as client-side validation can be bypassed.
    • Employ regular expressions to check text formats, and use built-in functions for other data types like dates and numbers.
    • Sanitize inputs to remove potentially harmful characters, especially those that could be used in SQL injection or cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

3: Use Whitelisting Instead of Blacklisting

  • Action: Adopt a whitelisting approach to validation, where only approved input is accepted.
  • Details:
    • Define a clear list of acceptable inputs for each field.
    • Reject any input that does not strictly conform to these whitelisted values.

4: Validate Data Origins

  • Action: Ensure that the source of the data is legitimate, especially in scenarios involving data from external systems or APIs.
  • Details:
    • Verify API keys and authenticate data sources when receiving data from external services.
    • Use cryptographic techniques like digital signatures when data integrity and origin verification are critical.

5: Handle Validation Failures Properly

  • Action: Define and implement secure error handling procedures to manage invalid inputs.
  • Details:
    • Provide generic error messages that do not expose details of the data validation logic or system internals.
    • Log details about the validation failure and the source of the input for auditing and troubleshooting purposes.

6: Regularly Update Validation Logic

  • Action: Continuously review and update your validation rules and procedures to adapt to new threats and changes in application functionality.
  • Details:
    • Keep abreast of new security practices and vulnerabilities related to input validation.
    • Regularly test the application with security testing tools and update validation logic to mitigate newly discovered threats.

7: Educate Developers and Users

  • Action: Train developers on secure coding practices and inform users about the importance of providing accurate data.
  • Details:
    • Conduct regular training sessions for developers focusing on security best practices, including proper input validation.
    • Include tips in user interfaces to help users understand expected input formats and requirements.

By following these steps, you can ensure that all data received by your application is thoroughly validated, reducing the risk of security breaches and data integrity issues. Proper validation is a cornerstone of secure application development and helps in maintaining trust with your users by protecting their data.

countermeasure.name: Validate the imported file format before processing
countermeasure.desc:
Validating the format of imported files before processing them is a critical security measure to prevent various types of attacks, including file corruption, injection attacks, and other forms of data tampering. Proper validation ensures that only files with expected and safe formats are processed, significantly reducing the risk of executing malicious content. Here's how to implement file format validation effectively:

Define Allowed File Types:

  • Clearly define and document the types of files your application will accept. This specification should be based on the needs of your application and the nature of the data it handles.
  • Example: For a data import feature, you might only allow CSV, XML, or JSON files.

Implement File Type Validation:

  • Add checks to ensure that the uploaded files match one of the allowed formats both by file extension and MIME type.
  • Use server-side methods to determine the file type. Do not rely on client-side validation as it can be easily bypassed.
  • Example in Python using the python-magic library:

import magic

def validate_file_type(file_path):
   mime = magic.Magic(mime=True)
   file_mime_type = mime.from_file(file_path)
   allowed_mime_types = ['text/csv', 'application/xml', 'application/json']
   if file_mime_type not in allowed_mime_types:
       raise ValueError("Unsupported file type.")

Check File Headers and Content:

  • In addition to checking file extensions and MIME types, inspect the file headers and the initial content to further verify that they match the expected formats.
  • Example: Ensure that CSV files begin with expected column headers, or that XML and JSON files have the correct root elements.

Use Secure File Handling Practices:

  • Handle files in a secure manner by storing them in a designated area with restricted access, preferably outside the web root. Ensure files are scanned for malware if they are to be stored or further processed.
  • Example: Use antivirus scanning on the server side before the files are processed or stored long-term.

Limit File Size:

  • Impose limits on the size of the files being uploaded to prevent denial-of-service (DoS) attacks caused by extremely large files.
  • Example: Reject files that exceed a maximum size threshold (e.g., 5 MB for a CSV file).

Provide Detailed Error Feedback:

  • When rejecting a file, provide clear, non-technical feedback to the user about why the file was not accepted. This helps legitimate users correct the issue without giving too much information to potential attackers.
  • Example: "The uploaded file type is not supported. Please upload a CSV, XML, or JSON file."

Log and Monitor Upload Activities:

  • Keep detailed logs of file upload attempts, including information about the file type, the user who uploaded it, and whether the upload was successful or rejected.
  • Use monitoring tools to detect and alert on unusual upload patterns that might indicate an attack.

Regularly Update Validation Logic:

  • As file formats evolve and new vulnerabilities are discovered, regularly update your validation logic to cover new security threats.
  • Example: Regularly review and update the list of allowed MIME types and the logic used to validate file headers.

By following these steps, you can robustly validate the format of files imported into your system, significantly reducing the risk associated with handling potentially malicious files. This proactive approach helps maintain the integrity and security of your data import processes.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers cause the target to allocate excessive resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This threat involves attackers manipulating the data import or export functionality of an application to cause the target system to allocate excessive resources. This could be in the form of CPU, memory, disk space, or network bandwidth. By crafting data in a way that is computationally expensive to process or by creating data structures that grow exponentially, attackers can slow down the system, cause service degradation, or even lead to a complete Denial of Service (DoS).

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The primary threat agents are external attackers who might not need authenticated access to exploit this vulnerability if the import/export functionality is exposed. Common attack vectors include:

  • Uploading specially crafted files that require extensive processing.
  • Exporting or importing data in formats that lead to inefficient processing (e.g., deeply nested XML or JSON).
  • Exploiting flaws in the way data is parsed or handled, such as recursive references in serialized objects or oversized files.

Impacts

The impacts of such attacks can be significant, including:

  • System slowdown or unavailability, affecting user experience and disrupting business operations.
  • Increased operational costs due to the need for additional resources to handle the load or mitigate the attack.
  • Potential data loss or corruption if systems fail under the strain.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers that an application's data import function does not properly handle large CSV files. They create a CSV file with millions of rows and excessively long strings in each cell, and then import this file into the application. The application attempts to load the entire file into memory for processing, resulting in exhaustion of system memory and a crash.

Scenario 2: A financial software allows users to import transaction data in XML format. An attacker crafts an XML file that uses XML entity expansion, a technique where a small amount of XML text is used to create a large amount of text when the file is processed. This 'XML bomb' causes the server's CPU and memory usage to spike to 100%, effectively rendering the service inoperable.

Scenario 3: An attacker targets a data export feature of a database management tool. They initiate multiple export processes simultaneously, each designed to export the largest tables in the database repeatedly. This floods the network and disk I/O, slowing down the database server and affecting all other operations on it.

To mitigate these risks, it is crucial for applications to implement resource usage limits and efficient parsing algorithms. Validating file sizes and types before processing, using secure coding practices to handle data structures, and monitoring system performance for anomalies can also help prevent such resource exhaustion attacks. Additionally, implementing rate limiting on data import and export functionalities can reduce the risk of abuse.

reference.name: Mitre ATT&CK Technique T1499.003

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers exploit a weakness in the configuration of access controls and is able to bypass the intended protection
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data export/import features in applications are used to transfer large volumes of data between systems or to backup and restore data. When attackers exploit weaknesses in the configuration of access controls for these features, they can bypass the intended protections, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive data. This vulnerability typically arises from misconfigurations that leave import/export functions less secure than other system components, such as insufficient validation of user roles or flawed implementation of security checks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Typically include external attackers who may be motivated by financial gain, industrial espionage, or malicious intent to disrupt operations. Insiders with limited permissions exploiting these weaknesses to gain unauthorized access or elevate privileges can also be threat agents.
  • Attack Vectors: Common vectors include:
    • Social Engineering: Manipulating legitimate users to perform data exports/imports that include malicious data.
    • Direct Exploitation of Weak Configurations: Accessing misconfigured interfaces that should be restricted, or using stolen credentials that are not adequately checked during the data export/import process.
    • Abuse of Insufficiently Protected API Endpoints: Interacting with APIs that are used for data transfer but lack robust authentication and authorization checks.

Impacts

The consequences of such attacks can be severe, including:

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive, proprietary, or confidential data, leading to leakage of customer information, financial data, or intellectual property.
  • Data Integrity Issues: The attacker could alter or corrupt data during import or export, leading to misinformation or system malfunctions.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Breaches involving personal data can result in violations of data protection regulations (such as GDPR or HIPAA), incurring heavy fines and legal repercussions.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust and confidence, which can have long-lasting effects on the business's market position and financial stability.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An external attacker discovers that the data export feature of a financial software does not properly validate whether users have the right to export data. By exploiting this, the attacker, posing as a low-level employee, exports financial reports and customer data, which are then used for identity theft and financial fraud.

Scenario 2: An insider within a company uses their legitimate access to the import functionality of a human resources management system, which is misconfigured to allow the import of executable scripts along with data files. The insider uploads a malicious script that grants them backdoor access to the system, which they later use for unauthorized data access and manipulation.

Mitigation Strategies

To mitigate the risks associated with these vulnerabilities, the following strategies should be implemented:

  • Rigorous Access Control: Ensure that all data import and export functions enforce strict access control checks that validate the user's identity and permissions.
  • Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular audits of the configurations of all access controls to identify and rectify any misconfigurations or weak policies.
  • Least Privilege Principle: Limit permissions strictly to what is necessary for users to perform their duties, especially in functions that handle sensitive data.
  • Secure API Endpoints: Protect all API endpoints involved in data export/import with strong authentication and authorization mechanisms.
  • User Activity Monitoring and Logging: Monitor and log all user activities related to data export/import functions to detect and respond to unauthorized access attempts promptly.
  • Education and Training: Regularly train staff on the importance of security practices and the specific measures taken to secure data export/import functions.

By implementing these measures, organizations can strengthen the security of their data export/import functionalities and protect against unauthorized access and data breaches.

reference.name: Mitre ATT&CK Technique T1574.010

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0004 - Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to data and/or systems through injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Injection attacks involve the introduction of malicious code or commands into a system, typically via input fields that are improperly validated or sanitized. This broad category of attacks can affect systems that handle data export/import by manipulating the data or commands that such systems process. Common types of injection include SQL injection, command injection, and script injection, all of which could be used to corrupt database queries, execute arbitrary commands, or run malicious scripts, respectively.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: These attacks are commonly conducted by external attackers who may seek to steal, modify, or destroy data. However, they can also be carried out by insiders or third parties who have been granted limited access to the system.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • User Input Fields: Attackers might inject malicious code into data fields that are part of data export/import forms or APIs.
    • Manipulation of Export/Import Files: Malicious code could be inserted into files that are expected to be imported into the system, exploiting inadequate validation of file contents.
    • Unsanitized API Calls: APIs handling data transfers that do not properly sanitize inputs can be exploited to inject malicious commands or SQL code.

Impacts

The impacts of injection attacks on data export/import systems can be significant:

  • Unauthorized Access and Data Theft: Successful SQL injection could allow attackers to bypass authentication and access sensitive data stored in databases.
  • Data Corruption or Deletion: Command injections may enable attackers to delete logs, corrupt databases, or alter exported data, undermining data integrity.
  • System Compromise: In cases of severe vulnerabilities, injection attacks can lead to complete system takeovers, allowing persistent access to the attacker.
  • Compliance Violations and Legal Repercussions: Breaches involving sensitive data can lead to non-compliance with regulatory standards, resulting in fines and legal challenges.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker targets an e-commerce site's product database that integrates with a data export tool used for generating sales reports. The attacker injects SQL code into a search field that is part of the data export feature. This code is crafted to execute within the database query used to gather data for the report, resulting in unauthorized access to all customer transactions.

Scenario 2: During a routine import of supplier data through an administrative portal, an attacker includes shell commands in a CSV file. The import script, which does not properly sanitize its inputs, executes these commands. This results in the execution of a script that installs malware on the server, allowing the attacker to control the server remotely.

Mitigation Strategies

To defend against injection attacks in data export/import functions, consider the following measures:

  • Input Validation and Sanitization: Implement strict validation rules to ensure only expected types of data are processed. Sanitize inputs to remove or neutralize potentially harmful code.
  • Use of Prepared Statements and Parameterized Queries: For database interactions, use prepared statements with parameterized queries to prevent SQL injection.
  • Secure File Handling: Ensure that files imported into the system are scanned for malicious content and that their formats and contents are validated against expected norms.
  • Limit API Exposure: Restrict API access with authentication and authorization checks. Sanitize all data received via API calls rigorously.
  • Regular Security Audits and Code Reviews: Conduct comprehensive audits and reviews of code handling data import and export to identify and mitigate potential injection flaws.
  • Security Training: Educate developers and administrators about the risks of injection attacks and the importance of implementing secure coding practices and operational protocols.

By taking these steps, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with injection attacks and enhance the overall security posture of their data export/import systems.

reference.name: Mitre ATT&CK Technique T1190

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1021 - Remote Services

threat.name: An adversary attempts to exploit an application by injecting additional, malicious content during its processing of serialized objects
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This threat involves adversaries exploiting the application's deserialization process by injecting malicious content into serialized objects. Serialization is the process of converting data structures or object states into a format that can be stored or transmitted and reconstructed later. When an application deserializes these objects without adequate safeguards, it can execute the malicious content embedded within, leading to unauthorized actions or data breaches. This form of attack is particularly dangerous because it can allow attackers to execute arbitrary code, escalate privileges, or manipulate application logic.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The primary threat agents are typically external attackers, though insiders with malicious intent can also exploit these vulnerabilities. Common attack vectors include:

  • Submitting maliciously crafted serialized objects via web forms, APIs, or other data input channels that accept serialized formats.
  • Manipulating serialized data stored in cookies, URL parameters, or hidden form fields that the application later deserializes.
  • Exploiting applications that deserialize data without validating its authenticity or integrity, making them susceptible to object injection attacks.

Impacts

The impacts of injecting malicious content into serialized objects can be extensive, including:

  • Remote Code Execution: Execution of arbitrary code by the attacker, potentially leading to full system compromise.
  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data stored within the application or its connected backend systems.
  • Denial of Service: Crashing the application or making it unavailable to legitimate users.
  • Privilege Escalation: Gaining elevated privileges within the application, allowing for further malicious activities.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers that a web application's user settings are stored in a serialized format in a cookie. They craft a cookie with a serialized object that includes a command to delete important files when deserialized. When the user next accesses the application, the malicious serialized object is deserialized, and the command is executed, leading to data loss.

Scenario 2: An online forum allows users to upload serialized data representing their user profiles. An attacker crafts a profile object that includes a script designed to execute upon deserialization. This script accesses the servers database, exporting confidential data to a remote server controlled by the attacker.

Scenario 3: A corporate application deserializes XML files received over a network interface to configure application settings. An attacker sends a specially crafted XML document that exploits an insecure deserialization vulnerability, causing the application to execute embedded malicious code that installs malware on the server.

To mitigate the risks associated with malicious content injection in serialized object processing, applications should:

  • Validate and Sanitize All Input: Use whitelisting to allow only known safe content within serialized objects. Validate all incoming data before deserialization to ensure it conforms to expected formats.
  • Implement Integrity Checks: Use digital signatures or checksums to verify that serialized data has not been tampered with before processing it.
  • Limit Object Creation: Restrict deserialization to only known safe classes or objects. This can often be configured in modern serialization libraries.
  • Use Secure Libraries and Practices: Utilize libraries and frameworks that inherently mitigate common deserialization vulnerabilities, such as those that do not allow arbitrary code execution during the deserialization process.
  • Regular Security Audits and Testing: Conduct regular security reviews and penetration testing focused on components that serialize and deserialize data to identify and remediate potential vulnerabilities.

By taking these precautions, developers can protect their applications from the severe risks posed by malicious content injection in serialized object processing.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable server-side encryption for dependent resources
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data at rest in AWS Kinesis Data Analytics, enable server-side encryption (SSE) for all dependent resources such as Kinesis Data Streams, Firehose delivery streams, and Amazon S3 buckets. Follow these steps to implement SSE:

For Kinesis Data Streams:

  • In the Kinesis Data Streams console, select the stream, enable SSE, and choose an AWS KMS key.

For Kinesis Firehose:

  • In the Firehose console, select the delivery stream, enable SSE, and choose an AWS KMS key.

For Amazon S3 Buckets:

  • In the S3 console, select the bucket, enable default encryption (SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS), and choose or create an AWS KMS key.

Verify and Monitor:

  • Verify configurations in the AWS Management Console and use AWS Config and CloudTrail to monitor and audit encryption status.
