customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Harden Redis configuration and disable dangerous commands
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update a hardened Redis configuration by disabling dangerous commands to reduce the system's attack surface. This control ensures that only necessary commands are enabled, limiting the potential for misuse by attackers or malicious insiders. Developers and DevOps engineers should review the default Redis configuration, disable or restrict high-risk commands (such as FLUSHDB, FLUSHALL, CONFIG, and others), and enforce these settings via configuration management tools to maintain a secure deployment.

Implementation Steps:

Review Default Configuration:
Audit the default Redis configuration to identify and document commands that are not required for your use case.

Disable Dangerous Commands:
Update the configuration file to disable commands that could be misused (e.g., FLUSHDB, FLUSHALL, CONFIG, DEBUG) by renaming them or setting appropriate access controls.

Enforce Secure Configurations:
Use configuration management tools (e.g., Ansible, Puppet, Chef) to ensure that hardened settings are consistently applied across all Redis instances.

Regular Audits and Testing:
Periodically audit the Redis configuration and test the system to verify that dangerous commands remain disabled and that the system complies with security best practices.

References:

  • Redis Security Documentation

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Implement data integrity verification and access logging
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update data integrity verification and access logging for Redis Server to ensure that all data modifications are validated and all access events are recorded for auditing purposes. This control helps maintain the accuracy and reliability of data while providing detailed logs to facilitate forensic analysis and real-time monitoring. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate integrity checks into Redis operations and configure centralized logging systems to capture and analyze access events.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Integrity Verification:
Integrate mechanisms such as checksums or hash verifications to continuously validate the integrity of data stored in Redis.

Configure Comprehensive Access Logging:
Set up Redis to log all relevant access events, including command usage, authentication attempts, and configuration changes. Use centralized logging solutions (e.g., ELK stack, Splunk) for real-time analysis and historical audits.

Integrate with Monitoring and SIEM Tools:
Feed access logs and integrity check results into security information and event management (SIEM) systems to trigger alerts for anomalous activities.

Regular Audits and Reviews:
Periodically review logs and perform data integrity audits to ensure compliance with security policies and quickly detect any unauthorized changes.

References:

  • OWASP Logging Cheat Sheet

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and resource throttling
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update rate limiting and resource throttling for Redis Server to protect against denial-of-service attacks and resource exhaustion. This control ensures that incoming requests are controlled and that system resource usage (e.g., CPU, memory, I/O) is constrained, preventing overload caused by excessive or malicious traffic. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate rate limiting policies and resource throttling mechanisms into their Redis deployment using built-in configurations or external middleware, and continuously monitor system performance to adjust thresholds as needed.

Implementation Steps:

Define Rate Limiting Policies:
Establish acceptable thresholds for incoming requests based on system capacity and expected workloads.

Implement Rate Limiting Mechanisms:
Utilize built-in Redis configurations or deploy external proxies/load balancers that enforce rate limiting on API calls and client connections.

Apply Resource Throttling Controls:
Configure settings to limit resource consumption (e.g., CPU, memory, and I/O usage) per client or connection to prevent a single source from overloading the system.

Monitor and Audit:
Continuously monitor performance metrics and log access patterns. Regularly review and adjust rate limiting and throttling settings to ensure they remain effective against emerging traffic patterns or attack vectors.

References:

  • OWASP API Security Project

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Implement strong authentication and ACLs
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update strong authentication and ACLs for Redis Server to ensure that only verified users can access the system and that their actions are tightly controlled. This control mandates the use of robust authentication mechanisms (e.g., strong passwords, multi-factor authentication) and the configuration of granular Access Control Lists (ACLs) to restrict command execution and data access based on the principle of least privilege. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate these controls into Redis configurations using centralized management tools and continuously monitor access logs to verify compliance and detect any unauthorized activities.

Implementation Steps:

Enforce Strong Authentication:
Configure Redis to require strong passwords and, where applicable, integrate with centralized authentication services to enforce multi-factor authentication.

Configure Granular ACLs:
Define and apply ACLs to specify allowed commands and restrict access to sensitive data, ensuring that each user or application has only the permissions necessary for their function.

Integrate with Centralized Identity Management:
Utilize identity providers or centralized management systems to manage user credentials and enforce consistent authentication policies across your infrastructure.

Monitor and Audit:
Enable logging for authentication attempts and access events, and perform regular audits of ACL configurations to ensure that access controls remain effective and up-to-date.

References:

  • Redis ACL Documentation

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1021 - Restrict Web-Based Content

countermeasure.name: Regularly update Redis to the latest secure version
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update Redis to the latest secure version to ensure that all vulnerabilities are promptly patched and that the system benefits from the latest security enhancements. This control minimizes the risk of exploitation from known flaws by integrating an effective patch management process. Developers and DevOps engineers should monitor for new releases, thoroughly test updates in a controlled environment, and deploy them systematically using automated tools to maintain a secure and resilient Redis deployment.

Implementation Steps:

Monitor for New Releases:
Subscribe to Redis security bulletins and follow release notes to stay informed about updates and patches.

Test Updates in Staging:
Validate new Redis versions in a testing environment to ensure compatibility and stability with your existing applications before production deployment.

Automate Deployment:
Use automated deployment tools or scripts to roll out updates consistently across all Redis instances.

Audit and Verify Compliance:
Regularly review version inventories and update logs to confirm that all instances are running the latest secure version of Redis.

References:

  • Redis Security Documentation

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers cause denial of service through command flooding
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat occurs when attackers overwhelm the Redis server by flooding it with an excessive number of commands. Such command flooding consumes critical system resources (CPU, memory, and network bandwidth), potentially rendering the service unresponsive or completely unavailable to legitimate users.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers leveraging botnets or automated scripts to generate a high volume of Redis commands.
  • Distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attackers intentionally saturating the server with malicious traffic.
  • Insider threats abusing legitimate access to overload the system.
  • Adversaries exploiting misconfigurations or vulnerabilities in Redis that allow high-frequency command injections.

Impacts:

  • Denial of service, leading to prolonged downtime and loss of availability for legitimate users.
  • Degradation in system performance, affecting application responsiveness and user experience.
  • Increased operational costs and potential financial losses due to resource exhaustion and remediation efforts.
  • Damage to reputation and erosion of trust in the reliability of the service.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a botnet to send millions of requests per second to the Redis server, saturating its resources and causing it to crash or become unresponsive.
  • A malicious insider intentionally issues repetitive, resource-intensive commands during peak business hours, overwhelming the Redis instance and disrupting normal operations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers exploit outdated Redis vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat arises when Redis servers operate on outdated software versions that contain known vulnerabilities. Without timely updates, these vulnerabilities remain exploitable, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access, execute arbitrary code, or disrupt service availability.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers employing automated scanning tools to identify and target outdated Redis instances.
  • Cybercriminals exploiting publicly documented vulnerabilities to compromise Redis servers.
  • Insider threats leveraging legacy software configurations to bypass security controls.
  • Malware campaigns that specifically target unpatched Redis systems.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and administrative controls.
  • Execution of arbitrary code leading to full system compromise.
  • Service disruption or complete denial of service, impacting application availability.
  • Increased potential for lateral movement within the network, endangering broader infrastructure.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker identifies a Redis instance running an outdated version with a known vulnerability, then exploits it to obtain administrative access and modify or exfiltrate data.
  • A malware campaign targets unpatched Redis servers, exploiting a vulnerability to deploy ransomware that disrupts operations and demands payment for decryption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers intercept data due to unencrypted communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat arises when data transmitted between the Redis server and its clients or between internal nodes is not encrypted. Without TLS or other encryption mechanisms, the communication channel is exposed, allowing attackers to eavesdrop on and potentially manipulate sensitive information as it travels across the network.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers using man-in-the-middle (MITM) techniques to intercept traffic over unencrypted channels.
  • Adversaries exploiting insecure public Wi-Fi or compromised network devices to capture data in transit.
  • Insider threats with network access capturing sensitive information.
  • Automated tools designed to scan for and intercept unsecured communications.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data such as authentication credentials, commands, and data payloads.
  • Data manipulation or injection attacks, leading to service compromise.
  • Increased risk of broader network compromise if intercepted data includes session tokens or other access credentials.
  • Potential reputational damage and compliance violations due to data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker sets up a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot in a public area and intercepts unencrypted communications between a client application and the Redis server, capturing sensitive login details.
  • A compromised network device within an internal network captures data exchanged between Redis nodes, allowing an adversary to reconstruct confidential information or inject malicious commands into the data stream.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Attackers exploit default configurations and misconfigurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat arises when Redis servers are deployed with default configurations or improperly secured settings, leaving them vulnerable to exploitation. Default settings often lack proper authentication, access controls, or hardened security measures, allowing attackers to easily gain access or manipulate the system. Misconfigurations, such as open network ports or enabled dangerous commands, further increase the risk of unauthorized access and system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers using automated scanning tools to detect Redis instances with default or weak configurations.
  • Cybercriminals exploiting misconfigured settings, such as no authentication or exposed management interfaces.
  • Insider threats leveraging misconfigurations to gain unauthorized access or disrupt service.
  • Malware targeting unprotected Redis servers with known insecure defaults.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and administrative functions.
  • Data manipulation, corruption, or deletion leading to operational disruptions.
  • Denial of service due to malicious commands or system overload.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network and broader infrastructure compromise.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker scans for Redis servers using default ports and finds an instance with no authentication configured; they then execute administrative commands to flush the database or alter stored data.
  • A misconfigured Redis node with exposed management interfaces is exploited by an insider, who uses the insecure settings to gain elevated privileges and manipulate critical data.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access due to weak authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat occurs when Redis servers are protected by inadequate authentication measuressuch as weak, default, or easily guessable credentialswhich allow attackers to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized access. Without strong authentication, adversaries can exploit the system, access sensitive data, and potentially execute malicious commands.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers employing automated brute force or credential stuffing techniques.
  • Insider threats leveraging default or weak passwords to access restricted resources.
  • Adversaries exploiting misconfigured systems that lack robust authentication mechanisms.
  • Social engineering tactics that trick users into disclosing their credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and administrative functions.
  • Data exfiltration, manipulation, or deletion compromising data integrity.
  • Potential for lateral movement within the network, leading to broader system compromise.
  • Reputational damage and financial loss due to security breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses automated tools to brute force weak or default credentials on a Redis server, eventually gaining administrative access and exfiltrating confidential information.
  • A malicious insider exploits a system with minimal authentication controls to access and modify critical data, enabling further exploitation or data theft.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers tamper with data due to lack of data integrity controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat arises when Redis servers lack robust data integrity mechanisms, enabling attackers to modify, corrupt, or delete data without detection. Without proper integrity checkssuch as hash verifications, digital signatures, or built-in consistency mechanismsany unauthorized data changes can go unnoticed, undermining the reliability and trustworthiness of the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers exploiting weak authentication or misconfigured systems to gain access to Redis data.
  • Insider threats with legitimate access who abuse their privileges to alter critical data.
  • Automated scripts or malware that bypass or exploit the absence of integrity checks to manipulate data.
  • Attackers leveraging network vulnerabilities to intercept and modify data in transit.

Impacts:

  • Data corruption or unauthorized modifications leading to unreliable or incorrect information.
  • Disruption of business operations due to compromised data integrity.
  • Financial and reputational damage arising from the manipulation of critical data.
  • Increased risk of further exploitation if tampered data is used to trigger additional vulnerabilities or misconfigurations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker gains unauthorized access to a Redis node and alters key-value entries, causing downstream applications to process corrupted data, which leads to operational failures.
  • A malicious insider modifies transaction records stored in Redis without triggering any alarms, resulting in financial discrepancies that impact business reporting and decision-making.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

countermeasure.name: Enforce identity-based access control using AWS Directory Service or custom providers
countermeasure.desc: Leverage AWS Transfer Familys integration with AWS Directory Service or custom identity providers to implement strong, identity-based access controls. Configure your Transfer Family server to authenticate users through these external identity providers, ensuring that only authorized users can access and manage file transfers. This approach enhances security by utilizing robust authentication mechanisms and streamlining user management. Regularly review access policies to ensure compliance with least-privilege principles.

countermeasure.name: Enforce secure protocols on AWS Transfer Family
countermeasure.desc: Configure AWS Transfer Family to only use secure protocols, such as SFTP and FTPS, to ensure all data transferred is encrypted. In the AWS Management Console, set up your Transfer Family server to exclusively support these protocols, preventing unencrypted transfers over insecure channels. This mitigates the risk of data interception or tampering during transit. Regularly audit your server configurations and file transfer protocols to ensure they adhere to security best practices for data protection.

countermeasure.name: Integrate AWS Transfer Family with VPC endpoints for private file transfers
countermeasure.desc: Integrate AWS Transfer Family with VPC endpoints to route file transfers securely through your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC), ensuring that data is kept private and does not traverse the public internet. This can be configured through the AWS Management Console by setting up VPC endpoints for your Transfer Family server. This approach enhances security by isolating traffic within your network, preventing exposure to external threats. Regularly audit VPC configurations to maintain secure and private data transfers.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure data in transit
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data in transit is vulnerable to interception or tampering when transferred over insecure protocols, such as FTP, or without encryption. This could lead to unauthorized access and manipulation of sensitive information.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Agents: External attackers, man-in-the-middle (MitM) attackers.
  • Vectors: Insecure transfer protocols like FTP or unencrypted data transfer over public networks.

Impacts

  • Data breaches or data manipulation.
  • Compliance violations and loss of trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A file is transferred over FTP without encryption, allowing an attacker to capture sensitive information.
  2. An attacker intercepts unencrypted data during transit, altering its contents.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data due to public internet transfers
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data may be exposed when transferred over the public internet using AWS Transfer Family without proper security measures. Public data transfers are vulnerable to interception or tampering, leading to unauthorized access to confidential information.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Agents: External attackers, man-in-the-middle (MitM) attackers.
  • Vectors: Public internet file transfers without encryption or secure protocols.

Impacts

  • Data breaches exposing sensitive business or customer information.
  • Financial losses and compliance violations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A file transfer occurs over the public internet without encryption, allowing an attacker to intercept sensitive information.
  2. An unsecured FTP transfer is intercepted by a MitM attacker who gains access to critical business documents.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access through weak identity management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Weak identity management in AWS Transfer Family can result in unauthorized access to sensitive data or services. Without strong authentication mechanisms, attackers or unauthorized users may gain access, leading to data breaches.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders.
  • Vectors: Weak credentials, lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA), insufficient identity provider integration.

Impacts

  • Data breaches and service disruption.
  • Compliance violations and potential financial loss.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses weak credentials to access AWS Transfer Family, exfiltrating sensitive data.
  2. Lack of integration with an external identity provider allows unauthorized users to gain access.

component.name: Unstructured Data/Media
component.desc: Represents unstructured data and media sources.

weakness.name: CWE-257
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-257: Storing Passwords in a Recoverable Format The storage of passwords in a recoverable format makes them subject to password reuse attacks by malicious users. In fact, it should be noted that recoverable encrypted passwords provide no significant benefit over plaintext passwords since they are subject not only to reuse by malicious attackers but also by malicious insiders. If a system administrator can recover a password directly, or use a brute force search on the available information, the administrator can use the password on other accounts.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-415
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-415: Double Free The product calls free() twice on the same memory address, potentially leading to modification of unexpected memory locations. When a program calls free() twice with the same argument, the program's memory management data structures become corrupted. This corruption can cause the program to crash or, in some circumstances, cause two later calls to malloc() to return the same pointer. If malloc() returns the same value twice and the program later gives the attacker control over the data that is written into this doubly-allocated memory, the program becomes vulnerable to a buffer overflow attack.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-942
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-942: Permissive Cross-domain Policy with Untrusted Domains The product uses a cross-domain policy file that includes domains that should not be trusted.

countermeasure.name: Configure CORS headers to restrict resource sharing to trusted domains
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the OpenStack Swift Documentation on CORS for detailed guidance on setting up CORS headers.

Configure CORS Headers:

  • Update your Swift proxy server configuration to define the CORS headers, ensuring that only trusted domains are allowed access to your resources.
  • Set allowed origins to a whitelist of trusted domains, and configure allowed methods, headers, and credentials as necessary.
  • Test the configuration to confirm that unauthorized domains are blocked from accessing Swift resources.

Test and Validate:

  • Use tools like curl or browser developer tools to simulate requests from both authorized and unauthorized domains.
  • Verify that responses include the correct CORS headers and that access is restricted as per the configuration.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate logging and monitoring to continuously check for misconfigurations or unauthorized access attempts.
  • Periodically review the CORS settings to ensure they align with evolving security requirements and trusted domain lists.

References:

  • OpenStack Swift Documentation on CORS
  • Mozilla Developer Network on CORS

countermeasure.name: Enforce correct ACLs for Swift data access
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the OpenStack Swift Documentation on Access Control Lists for guidance on best practices in configuring and auditing ACLs.

Configure and Audit ACLs:

  • Define and implement ACLs that explicitly grant access only to intended users or groups for each Swift container or object.
  • Regularly review and audit ACL configurations to ensure they remain accurate and reflect any changes in user roles or organizational policies.

Test and Validate:

  • Verify that ACL settings restrict data access as intended by performing access tests with both authorized and unauthorized users.
  • Monitor audit logs to confirm that any changes or access attempts are properly recorded and reviewed.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate ACL audit reports into your centralized monitoring system to detect unauthorized modifications.
  • Schedule periodic audits to update ACL configurations in response to evolving security requirements and ensure compliance with your security policies.

References:

  • OpenStack Swift Documentation on Access Control Lists
  • OpenStack Swift Official Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enforce Keystone authentication for Swift data access
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the OpenStack Swift Documentation on Authentication Systems for guidance on integrating authentication middleware and best practices for securing data access.

Integrate Keystone Authentication:

  • Update Swift configuration files (e.g., swift.conf) to enable Keystone integration for authentication.
  • Configure the authentication middleware to verify and validate Keystone tokens, ensuring that only authorized users can access Swift data.
  • Adjust settings to enforce strict access controls and align with your organizational security policies.

Test and Validate:

  • Use both authorized and unauthorized test scenarios to confirm that only users with valid Keystone tokens can access the data.
  • Monitor authentication logs to ensure that the middleware is correctly enforcing access restrictions.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor access logs and integrate them into your centralized monitoring or SIEM system to detect any unauthorized attempts.
  • Periodically review and update your Keystone integration and Swift authentication settings to maintain compliance with evolving security standards.

References:

  • OpenStack Swift Documentation on Authentication Systems
  • OpenStack Keystone Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enforce metadata encryption for Swift objects
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the OpenStack Swift Documentation on Object Encryption for guidance on encrypting sensitive metadata and protecting object data.

Configure Metadata Encryption:

  • Identify the sensitive metadata fields within your Swift objects that require encryption.
  • Implement encryption at the application layer or use Swift's built-in support for object encryption if available, ensuring that metadata is encrypted both at rest and in transit.
  • Integrate with a key management system (e.g., OpenStack Barbican) to securely store and manage encryption keys used for protecting metadata.

Test and Validate:

  • Perform tests to ensure that the encryption process correctly secures metadata and that only authorized entities can decrypt it.
  • Use encryption validation tools to confirm that metadata is not stored in plaintext in logs or backups.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate metadata encryption checks into your continuous monitoring system to detect any lapses in encryption.
  • Periodically audit encryption configurations and key management practices to ensure ongoing compliance with security standards.

References:

  • OpenStack Swift Documentation on Object Encryption
  • OpenStack Barbican Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enforce rate limiting and quotas for Swift uploads
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the OpenStack Swift Documentation on Rate Limiting for detailed guidance on setting up rate limiting and quotas.

Configure Rate Limiting:

  • Update Swift configuration files to enforce rate limiting on API endpoints that handle object uploads.
  • Define thresholds for the maximum number of requests and data volume per tenant within a specified timeframe to prevent abuse.

Set Quotas:

  • Configure quotas to limit the number and size of objects that a user or tenant can upload.
  • Use Swifts quota management features to ensure that resource usage is balanced and that no single user can consume disproportionate storage capacity.

Test and Validate:

  • Simulate upload scenarios to verify that rate limits and quotas are correctly enforced, ensuring that excessive upload attempts are throttled or blocked.
  • Monitor logs to check that quota violations and rate limiting events are accurately recorded and reported.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate rate limiting and quota metrics into your centralized monitoring system to track user behavior and detect potential abuse.
  • Periodically review and adjust the thresholds based on evolving usage patterns and security requirements.

References:

  • OpenStack Swift Documentation on Rate Limiting
  • OpenStack Swift Official Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enforce Swift auditing mechanisms for replication integrity
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the OpenStack Swift Documentation on Replication for detailed guidance on Swift's replication and auditing mechanisms.

Configure Auditing Mechanisms:

  • Enable and configure Swift's built-in auditing features to monitor data replication processes.
  • Set up alerts and automated checks that verify the integrity of replicated data, detecting any instances of corruption.

Test and Validate:

  • Perform replication tests in a controlled environment to ensure that corrupted data is promptly detected and replication is halted or corrected.
  • Review audit logs to confirm that the system accurately reports anomalies and triggers appropriate alerts.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate auditing logs with your centralized monitoring system to continuously track replication integrity.
  • Schedule periodic reviews of replication and auditing configurations to ensure they remain effective and compliant with security policies.

References:

  • OpenStack Swift Documentation on Replication
  • OpenStack Swift Official Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enforce Swift object encryption for data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the OpenStack Swift Documentation on Object Encryption for detailed guidance on enabling and managing object encryption.

Configure Object Encryption:

  • Update your Swift proxy server configuration to enable object encryption for data stored on disk.
  • Configure the necessary encryption settings and key management options, integrating with a key management service if available.
  • Ensure that encryption is applied to all objects at rest, protecting data from unauthorized access.

Test and Validate:

  • Deploy the configuration in a test environment and verify that objects stored in Swift are encrypted on disk using encryption validation tools.
  • Confirm that only authorized services or users with proper decryption keys can access the encrypted data.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate encryption status checks into your monitoring framework to detect any misconfigurations or failures in encryption processes.
  • Periodically review key management and encryption configurations to ensure compliance with evolving security standards.

References:

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS encryption for Swift communications
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the OpenStack Security Guide on Secure Communication for best practices on implementing TLS encryption.

Configure TLS for Swift:

  • Update Swift configuration files (e.g., swift.conf or the proxy server configuration) to enable TLS encryption for all data in transit.
  • Install and configure valid SSL/TLS certificates on Swift endpoints to ensure that all communications are encrypted.
  • Ensure that any unencrypted protocols are disabled, enforcing the use of HTTPS.

Test and Validate:

  • Restart Swift services and verify that all communications are encrypted using tools such as SSL Labs or your browser's developer tools.
  • Confirm that attempts to connect using non-secure channels are blocked or redirected to TLS-secured connections.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor network traffic and log files to verify that TLS encryption remains in effect.
  • Periodically review TLS configurations and certificate expiry dates to ensure ongoing compliance with security standards.

References:

  • OpenStack Security Guide on Secure Communication
  • OpenStack Swift Documentation

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Denial of Service (DoS) through large object uploads
threat.desc:
General threat description

OpenStack Swift allows users to upload large objects by splitting them into segments and uploading them individually. Attackers can abuse this feature by repeatedly uploading massive or excessive segmented objects, overwhelming storage, compute, or network resources, and degrading performance or availability of the Swift cluster.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Malicious or careless tenants uploading excessively large or numerous objects.
  • Automated scripts or bots repeatedly issuing segmented upload requests.
  • Compromised accounts abusing legitimate credentials to flood the service.

Impacts

  • Exhaustion of storage capacity or I/O bandwidth.
  • Degraded performance for legitimate users.
  • Potential crash or hang of proxy or storage nodes.
  • Increased operational cost due to resource overuse.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Tenant uploads millions of large segments via the Static Large Object (SLO) or Dynamic Large Object (DLO) feature, consuming storage node capacity.
  2. Scripted upload flood overwhelms proxy servers with simultaneous large object PUT requests.
  3. Multiple partial uploads left incomplete, consuming metadata and space without cleanup.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to misconfigured ACLs
threat.desc:
General threat description

Swift uses Access Control Lists (ACLs) to define who can read or write to containers and objects. Incorrectly configured ACLssuch as overly permissive settings or missing restrictionscan allow unauthorized users to access, modify, or delete data.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External users accessing containers with public-read or write permissions.
  • Malicious tenants discovering and exploiting open containers or objects.
  • Developers or admins unintentionally misconfiguring ACLs via API or dashboard.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized data exposure, tampering, or deletion.
  • Loss of data confidentiality and integrity.
  • Breach of compliance obligations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA).

Example attack scenarios

  1. Container with public-write ACL is used by an attacker to store malicious files.
  2. ACL typo grants read access to all authenticated users across the environment.
  3. Misconfigured ACL allows object listing and download by unauthenticated users.

threat.name: Data exposure from compromised storage media
threat.desc:
General threat description

OpenStack Swift stores data across multiple storage nodes. If a physical disk or storage device is lost, decommissioned, or accessed without proper safeguards (e.g., encryption or secure wiping), it may lead to exposure of sensitive tenant data.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Insiders or attackers with physical access to decommissioned or failed disks.
  • Improper disposal or resale of storage hardware without secure erasure.
  • Lack of encryption for data at rest on Swift storage nodes.

Impacts

  • Loss of confidentiality for tenant data.
  • Regulatory and compliance violations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA).
  • Reputational damage and tenant distrust.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Retired disk reused or sold without proper wiping, allowing recovery of stored objects.
  2. Stolen storage node with unencrypted disks yields readable tenant data.
  3. Failed disk sent for RMA without secure erase, exposing sensitive content.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1005 - Data from Local System

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive metadata
threat.desc:
General threat description

Swift stores and manages metadata for accounts, containers, and objects. If access controls are weak or metadata is improperly exposed (e.g., through public containers or insecure APIs), attackers may gain insights into sensitive operational or user-specific information.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Unauthorized users accessing public containers with exposed metadata.
  • Malicious tenants querying object or container metadata via Swift APIs.
  • Insiders misusing access privileges to enumerate or extract metadata.

Impacts

  • Disclosure of internal naming conventions, timestamps, and user data.
  • Facilitation of targeted attacks or social engineering.
  • Violation of privacy or compliance requirements.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Public container reveals object metadata like filenames, user info, or timestamps.
  2. Scripted metadata queries collect data across multiple containers for profiling.
  3. Leaked URL with metadata headers provides attacker insights into usage patterns or data classification.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description

Swift supports CORS to enable web applications to access resources from different origins. Misconfigured CORS settingssuch as overly permissive Access-Control-Allow-Origin headerscan allow untrusted domains to interact with Swift containers and objects, potentially exposing sensitive data.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Malicious websites issuing cross-origin requests to Swift APIs.
  • Tenants misconfiguring CORS policies on public containers.
  • Attackers exploiting wildcard origins (*) or lack of strict headers.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to object metadata or contents via the browser.
  • Leakage of sensitive data through JavaScript in malicious domains.
  • Circumvention of same-origin policy in client browsers.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Container with Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * allows attackers site to read public object metadata.
  2. JavaScript exploit on malicious domain uses victim's browser to fetch objects from Swift.
  3. CORS misconfig on sensitive container enables unintended cross-site access to private data.

threat.name: Data interception during transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description

Swift transfers data between clients and storage nodes over the network. If encryption in transit is not enforced, attackers can intercept this data using techniques like packet sniffing or man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks, leading to loss of confidentiality.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Network-based attackers on the same physical or virtual network.
  • Compromised routers or switches intercepting unencrypted traffic.
  • Clients or services communicating with Swift over HTTP instead of HTTPS.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive data (e.g., PII, credentials, tokens).
  • Session hijacking or replay attacks.
  • Regulatory violations due to insecure data transmission.

Example attack scenarios

  1. User uploads objects over HTTP, and attacker on the same network captures the file contents.
  2. MitM attack intercepts authentication tokens during Swift API access.
  3. Internal service-to-service communication in plaintext allows internal actor to harvest metadata or data content.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General threat description

OpenStack Swift stores user and application data in objects and containers. If authentication, authorization, or access controls are weak or misconfigured, unauthorized users may access or manipulate data, leading to confidentiality breaches or data integrity issues.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers exploiting weak or missing access controls.
  • Malicious tenants accessing other users' data via exposed endpoints or tokens.
  • Compromised user accounts or service credentials.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive or regulated data.
  • Unauthorized data modification or deletion.
  • Loss of tenant trust and compliance failures.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Exposed Swift endpoint allows unauthenticated users to retrieve objects.
  2. Token reuse enables one tenant to access another tenant's container.
  3. Misconfigured identity integration grants access to unauthorized users or services.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Replication of corrupted data
threat.desc:
General threat description

OpenStack Swift uses replication to maintain data durability and availability across storage nodes. If corrupted or malicious data is introduceddue to hardware faults, software bugs, or intentional tamperingSwift may replicate the corrupted data across multiple nodes, spreading the issue and making recovery difficult.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Hardware failures causing silent data corruption.
  • Malicious insiders or tenants uploading tampered or malformed objects.
  • Bugs in replication logic failing to detect and isolate bad data.

Impacts

  • Loss of data integrity across the cluster.
  • Difficulty in identifying or recovering original uncorrupted data.
  • Potential service degradation or client application failures.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Tenant uploads corrupted object, and Swift replicates it without integrity checks.
  2. Bit rot on a storage node is undetected, and replication overwrites good copies.
  3. Malicious user repeatedly replaces valid data with corrupted versions before replication kicks in.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

countermeasure.name: Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for a User Profile component adds an essential layer of security by requiring users to provide two or more verification factors to gain access or perform specific actions. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access resulting from compromised credentials. Heres a step-by-step guide to implementing MFA:

Step 1: Choose Your MFA Methods

  • Select at least two different authentication factors from the following categories: something the user knows (password or PIN), something the user has (a mobile device, security token, or smart card), and something the user is (biometric verification like fingerprints or facial recognition).
  • Consider user experience and security needs when selecting MFA methods. For instance, SMS-based codes and authentication apps are popular choices for their balance of convenience and security.

Step 2: Integrate MFA into Your User Profile System

  • Use a reputable MFA library or service that is compatible with your development stack. Many cloud providers and security companies offer MFA services that can be easily integrated into existing systems.
  • Configure the MFA service or library according to the provider's documentation, ensuring it is set up to manage the authentication factors you've chosen.

Step 3: Update Authentication Flows

  • Modify the login and sensitive action workflows to include MFA. After entering their standard credentials (e.g., username and password), prompt users to complete an additional authentication step.
  • Implement logic to handle different MFA methods, such as sending a code via SMS or email, generating time-based codes through an app, or prompting for biometric verification.

Step 4: Securely Store MFA Credentials

  • Store MFA secret keys or tokens securely, using encryption and secure access controls. Ensure they are protected both in transit and at rest.
  • Follow best practices for any biometric data, ensuring it is stored in a manner that respects privacy and is secure against unauthorized access.

Step 5: Provide User Instructions and Support

  • Guide users through setting up MFA for their profiles. Offer clear instructions on activating and using their chosen authentication factors.
  • Offer support for users who have issues with MFA, including options to reset or change their authentication factors if they lose access to their device or encounter other problems.

Step 6: Test and Monitor

  • Thoroughly test the MFA implementation across different devices and scenarios to ensure reliability and usability.
  • Monitor for failed authentication attempts and investigate any anomalies that could indicate attempted unauthorized access.

Best Practices and Considerations

  • Fallback options: Provide alternatives in case the primary MFA method fails (e.g., backup codes or secondary verification methods).
  • Rate limiting: Implement rate limiting for MFA attempts to prevent brute force attacks.
  • Compliance: Ensure your MFA implementation complies with relevant regulations and standards, such as GDPR for privacy or PCI DSS for payment information.
  • User education: Educate your users on the importance of MFA and how to securely manage their authentication factors.

By following these steps and considerations, developers can effectively implement MFA for the User Profile component, significantly enhancing the security posture of the application.

countermeasure.name: Implement secure session management
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard the "User Profile" software component through secure session management, follow these targeted, actionable steps. Secure session management is crucial to prevent unauthorized access and protect user data. This guidance focuses on creating and managing sessions securely, with an emphasis on web applications.

Step 1: Generate Secure Session Identifiers

  1. Use Secure, Random Values: Ensure session identifiers (IDs) are generated using a cryptographically secure random number generator.
  2. Maintain Sufficient Length: Session IDs should be long enough to prevent brute force attacks. Aim for at least 128 bits of entropy.

Step 2: Use HTTPS for All Transactions

  1. Implement HTTPS: Ensure that all communication between the client and server is encrypted using HTTPS to protect the session ID and other sensitive data in transit.
  2. Secure Cookies: Set the Secure attribute on all cookies to ensure they are only sent over encrypted connections.

Step 3: Proper Session Expiration

  1. Set Timeout Limits: Implement automatic session expiration. Sessions should time out after a predefined period of inactivity (e.g., 15 to 30 minutes).
  2. Clear Session at Logout: Ensure that sessions are completely invalidated and cleared from the server upon user logout.

Step 4: Implement Cookie Attributes Correctly

  1. HttpOnly Attribute: Set the HttpOnly attribute for cookies to prevent access to the session cookie via client-side scripts, mitigating the risk of cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
  2. SameSite Attribute: Use the SameSite attribute to restrict how cookies are sent with cross-site requests, providing some protection against cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks.

Step 5: Validate Session ID for Every Request

  1. Verify Sessions: Check the validity of the session ID for every request to ensure it matches the user and hasn't been tampered with.
  2. Regenerate Session IDs: Upon login, logout, and during regular intervals, regenerate session IDs to mitigate session fixation attacks.

Step 6: Store Sessions Securely

  1. Use Server-Side Storage: Preferably store session data on the server side where possible, using a secure and scalable session management system.
  2. Encrypt Sensitive Data: If any sensitive information must be stored within the session, ensure it is encrypted.

Good Security Practices

  • Monitor and Log Session Activities: Implement monitoring to detect unusual session patterns or behaviors that may indicate an attack.
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Protection: Sanitize user input and implement content security policies to prevent XSS attacks, which can compromise session security.
  • Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection: Use anti-CSRF tokens in forms and requests to ensure that state-changing requests originate from your application.
  • Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular security reviews and penetration testing focused on session management to identify and rectify potential vulnerabilities.

By following these steps, developers can significantly enhance the security of user sessions within their applications, protecting both user data and the integrity of the application itself.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Sanitize all input to avoid injection attacks
countermeasure.desc:
When developing software, particularly components like user profiles that accept user-generated input, its crucial to mitigate the risk of injection attacks. Injection attacks occur when attackers input malicious data that the system interprets and executes as commands. This can lead to unauthorized access, data leaks, and system compromise. To prevent such vulnerabilities, follow these steps to sanitize inputs effectively:

Validate Input Strictly:

  • Enforce strict type, length, and format for all inputs. Use regular expressions to validate string inputs against expected patterns.
  • Implement client-side validation for immediate feedback but always perform server-side validation as the primary defense mechanism.

Employ Parameterized Queries:

  • Use parameterized queries or prepared statements for database access. This ensures that input is treated only as data and not executable code, effectively neutralizing SQL injection threats.

Utilize Content Security Policy (CSP):

  • Implement a Content Security Policy as an additional layer of protection against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks. CSP can restrict how and where content can be loaded, preventing the execution of unauthorized scripts.

Encode Data:

  • Before displaying user input on web pages or in application interfaces, encode the data to escape any characters that could be interpreted as executable code. This is especially crucial for HTML, JavaScript, and SQL outputs.

Leverage Security Libraries and Frameworks:

  • Take advantage of existing security libraries and frameworks that offer input sanitization and validation functions. These are often well-tested and updated to defend against emerging threats.

Conduct Regular Security Audits:

  • Regularly review and audit your codebase and dependencies for vulnerabilities. Automated security scanning tools can identify potential injection flaws in your application.

Educate and Train Developers:

  • Ensure that all team members are aware of the risks associated with injection attacks and understand the importance of input sanitization. Promote a culture of security within the development team.

Test for Vulnerabilities:

  • Implement comprehensive testing strategies, including static analysis, dynamic analysis, and penetration testing, to uncover and mitigate injection vulnerabilities.

By adhering to these guidelines and adopting a proactive security posture, developers can significantly reduce the risk of injection attacks on user profile components and other vulnerable parts of their applications. Always stay informed about the latest security best practices and vulnerabilities to maintain the robustness of your security measures.

customField.value: ATT&CK ICS - M0818 - Validate Program Inputs||ATT&CK Enterprise - M1013 - Application Developer Guidance

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of exposed sensitive data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposed sensitive data refers to personal or confidential information that becomes accessible to unauthorized individuals due to inadequate protection measures. In the context of a User Profile component, this could include names, email addresses, passwords, payment information, or any personal data that users submit. Exposure can occur through various means, such as improper access controls, lack of encryption, or inadvertent leaks via logs or error messages.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Includes cybercriminals aiming for identity theft or financial gain, competitors seeking confidential information, and insiders with malicious intent or negligence.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR): Attackers manipulate direct references to access other users' data.
    • Insufficient Data Encryption: Data transmitted or stored without encryption can be intercepted or accessed.
    • Misconfigured Databases or Servers: Incorrect configurations can expose data through unintended public access points.
    • Caching Mechanisms: Sensitive information stored in cache without proper access controls could be leaked.

Impacts

  • Identity Theft: Exposed personal details can lead to identity theft, significantly impacting users' lives.
  • Financial Loss: Exposure of payment information can lead to unauthorized transactions and financial losses for users.
  • Reputation Damage: Organizations responsible for data breaches face severe reputational damage, eroding trust among users and partners.
  • Legal and Compliance Violations: Breaches involving sensitive data can result in legal penalties, fines, and failure to comply with data protection regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. IDOR Exploit: An attacker discovers that the user profile edit function is vulnerable to IDOR. By changing the user ID in the URL, they gain access to and modify other users' profiles, harvesting sensitive data.
  2. Database Misconfiguration: A database containing user profiles is mistakenly configured to allow public access. Sensitive user data is indexed by search engines, making it easily accessible to anyone performing a simple search.
  3. Insecure API Endpoint: An API endpoint designed to fetch user profile details does not properly verify the requestor's identity or permissions. Attackers exploit this by crafting requests that retrieve personal information of all users.
  4. Error Message Leakage: A coding error in the user profile management system leads to detailed error messages being displayed, including sensitive database information. Attackers use this information to further exploit the system.

To mitigate the risk of exposed sensitive data:

  • Implement Strict Access Controls: Ensure that only authenticated and authorized users can access or modify user profile data.
  • Encrypt Sensitive Data: Use strong encryption for storing and transmitting user data.
  • Regularly Audit and Configure Security Settings: Regularly review and update configurations for databases, servers, and applications to prevent accidental exposure.
  • Data Minimization: Collect and retain only the minimum necessary personal information for users.
  • Error Handling: Implement secure error handling practices that do not expose sensitive information in logs or error messages.
  • Educate Employees: Provide training on data protection best practices and the importance of maintaining the confidentiality of user data.

By addressing these aspects, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with the exposure of sensitive data within user profile components.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers exploit flaws in access control systems
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Access control systems are designed to restrict unauthorized users from performing certain actions within a software system, typically through mechanisms like authentication and authorization. Flaws in these systems can arise from misconfigurations, software vulnerabilities, or inadequate security policies, potentially allowing attackers to bypass security measures. This can lead to unauthorized access to or manipulation of user profiles and associated data, which may contain sensitive personal information, preferences, and security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents include:

  1. Cybercriminals: Seeking financial gain through data theft, fraud, or selling access.
  2. Disgruntled Employees: Internal actors who exploit their knowledge of the system's weaknesses.
  3. Competitors: Looking to gain a competitive edge by stealing confidential data.
  4. Hacktivists or State-Sponsored Actors: Targeting systems for political, ideological, or strategic reasons.

Attack Vectors involve:

  1. Privilege Escalation: Exploiting vulnerabilities to gain elevated access rights.
  2. Authorization Bypass: Manipulating the system to access functions or data without proper authorization.
  3. Credential Stuffing: Using breached username and password pairs to gain unauthorized access.
  4. Session Hijacking: Exploiting flaws in session management to take over a user's legitimate session.

Impacts

  1. Data Breach: Unauthorized access to user profiles can lead to the exposure of sensitive personal and financial information.
  2. Identity Theft: Attackers can use stolen data for impersonation and fraud.
  3. Loss of Integrity: Modification of user data can lead to incorrect or malicious actions being taken on behalf of the user.
  4. Reputational Damage: Breaches can severely damage an organization's reputation, leading to loss of trust and customers.
  5. Regulatory and Legal Consequences: Non-compliance with data protection laws can result in fines and legal action.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a flaw in the application's role-based access control mechanism that allows unauthorized API calls to be made without proper role verification. The attacker exploits this to access and export user profiles en masse.

Scenario 2: Through credential stuffing, an attacker gains access to a user's profile with administrative privileges due to reused passwords from another breached service. The attacker then alters access controls to grant unauthorized access to other attackers.

Scenario 3: A session management vulnerability allows an attacker to hijack an authenticated user's session token. The attacker uses this token to impersonate the user, accessing and manipulating the user's profile information without detection.

To mitigate these threats, it's crucial to implement robust access control mechanisms, regularly update and patch software components, employ multi-factor authentication, conduct regular security audits and vulnerability assessments, and educate users about security best practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1556 - Modify Authentication Process||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1110 - Brute Force||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1111 - Multi-Factor Authentication Interception||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1187 - Forced Authentication

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

This threat involves attackers injecting malicious code into systems by exploiting security weaknesses in the software component handling user profiles. The injected code could range from scripts designed to steal data to commands that compromise the integrity or availability of the system. This vulnerability often stems from insufficient input validation, allowing attackers to insert and execute unauthorized code within the system's operational context.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

The primary threat agents are cyber attackers ranging from individual hackers to organized cybercrime groups. They exploit vulnerabilities in the software's input validation processes, using attack vectors such as crafted inputs submitted through forms, URLs, or any interface that accepts user data. The attackers might also employ social engineering techniques to trick users into executing the malicious code themselves.

Impacts:

The impacts of such an attack can be severe and multifaceted, including:

  • Unauthorized access to or theft of sensitive user data, potentially leading to identity theft or financial fraud.
  • Compromise of system integrity, allowing attackers to alter or delete critical data.
  • Disruption of service, which could degrade the user experience or completely disable the service.
  • Damage to the organizations reputation, leading to loss of trust among users and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios:

Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a vulnerability in the user profile component of a web application that fails to properly sanitize input. The attacker crafts a malicious script that is executed when a user views their profile. This script steals the user's session cookie and sends it to the attacker, allowing them to hijack the user's session.

Scenario 2: In another instance, the attacker injects a SQL command into a poorly secured user input field related to the user profile. This injection manipulates the backend database to grant the attacker unauthorized access to other users' profiles, exposing personal information or even altering user privileges.

Scenario 3: An attacker exploits a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in a user profile page to inject a malicious script. When any user visits the infected profile, the script redirects them to a phishing site controlled by the attacker, aiming to steal their credentials.

To mitigate such threats, organizations should employ rigorous input validation, implement content security policies, regularly update and patch software components, and educate users on secure practices.

countermeasure.name: Evaluate the library/service security posture
countermeasure.desc:
Create a workflow for the team to evaluate the security and integrity of data handled by third-party libraries or services integrated into your analytics and visualization projects by following these actionable steps:

  • Assess the service's security and privacy track record. Research any past security breaches or vulnerabilities that have been publicly disclosed. Use resources like CVE (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) and NVD (National Vulnerability Database) to check for any known issues.
  • Verify that the service implements robust encryption techniques to protect data both in transit and at rest. Ensure configurations allow for secure integration practices. Consult the OWASP Cheat Sheet Series for best practices on secure communication and storage.
  • Confirm that the service minimizes data retention, especially for sensitive data and metadata. Ensure that any data storage complies with applicable privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA). Review the services data retention policies and mechanisms for secure data deletion.
  • Continuously monitor the security practices of the service provider. Subscribe to their security bulletins or use automated tools like Google Alerts to stay informed about any updates or issues related to their services.

By systematically evaluating the security measures and practices of third-party services, developers can better protect sensitive data and comply with regulatory requirements.

reference.name: How do you evaluate third-party libraries for security?

countermeasure.name: Secure data connectors and API integration
countermeasure.desc:
To protect the integrity and confidentiality of data exchanged between your system and any utilized libraries or tools, adhere to the following steps:

  • Regularly update all libraries to mitigate vulnerabilities exposed in older versions. Utilize tools like Dependabot or Snyk to automate dependency updates and vulnerability alerts.
  • Restrict API access to authorized systems, services, and users only. Implement authentication mechanisms such as API keys, tokens, or OAuth. Ensure that these credentials are stored securely, such as in environment variables or dedicated secrets management tools.
  • Encrypt data in transit using TLS protocols to safeguard data from interception and tampering. Ensure that TLS implementation is up-to-date by following guidelines from the OpenSSL Project or similar.
  • Continuously monitor API interactions and data transfers for unusual or unauthorized activities. Set up logging for all access and transactions to facilitate auditing and forensic analysis. Tools like Splunk or ELK Stack can be instrumental for monitoring and logging.
  • Implement input validation techniques to prevent common web vulnerabilities such as cross-site scripting (XSS) and SQL injection. Tools like OWASP ESAPI can be utilized for secure input handling.

By following these steps, developers without prior security experience can significantly enhance the security of data connectors and API integrations in their applications.

reference.name: How to Prevent Data Breach Risks in Integration and Third-Party Apps
Navigating Third-Party Library Security: Best Practices for Safe Dependency Management

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to sensitive data exposed through misconfigurations or vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When integrating third-party data analytics and visualization tools or libraries, organizations may encounter misalignments in security postures. Such discrepancies can expose sensitive data through misconfigurations or vulnerabilities inherent in these tools. This exposure is particularly concerning if the third-party service fails to adhere to stringent data protection standards such as GDPR or HIPAA, which are crucial for maintaining confidentiality and compliance.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors
Threat agents include external attackers exploiting known vulnerabilities, insiders exploiting system weaknesses, or even third-party vendors whose inadequate security measures provide a gateway to sensitive data. Common attack vectors involve exploiting misconfigurations in the analytics setup, using compromised credentials to gain unauthorized access, or exploiting vulnerabilities within the analytics and visualization software itself.

Impacts
The consequences of unauthorized access to sensitive data through these vulnerabilities can be severe. Beyond the immediate breach of confidentiality, there can be a violation of compliance regulations, resulting in hefty fines and damaged reputations. Furthermore, the integrity of data analysis and business decision-making processes can be compromised, leading to strategic missteps based on inaccurate or manipulated data insights.

Example Attack Scenarios
Scenario 1: An attacker discovers a misconfiguration in a data visualization tool that exposes sensitive customer data. Using this access point, the attacker extracts data, leading to a significant breach of customer privacy and compliance violations.
Scenario 2: A developer integrates a visualization library without properly assessing its security features, leading to the integration of a library with known vulnerabilities. An attacker exploits these vulnerabilities to inject malicious code, gaining access to the entire data flow within the organization.

reference.name: A05:2021 Security Misconfiguration
Security Misconfigurations Caused 35% of All Time Cyber Incidents

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers inject malicious or erroneous data into your analytics and visualization pipeline
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
In this scenario, attackers target the data analytics and visualization tools or libraries integrated into applications. By injecting malicious or erroneous data into the analytics and visualization pipeline, attackers can manipulate the output and functionality of these tools. This manipulation not only misleads end-users with deceptive data visualizations but can also serve as a conduit for executing more severe attacks, including the execution of malicious scripts directly through the visualization components.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors
The primary threat agents in this scenario are cyber attackers who possess skills in crafting deceptive data or scripts capable of compromising data integrity or security. These attackers may include external malicious actors, insider threats, or even third parties with temporary access to the system. Common attack vectors involve injecting falsified data or scripts into data streams that feed into the visualization tools, exploiting weak input validation mechanisms to deliver malicious payloads.

Impacts
The impacts of such attacks are multifaceted. Initially, there is the direct deception of users through manipulated visual data, which can lead to erroneous business decisions. More dangerously, if the attack escalates to script execution, it could result in cross-site scripting (XSS), where attackers might steal sensitive information, compromise user sessions, or gain unauthorized access to broader systems and data repositories.

Example Attack Scenarios
Scenario 1: An attacker injects falsified sales data into a visualization tool used by a retail company. This leads the company to make poor inventory decisions based on the manipulated high demand visualized for certain products.
Scenario 2: Through a compromised user account, an attacker injects a script into the data source for a popular visualization library used in an enterprise's reporting dashboard. The script executes as an XSS attack, stealing session tokens of the enterprise's finance team and gaining unauthorized access to sensitive financial reports.

reference.name: Data Tampering: A Comprehensive Guide
